chestnut.eng_def: a large tree with leaves divided into five parts and large, round nuts
a large, brown nut that grows on a sweet chestnut tree, often cooked and eaten hot
chestnut.eg: A man in the street was selling bags of roast chestnuts.

chestnut.chi_def: 栗色的，紅褐色的，紅棕色的

chew.eng_def: to crush food into smaller, softer pieces with the teeth so that it can be swallowed
chew.eg: This meat is difficult to chew.

chew.eng_def: to bite something with your teeth, usually in order to taste its flavour
chew.eg: Would you like some gum to chew?

chew.eng_def: a piece of hard food that can be given to an animal to chew
a hard sweet that gets softer the more you chew it

chick.eng_def: a baby bird, especially a young chicken
a young woman. This word is considered offensive by many women.

chicken.eng_def: a type of bird kept on a farm for its eggs or its meat, or the meat of this bird that is cooked and eaten
chicken.eg: A male chicken is called a cock and a female chicken is called a hen.

chicken.eng_def: a person who is not brave

chicken.eg: Why won't you jump? Are you chicken?

chief.chi_def: 首要的；最重要的；最主要的
chief.eg: The chief problem we have in the area now is the spread of disease.

chief.eng_def: the person in charge of a group or organization, or the ruler of a tribe

child.eng_def: a boy or girl from the time of birth until he or she is an adult, or a son or daughter of any age
an adult who behaves badly, like a badly behaved child
child.chi_def: 孩子氣的人；任性妄為的人
child.eg: He's such a child if he doesn't get his own way.

child.eng_def: someone who has been very influenced by a particular period or situation
child.chi_def: 深受（某一時期或形勢）影響的人
child.eg: Me, I'm a child of the 60s.

childhood.eng_def: the time when someone is a child
childhood.chi_def: 童年；孩童時期，孩提時代

childish.eng_def: If an adult is childish, they behave badly in a way that would be expected of a child.
childish.eg: He wasn't enjoying the occasion so he thought he'd spoil it for everyone else - it was very childish of him.

childlike.eng_def: (of adults) showing the good qualities that children have, such as trusting people, being honest and enthusiastic
childlike.chi_def: （成人）孩子般的，單純的，純真無邪的

chill.eng_def: to (cause to) become cold but not freeze
chill.eg: I've put the beer in the fridge to chill.
There was a chill in the air this morning.
Don't go out with wet hair, you might catch a chill.

chill.eng_def: a sudden unpleasant feeling, especially of fear
chill.chi_def: 害怕的感覺；（尤指恐懼引起的）寒氣，寒意
chill.eg: I suddenly realized, with a chill of apprehension, the danger ahead.

chilly.eng_def: (of weather, conditions in a room, or parts of the body) cold
chilly.chi_def: （天氣、房間或人體）寒冷的，涼颼颼的
chilly.eg: The bathroom gets chilly in the winter.
I went to see the sales manager but got a rather chilly reception.

chimney.eng_def: a hollow structure that allows the smoke from a fire inside a building to escape to the air outside
chimney.eg: Factory chimneys belched dense white smoke into the sky.

chimney.eng_def: a narrow vertical passage in the rock of a cliff or mountain, through which a person can climb
chimney.chi_def: （可容一人攀登的）岩石狹縫，一線天

chimpanzee.eng_def: a small, very intelligent African ape with black or brown fur

chin.eng_def: the part of a person's face below their mouth
chin.eg: To keep the helmet in position, fasten the strap beneath the chin.

chip.eng_def: a long, thin piece of potato that is fried and usually eaten hot
a very thin, often round piece of fried potato, sometimes with a flavour added, sold especially in plastic bags
a thin slice of fried maize, banana, or other food that is eaten cold
a very small piece of semiconductor, especially in a computer, that contains extremely small electronic circuits and devices, and can perform particular operations
a small piece that has been broken off a larger object, or the mark left on an object such as a cup, plate, etc. where a small piece has been broken off it
chip.chi_def: （脫落的）碎屑，碎片；（杯、碟等的）缺口

chip.eng_def: a small plastic disc used to represent a particular amount of money in gambling
chip.eg: The hostages are being held as a bargaining chip by terrorist organizations.

chip.eng_def: a kick in football or a hit in golf, in which the ball goes high into the air for a short time
chip.chi_def: （足球的）挑球；（高爾夫球的）輕擊短打
chip.eg: His splendid chip from the 18 yard line caught the goalkeeper off his line.

chip.eng_def: to break a small piece off something by accident
chip.eg: I wish my nail polish wouldn't keep chipping.

chip.eng_def: to kick a football or hit a golf ball high into the air for a short distance.
chip.chi_def: （足球）挑球；（高爾夫球）輕擊短打
chip.eg: Berbatov managed to sidestep a tackle and chip the keeper.

chirp.eng_def: (especially of a bird) to make a short high sound or sounds
to say something with a high, happy voice
chirp.chi_def: 輕鬆愉快地說，快活地說

chocolate.eng_def: a sweet, usually brown, food made from cacao seeds, that is usually sold in a block, or a small sweet made from this

choice.eng_def: an act or the possibility of choosing
choice.eg: If the product doesn't work, you are given the choice of a refund or a replacement.

choice.eng_def: the range of different things from which you can choose
choice.chi_def: 可供選擇的東西；選擇範圍
choice.eg: There wasn't much choice on the menu.

choice.eng_def: a person or thing that has been chosen or that can be chosen
choice.chi_def: 入選者；被選中的東西；選項
choice.eg: Harvard was not his first choice.
I had the the most expensive dish on the menu - a choice fillet of fish.

choir.eng_def: a group of people who sing together
choir.chi_def: 合唱團；（尤指教堂的）唱詩班
choir.eg: He sings in the church choir.

choir.eng_def: the area in a church where the choir sits

choke.eng_def: If you choke, or if something chokes you, you stop breathing because something is blocking your throat.
choke.eg: She choked to death on a fish bone.

choke.eng_def: to make someone stop breathing by pressing their throat with the hands
choke.chi_def: （掐住喉嚨）使停止呼吸，使窒息

choke.eng_def: to fill something such as a road or pipe, so that nothing can pass through
choke.eg: At lunchtime the streets were choked with traffic.

choke.eng_def: (usually in sports) to fail to do something at a time when it is urgent, usually because you suddenly lose confidence
choke.chi_def: （通常指在運動中關鍵時刻因喪失信心而）失敗；怯場
choke.eg: He could score points at will during the qualifying matches, but in the final he completely choked.

choke.eng_def: a device in a motor vehicle that changes the amount of air going into the engine, allowing more fuel compared to air to go in and therefore making the engine easier to start

cholesterol.eng_def: a substance containing a lot of fat that is found in the body tissue and blood of all animals, thought to be part of the cause of heart disease if there is too much of it
cholesterol.eg: an oil that is high in polyunsaturates and low in cholesterol

choose.eng_def: to decide what you want from two or more things or possibilities
choose.eg: She had to choose between the two men in her life.
Katie chose (= decided) to stay away from work that day.

choose.eng_def: When there is little to choose between two or more things, they are (all) very similar.
choose.chi_def: 沒甚麼可挑的；相差無幾；不相上下

chop.eng_def: to cut something into pieces with an axe, knife, or other sharp instrument
chop.eg: He was chopping wood in the yard.

chop.eng_def: If something is chopped in business, it is stopped or reduced.
chop.chi_def: 減少，削減（資金或生意）；終止（生意）
chop.eg: Because of lack of funding many long-term research projects are being chopped.

chop.eng_def: a small piece of meat with a bone still in it
an act of cutting something with an axe, knife, or other sharp instrument
the situation in which your job is taken away from you, either because you have done something wrong or as a way of saving money
chop.eg: If you're late for work again, you'll be for the chop.

chop.eng_def: the ending of a factory, school, etc. or plan
chop.eg: When the reorganization occurs, the smaller departments will be the first for the chop.

chop.eng_def: the area of the face surrounding the mouth of a person or an animal
ability and technical skill, especially in playing a musical instrument
chop.chi_def: 吹奏管樂器（如薩克斯風）時運用嘴巴的方式；演奏樂器的能力
chop.eg: The players show their jazz chops and modern sensibility.

chop.eng_def: the ability, skill, or experience needed to do something well
chop.eg: She just doesn't have the chops for this demanding role.

chopstick.eng_def: one of a pair of narrow sticks that are used for eating East Asian food

chord.eng_def: three or more musical notes played at the same time
chord.eg: She strummed a few chords on her guitar.

chore.eng_def: a job or piece of work that is often boring or unpleasant but needs to be done regularly
chore.chi_def: 日常瑣事；雜務；乏味的例行工作
chore.eg: I'll go shopping when I've done my chores (= done the jobs in or around the house).

chorus.eng_def: part of a song that is repeated several times, usually after each verse (= set of lines)
chorus.chi_def: （通常在歌曲每一節後的）副歌，合唱部分；合唱曲
chorus.eg: I'll sing the verses and I'd like you all to join in the chorus.

chorus.eng_def: a piece of music written to be sung by a choir (= group of singers)
chorus.eg: The choir will be performing the Hallelujah Chorus at the concert.

chorus.eng_def: a group of people who are trained to sing together
chorus.eg: He sings with the Los Angeles Gay Men's Chorus.

chorus.eng_def: a group of performers who, as a team, sing or dance in a show
chorus.eg: She quickly left the chorus for a starring role.

chorus.eng_def: a group of actors in ancient Greek plays who explained or gave opinions on what was happening in the play using music, poetry, and dance
chorus.chi_def: （古希臘戲劇中解釋劇情的）歌隊，合唱隊

chorus.eng_def: many people speaking together or saying a similar thing at the same time
chorus.eg: The newcomers added their voices to the chorus expressing delight at the result.

chorus.eng_def: (of a group of people) to say similar things at the same time
chorus.eg: "Not now," the children chorused in unison, "we're watching TV."

chronic.eng_def: (especially of a disease or something bad) continuing for a long time
chronic.chi_def: （尤指疾病或不好的事物）慢性的，長期的

chubby.eng_def: (especially of children) fat in a pleasant and attractive way
chubby.chi_def: （尤指兒童）圓圓胖胖的，胖乎乎的，豐滿的

chuckle.eg: She was chuckling as she read the letter.

chunk.eng_def: a part of something, especially a large part
chunk.chi_def: 一部分；（尤指）大部分，一大塊

church.eng_def: a building for Christian religious activities

church.eg: All the local churches were represented at the memorial service.

church.eng_def: an occasion when this organization meets as a group of people

church.eg: Some people think the Church shouldn't interfere in politics.

cigar.eng_def: a tube made from dried and rolled tobacco leaves that people smoke

cigarette.eng_def: a small paper tube filled with cut pieces of tobacco that people smoke

cinema.eng_def: a theatre where people pay to watch films
cinema.eg: The town no longer has a cinema.
He was well known for his work in the cinema.

cinema.eng_def: to go to watch a film

circle.eng_def: a continuous curved line, the points of which are always the same distance away from a fixed central point, or the area inside such a line
circle.eg: Coloured paper was cut into circles.

circle.eng_def: a group of people with family, work, or social connections
circle.eg: The subject was never discussed outside the family circle.

circle.eng_def: an upper floor in a theatre or cinema where people sit to watch the performance
circle.eg: Shall I get seats in the circle or in the stalls?

circle.eng_def: to move in a circle, often around something
circle.eg: The plane circled for an hour before receiving permission to land.

circle.eng_def: to draw a circle around something
circle.eg: Circle the answer you think is correct.

circuit.eng_def: a regular pattern of visits or the places visited
circuit.eg: They first met each other on the tennis circuit (= while at different tennis competitions).

circuit.eng_def: a particular area containing different courts that a judge visits
circuit.eg: The judge had served for many years on the northeastern Circuit.

circuit.eng_def: something shaped approximately like a circle, especially a route, path, or sports track that starts and ends in the same place
circuit.chi_def: 環行物；（尤指）環形道路（或路線、賽道）
circuit.eg: They test the car tyres on a motor racing circuit.

circuit.eng_def: a closed system of wires or pipes through which electricity or liquid can flow
circuit.eg: A defect was found in the water-cooling/electrical circuit.

circular.eng_def: A circular argument is one that keeps returning to the same points and is not effective.
circular.chi_def: 循環論證的；迂迴而無效的

circular.eng_def: a letter or notice sent to a large number of people
circular.chi_def: （同時發給很多人的）通知，通報，傳單
circular.eg: Circulars and other junk mail go straight in the bin.

circulate.eng_def: to go around or through something, or to make something go around or through something
circulate.chi_def: （使）循環；（使）流通；（使）傳遞；（使）散佈
circulate.eg: Hot water circulates through the heating system.

circulate.eng_def: to move around at a party, etc., talking to different people
circulate.eg: I try to circulate at a party and not just stay with the friends I came with.

circulation.eng_def: the process in which something such as information, money, or goods passes from one person to another
circulation.chi_def: （資訊）流傳，傳播；（貨幣或商品）流通
circulation.eg: Police have warned that there are a lot of fake £50 notes in circulation.

circulation.eng_def: the number of people that a newspaper or magazine is regularly sold to
circulation.eg: The paper has a circulation of 150,000.

circulation.eng_def: the movement of blood around the body

circumstance.eng_def: a fact or event that makes a situation the way it is
circumstance.eg: I think she coped very well under the circumstances.

circumstance.eng_def: events that change your life, over which you have no control
circumstance.chi_def: 無法控制的因素；客觀環境；命運

circumstance.eg: Grants are available depending on your circumstances.

circus.eng_def: a group of travelling performers including acrobats (= people skilled in difficult physical movements) or those who work with trained animals, or a performance by such people usually in a large tent
circus.chi_def: 馬戲團；馬戲演員；馬戲表演
circus.eg: She ran away to join the circus.

circus.eng_def: a lot of activity and interest caused by an event or situation
circus.chi_def: 鬧哄哄的情形；熱鬧的場面
circus.eg: the media circus surrounding the case

circus.eng_def: an open circular area where several roads join

cite.eng_def: to mention something as proof for a theory or as a reason why something has happened
cite.eg: She cited three reasons why people get into debt.

cite.eng_def: to speak or write words taken from a particular writer or written work
cite.eg: She cites both T.S. Eliot and Virginia Woolf in her article.

cite.eng_def: to officially name or mention someone or something in a law court, or to officially request someone to appear in a court of law
cite.eg: The lawyer cited two similar cases.

cite.eng_def: to praise someone in the armed forces publicly because of their brave actions

citizen.eng_def: a person who is a member of a particular country and who has rights because of being born there or because of being given rights, or a person who lives in a particular town or city
citizen.eg: The interests of British citizens living abroad are protected by the British Embassy.

city.eg: Many of the world's cities have populations of more than five million.

city.eng_def: any town in the UK that has a cathedral (= large, important church)
city.eg: The city of Ely has about 15,000 inhabitants.
It's the city's responsibility to maintain the pavements.

city.eng_def: the business centre of London where the large financial organizations are, such as the Bank of England
the financial organizations as a group and the people who work for them
city.eg: The City acted swiftly to the news of a fall in the value of sterling.

civic.eng_def: of a town or city or the people who live in it
civic.eg: The prime minister met many civic leaders, including the mayor and the leaders of the immigrant communities.

civil.eng_def: not military or religious, or relating to the ordinary people of a country
civil.chi_def: 文職的；民用的；平民的，國民的
civil.eg: Helicopters are mainly used for military rather than civil use.

civil.eng_def: relating to private arguments between people or organizations rather than criminal matters
civil.eg: The matter would be better dealt with in the civil court rather than by an expensive criminal proceeding.

civil.chi_def: 有禮貌的；文明的；客氣的
civil.eg: His manner was civil, though not particularly friendly.

civilian.eng_def: a person who is not a member of the police or the armed forces
civilian.eg: The bomb killed four soldiers and three civilians.

civilization.eng_def: human society with its well developed social organizations, or the culture and way of life of a society or country at a particular period in time
civilization.chi_def: 文明社會；（特定時期特定社會或國家的）文明，文化
civilization.eg: Some people think that nuclear war would mean the end of civilization.

civilization.eng_def: a place that has comfortable living conditions
civilization.chi_def: 文明世界，舒適的生活環境
civilization.eg: How does it feel to be back in civilization after all those weeks in a tent?

civilization.eng_def: the process of educating a society so that its culture becomes more developed
civilization.eg: The civilization of Britain by the Romans took years to complete.

civilize.eng_def: to educate a society so that its culture becomes more developed
civilize.eg: The Romans set out to civilize the Ancient Britons.
I like to think I had a civilizing effect on my younger brothers.

claim.eng_def: to say that something is true or is a fact, although you cannot prove it and other people might not believe it
claim.eg: The company claims (that) it is not responsible for the pollution in the river.

claim.eng_def: If an organization or group claims a particular number of members, that number of people are believed to belong to it.
to ask for something of value because you think it belongs to you or because you think you have a right to it
claim.eg: The police said that if no one claims the watch, you can keep it.

claim.eng_def: to make a written demand for money from a government or organization because you think you have a right to it
claim.chi_def: （向政府或組織）索取（錢）；索（款）；索賠
claim.eg: The number of people claiming unemployment benefits has risen sharply this month.

claim.eng_def: to make an official request for money after an accident, from the person who caused your injuries
a statement that something is true or is a fact, although other people might not believe it
claim.eg: He said the police assaulted him while he was in custody, a claim that the police deny.

claim.eng_def: a written request asking an organization to pay you an amount of money that you believe they owe you
claim.eg: After her house was burgled, she made a claim on her insurance.

claim.eng_def: a right to have something or get something from someone
claim.eg: She has no rightful claim to the title.

clam.eng_def: a type of sea creature with a shell in two parts that can close together tightly, and a soft body that can be eaten

clamp.eng_def: a device made of wood or metal that is used to hold two things together tightly
clamp.eg: Carefully tighten the clamp until it firmly supports the pipette in a vertical position.

clamp.eng_def: to fasten two things together, using a clamp
clamp.eg: Clamp the two pieces of wood (together) for 15 minutes.

clamp.eng_def: If the police or another person in authority clamps a vehicle, they fix a metal device to one of its wheels, usually because it is parked illegally. The device is usually only removed when the owner pays an amount of money.
clamp.chi_def: 用夾鎖鎖住（違例停泊車輛的車輪）
clamp.eg: When I finally got back, I found my car had been clamped.

clamp.eng_def: If you clamp something in a particular place, you hold it there tightly.
clamp.eg: He clamped his hand over her mouth.

clan.eng_def: a group of families, especially in Scotland, who originally came from the same family and have the same name
clan.chi_def: （尤指蘇格蘭的）宗族，氏族，家族

clan.eng_def: a large family, or a group of people who share the same interest
clan.chi_def: 家族，氏族；（享有共同利益的）群體，集團
clan.eg: Is/Are the whole clan coming to visit you for Christmas?

clap.eng_def: to make a short loud noise by hitting your hands together
clap.eg: "When I clap my hands, you stand still," said the teacher.

clap.eng_def: to clap your hands repeatedly to show that you like or admire someone or have enjoyed a performance
clap.eg: The audience clapped and cheered when she stood up to speak.

clap.eng_def: to put a person or thing somewhere quickly or suddenly
clap.eg: She clapped her hand over her mouth to try to stop herself from laughing.

clap.eng_def: to hit someone lightly on the shoulder or back in a friendly way, especially to express pleasure at what they have done
clap.chi_def: （尤指為表示滿意而在肩上或背上輕輕友好地）拍
clap.eg: He clapped his daughter on the back and told her how proud of her he was.

clap.eng_def: the act of clapping your hands continuously to show that you like or admire someone or something
clap.eg: Let's give a big clap to/for our winning contestant!

clap.eng_def: a sudden loud noise made by thunder
clap.eg: There was a clap of thunder and then it started to pour with rain.

clap.eng_def: the act of hitting someone lightly on the shoulder or back in a friendly way, especially to express pleasure at what they have done
clap.chi_def: （尤指為表示滿意而在肩上或背上輕輕友好地）拍
clap.eg: He gave me a friendly clap on the shoulder and said, "Well done!"
a nasty dose of the clap

clarify.eng_def: to make something clear or easier to understand by giving more details or a simpler explanation
clarify.chi_def: 澄清；闡明；使更清晰易懂
clarify.eg: Could you clarify the first point please? I don't understand it completely.

clarify.eng_def: to remove water and unwanted substances from fat, such as butter, by heating it
clarify.chi_def: （透過加熱奶油等脂肪）使澄清，使純淨，使淨化

clarity.eng_def: the quality of being clear and easy to understand
clarity.eg: There has been a call for greater clarity in this area of the law.

clarity.eng_def: the quality of being easy to see or hear
clarity.eg: She was phoning from Australia, but I was amazed at the clarity of her voice.

clarity.eng_def: the ability to think clearly and not be confused
clarity.eg: He has shown great clarity of mind.

clash.chi_def: 打鬥，打架；發生衝突；爭論，爭辯
clash.eg: Students clashed with police after demonstrations at five universities.

clash.eng_def: If two opinions, statements, or qualities clash, they are very different from each other.
clash.chi_def: （兩種意見、聲明或品質）有分歧，不相容，相牴觸
clash.eg: This latest statement from the White House clashes with important aspects of US foreign policy.

clash.eng_def: If two people or teams clash in a sports competition or race, they compete seriously against each other.
If colours or styles clash, they look ugly or wrong together.
clash.chi_def: （顏色或風格）不協調，不搭配，不調和
clash.eg: I like red and orange together, though lots of people think they clash.

clash.eng_def: If two events clash, they happen at the same time in a way that is not convenient.
clash.eg: Her party clashes with my brother's wedding, so I won't be able to go.

clash.eng_def: to make a loud noise like metal hitting metal, or to cause something to make this noise
clash.chi_def: （使金屬）砰地相碰撞；（使）碰撞作響
clash.eg: The saucepans clashed as he piled them into the sink.

clash.eng_def: a fight or argument between people
clash.eg: Rioters hurled rocks and bottles in clashes with police at the weekend.

clash.eng_def: a situation in which people's opinions or qualities are very different from and opposed to each other
clash.chi_def: （觀點或品質等的）分歧，牴觸，衝突，巨大差異

clash.eng_def: a sports competition or race between two people or teams
the fact of colours or styles looking ugly or wrong together
clash.chi_def: （顏色或風格）不協調，不搭配，不調和

clash.eng_def: the situation when two events happen at the same time in a way that is not convenient
clash.eg: In the new timetable, there's a clash between history and physics.

clash.eng_def: a loud noise that sounds like metal hitting metal

clasp.eng_def: to hold someone or something firmly in your hands or arms
clasp.eg: He was clasping the vase tightly, terrified of dropping it.

clasp.eng_def: a tight hold with your hand or arms
clasp.eg: She held the child's hand in a firm clasp as they crossed the road.

clasp.eng_def: a small metal device that is used to fasten a belt, bag, or a piece of jewellery
clasp.chi_def: （皮帶、手提包或首飾的）鉤子，扣子，扣環

class.eng_def: a group of students who are taught together at school, college, or university
class.eg: Which class are you in this year?

class.eng_def: a period of time in which students are taught something
class.eg: My last class ends at four o'clock.

class.eng_def: a group of students who successfully finished their studies in a particular year
a group of people within society who have the same economic and social position
class.eg: The Labour Party has lost a lot of support among the working class.

class.eng_def: a group into which goods, services, or people are put according to their standard
class.chi_def: （貨物、服務或人的）等級，類別，級別
class.eg: Whenever I travel by train, I always travel first class.

class.eng_def: in the UK, the standard that someone has reached in their university degree
class.eg: What class of degree did you get?

class.eng_def: in UK law, a group of illegal drugs classified according to how dangerous they are thought to be and how severe the punishment is for using or selling them, with class A the most dangerous
class.chi_def: A／B／C類毒品（英國對毒品的分類，根據毒品的危險程度，以及被發現使用或銷售後的受罰程度而定，A類毒品最危險）
class.eg: He was charged with possession of a class A drug, namely heroin.

class.eng_def: to be the best at a particular activity
class.eg: As a long-distance runner, she's in a class of her own.

class.eng_def: to be something of such a high quality that nothing can be compared to it
to be much better at doing something than you
class.eg: I can't play chess with him. He's completely out of my class!

class.eng_def: the quality of being stylish or fashionable
a group of related plants or animals, in the general classification of plants and animals
to consider someone or something to belong to a particular group because of their qualities
class.eg: I'm 17, but I'm still classed as a child when I travel by bus.

classic.eng_def: having a high quality or standard against which other things are judged
extremely or unusually funny, bad, or annoying
classic.chi_def: 特別滑稽的；極壞的；極其令人討厭的
classic.eg: Then she fell over backwards into the flowerbed - it was absolutely classic!

classic.eng_def: having all the characteristics or qualities that you expect
classic.eg: He's a classic example of a kid who's clever but lazy.

classic.eng_def: bad or unpleasant, but not very surprising or unexpected
classic.chi_def: 糟糕的，討厭的，倒楣的（但並不令人驚訝）
classic.eg: It's classic - you arrive at the station on time and find that the train's left early.

classic.eng_def: having a simple, traditional style that is always fashionable
classic.eg: She wore a classic navy suit.

classic.eng_def: a piece of writing, a musical recording, or a film that is well known and of a high standard and lasting value
classic.chi_def: （書、音樂或電影的）經典作品，傑作
classic.eg: Jane Austen's "Pride and Prejudice" is a classic of English literature.

classic.eng_def: the most famous works of literature
classic.eg: I spent my childhood reading the classics.

classic.eng_def: the study of ancient Greek and Roman culture, especially their languages and literature
classic.chi_def: 古希臘和古羅馬文化研究（尤指語言與文學方面）

classic.eng_def: a piece of clothing that is always fashionable
classic.chi_def: 經典服裝；永不過時的傳統服裝
classic.eg: A long wool coat is a classic no one should be without.

classical.eng_def: Classical music is considered to be part of a long, formal tradition and to be of lasting value.
classical.eg: Do you prefer classical music like Mozart and Mahler, or pop?

classical.eng_def: used to refer to a style of music written in Europe between about 1750 and 1830
classical.chi_def: 歐洲古典音樂的（1750年到1830年間在歐洲創作的）
classical.eg: The works of Haydn and Mozart belong to the classical period.

classical.eng_def: traditional in style or form, or based on methods developed over a long period of time
classical.eg: Does she study classical ballet or modern ballet?

classical.eng_def: used to describe something that is attractive because it has a simple, traditional style
classical.eg: I love the classical lines of his dress designs.

classical.eng_def: belonging to or relating to the culture of ancient Rome and Greece
classical.chi_def: 和古希臘和古羅馬文化相關的

classification.eng_def: the act or process of dividing things into groups according to their type
classification.eg: Do you understand the system of classification used in ornithology?

classification.eng_def: a group that something is divided into

classify.eng_def: to divide things into groups according to their type
classify.eg: The books in the library are classified by/according to subject.

clause.eng_def: a particular part of a written legal document, for example a law passed by Parliament or a contract (= an agreement)
clause.eg: They have added/deleted/amended a clause in the contract which says the company can make people redundant for economic reasons.

clause.eng_def: a group of words, consisting of a subject and a finite form of a verb
clause.eg: In the sentence "I can't cook very well but I make quite good pancakes", both "I can't cook very well" and "I make good pancakes" are main/independent clauses (= they are of equal importance and could each exist as a separate sentence).

claw.eng_def: one of the sharp curved nails at the end of each of the toes of some animals and birds
claw.eg: Our cat likes to sharpen her claws on the legs of the dining table.

claw.eng_def: one of the two pointed parts, used for holding things, at the end of the legs of some insects and sea creatures
claw.eg: Keep your fingers away from the crab's claws when you pick it up.

claw.eng_def: to use claws to tear something or someone
claw.eg: He was seriously injured when one of the lions clawed his back.

clay.eng_def: thick, heavy soil that is soft when wet, and hard when dry or baked, used for making bricks and containers

clean.eng_def: honest or fair, or showing that you have not done anything illegal
clean.chi_def: 誠實的；公正的；光明正大的；清白的

clean.eng_def: not doing anything illegal, or not having or carrying illegal drugs or stolen goods
clean.chi_def: 清白的；沒有私藏（或攜帶）毒品的；沒有贓物的
clean.eg: The police busted Pete last night, but he was clean.

clean.chi_def: 不猥褻的，不下流的；無色情的
clean.eg: Can't you think of any clean jokes?

clean.eng_def: having no rough edges, and smooth, straight, or equally balanced
clean.chi_def: 邊緣整齊的；平滑的；流線型的；簡潔流暢的
clean.eg: I've broken my leg, but the doctor says that it's a clean break, so it should heal easily.
It's better for both of us if we make a clean break (of it) (= end our relationship completely).

clean.eng_def: When something you write on is clean, there is nothing on it or it is not yet used.
clean.chi_def: 未寫過的；未用過的；空白的
clean.eg: Take a clean sheet of paper.

clean.chi_def: 把…弄乾淨；打掃；清潔；清洗
clean.eg: I'm going to clean the windows this morning.
This carpet doesn't clean very well.

clean.eng_def: to prepare a fish or an animal killed for food by removing the inside parts of it that are not eaten
clean.chi_def: 清除（魚或動物）的內臟（以備烹飪）

clean.eg: These windows need a really thorough clean.
I clean forgot that I was supposed to be meeting Lucy last night.

cleaner.eng_def: a person whose job is to clean houses, offices, public places, etc.
cleaner.eg: Chris has an evening job as an office cleaner.

cleaner.eng_def: a substance used for cleaning things
cleaner.eg: We've run out of floor cleaner.

cleaner.eng_def: a shop where clothes that cannot be washed in an ordinary washing machine are cleaned
cleaner.eg: Could you pick up my suit from the cleaner's for me, please?

cleanse.eg: Cleanse the cut/wound thoroughly before you bandage it.

cleanse.eng_def: to make someone or something morally clean or pure
cleanse.eg: to cleanse the thoughts of our hearts

clear.eng_def: easy to understand, hear, read, or see
clear.chi_def: 明白的；清楚的；易懂的；清晰的
clear.eg: clear instructions/directions

clear.eng_def: something you say in order to emphasize what you have just said, or to express your authority
clear.chi_def: （強調剛說的話或表達自己的權威）我講清楚了嗎？聽明白我的意思了嗎？
clear.eg: I will not tolerate this behaviour any longer. Do I make myself clear?

clear.eng_def: certain, having no doubt, or obvious
clear.chi_def: 確定的；無可置疑的；明白無誤的；明顯的
clear.eg: He isn't at all clear about what he wants to do with his life.

clear.eng_def: pure or easy to see through, with no marks or areas that are less transparent
clear.chi_def: 晴朗的；純淨的；透明的；清澈的
clear.eg: clear glass

clear.eng_def: used to describe a pleasant, pure sound
clear.eg: the clear sound of the flute

clear.eng_def: used to describe something that you remember easily
clear.eg: I have clear memories of visiting my grandfather's farm as a child.

clear.eng_def: not covered or blocked by anything
clear.chi_def: 無遮蓋的；無阻礙的；暢通的
clear.eg: We have a clear view of the ocean from our hotel window.

clear.eng_def: not busy or filled by any planned activity
clear.chi_def: 不忙的，空閒的；沒有安排的
clear.eg: The only time I have clear next week is Tuesday afternoon.

clear.eng_def: without being or feeling guilty
clear.eg: to have a clear conscience

clear.eng_def: free from confusion; able to think quickly and well
clear.chi_def: 頭腦清醒的；思維清晰的；思維敏捷的
clear.eg: Marie is good at making decisions because she's a very clear thinker.

clear.eng_def: without problems or difficulties
clear.eg: This is the first time in his life that he's been clear of (= without) debt.

clear.eng_def: used to describe an amount of money that is left after all necessary payments have been made
clear.eg: The school summer fair made a clear profit of £1,500.

clear.eng_def: not touching something, or away from something
clear.eg: Only one competitor made a clear jump of the highest fence (= jumped over it without touching it).

clear.eng_def: to remove or get rid of whatever is blocking or filling something, or to stop being blocked or full
clear.chi_def: 移走；清除；清理；清掃；疏通
clear.eg: It took several hours to clear the road after the accident.

clear.eng_def: to give a small cough
clear.eg: She cleared her throat nervously before she began to speak.

clear.eng_def: to prove that someone is not guilty of something that they were accused of
clear.eg: After many years in prison, the men were finally cleared of the bombings.

clear.eng_def: to give official permission for something
clear.eg: Despite local opposition, the plans for the new supermarket have been cleared by the council.

clear.eng_def: to satisfy the official conditions of something
clear.eg: Before you can enter the country, you have to clear customs.

clear.eng_def: to become or make something pure or easy to see through
clear.eg: The children enjoyed stirring the mud at the bottom of the pond, then watching the water slowly clear again.

clear.eng_def: to make your mind free from confusion so that you can think quickly and well
clear.chi_def: 使頭腦清醒；使思維清晰
clear.eg: I need to get some fresh air to clear my head (= to make me able to think well).

clear.eng_def: to pay back all the money that you owe
to have an amount of money left from your earnings after any necessary payments, charges, taxes, etc.
clear.chi_def: （支付各種費用後）淨剩下，純收入為
clear.eg: Bill clears $200 a week.

clear.eng_def: to (cause a cheque to) go from one bank to another through a central organization, so that money can be paid to the person it is owed to
clear.eg: It usually takes four to five working days for a cheque to clear.

clear.eng_def: to jump or go over something without touching it
clear.eg: The horse cleared the fence with inches to spare.

clear.eng_def: not touching, or away from
clear.eg: Stand clear of the doors, please.

clear.eng_def: to avoid something or someone
clear.eg: His parents warned him to steer clear of trouble.

clearance.eng_def: the process of removing waste or things you do not want from a place
clearance.chi_def: （對廢物或不要的東西的）清除，清理，清掃，排除

clearance.eng_def: an occasion when goods are offered for sale cheaply so that people will be encouraged to buy them and there will be space for new goods
clearance.eg: We bought our new carpet at a clearance sale.

clearance.eng_def: the distance or space that is needed for one thing to avoid touching another thing
clearance.eg: It was difficult getting the piano through the doorway because we only had a clearance of a few centimetres.

clearance.eng_def: official permission for something or the state of having satisfied the official conditions of something
clearance.eg: The plane will be taking off as soon as it gets clearance.

clearance.eng_def: the process of a cheque going from one bank to another through a central organization, so that money can be paid to the person it is owed to
clearance.eg: Clearance (of a cheque) can take up to a week.

clearance.eng_def: in football, an occasion when a player kicks the ball away from their goal
clearance.chi_def: （足球比賽中）將足球從本方球門前踢出，解圍
clearance.eg: Robinson's long clearance was controlled by Mido who went on to score.

clench.eng_def: to close or hold something very tightly, often in a determined or angry way
clench.chi_def: （常指堅決或生氣地）捏緊，握緊，咬緊
clench.eg: The old man clenched his fist and waved it angrily at us.

clerk.eng_def: a person who works in an office, dealing with records or performing general office duties
a person who serves customers in a shop
clerk.eg: Take your purchases to the clerk, and he will wrap them for you.

clerk.eng_def: a hotel employee who deals with guests when they arrive
clerk.eg: The clerk checked us in and gave us our key.

clerk.eng_def: a person who works with a judge and helps the judge make decisions

clerk.eg: Debbie has a summer job clerking in an office.

clever.eng_def: having or showing the ability to learn and understand things quickly and easily
clever.eg: Judy has never been very clever, but she tries hard.
My mother is very clever with her hands.
I've got a clever little gadget for opening jars.

clever.eng_def: showing intelligence, but not sincere, polite, or serious
clever.eg: That's enough clever talk, young lady.

click.eng_def: to carry out a computer operation by pressing a button on the mouse or keyboard
click.eg: If you want to open a file, click twice on the icon for it.

click.eng_def: to make a short, sharp sound, or to make something do this
click.chi_def: （使）發出短而尖的聲音；（使）發出哢嗒聲
click.eg: The door clicked shut behind her.
Liz and I really clicked the first time we met.

click.eng_def: to be understood, or become clear suddenly
click.eg: Suddenly everything clicked and I realized where I'd met him.
The soldier gave a click of his heels as he saluted.

click.eng_def: the act of pressing a button on the mouse (= small control device) of a computer to operate it
If something is (just) a click away, it is very easy to get on your computer, especially from the Internet.
click.chi_def: 一鍵之遙（指很容易從電腦、特別是網際網路上獲得）
click.eg: All reference materials are just a click away in the computer databases.

client.eng_def: a customer or someone who receives services
client.eg: Mr Black has been a client of this firm for many years.

client.eng_def: a computer that is connected to a server (= large central computer) from which it gets information

cliff.eng_def: a high area of rock with a very steep side, often on a coast
cliff.eg: Keep away from the edge of the cliff - you might fall.

climate.eng_def: the general weather conditions usually found in a particular place
the general development of a situation, or the situation, feelings, and opinions that exist at a particular time
climate.chi_def: 形勢，趨勢；（某一時期的）風尚，風氣，思潮

climax.eng_def: the most important or exciting point in a story or situation, especially when this happens near the end
climax.chi_def: 高潮；最精彩的部分；頂點
climax.eg: The climax of the air show was a daring flying display.

climax.eng_def: the highest point of sexual pleasure
to reach the most important or exciting part
climax.eg: The show climaxed with all the performers singing on stage together.

climax.eng_def: to reach the highest point of sexual pleasure

climb.eng_def: to go up, or to go towards the top of something
climb.eg: The plane climbed quickly to a height of 30,000 feet.

climb.eng_def: to use your legs, or your legs and hands, to go up or onto the top of something
If a price, number, or amount climbs, it increases.
climb.eg: Our costs have climbed rapidly in the last few years.

climb.eng_def: to move into a higher social position, or to improve your position at work
climb.chi_def: 提高社會地位，向上爬；晉升
climb.eg: He quickly climbed to the top of his profession.

climb.eng_def: to move into or out of a small space awkwardly or with difficulty or effort
climb.eg: They climbed into the truck and drove away.
There's masses of ivy climbing up/over the walls of our house.

climb.eng_def: an act or process of climbing
climb.eg: We were very tired after our climb.

climb.eng_def: a place or object to be climbed
climb.eg: The north face of the Eiger is a very difficult climb.

cling.eng_def: to stick onto or hold something or someone tightly, or to refuse to stop holding it, him, or her
cling.eg: We got so wet that our clothes clung to us.
The road clings to (= closely follows) the coastline for several miles, then it turns inland.

cling.eng_def: to stay close to someone who is taking care of you, because you need their support
cling.eg: Jenny is the kind of child who always clings whenever she's taken to a new place.

clinic.eng_def: a building, often part of a hospital, to which people can go for medical care or advice relating to a particular condition
clinic.eg: Bring your baby to the clinic and we'll take a look at her.

clinical.eng_def: used to refer to medical work or teaching that relates to the examination and treatment of ill people

clinical.chi_def: 冷漠的；無動於衷的；無感情的
clinical.eg: She seems to have a very clinical attitude towards her children.

clinical.chi_def: 無特色的；冷冰冰的；簡樸的
clinical.eg: We were going to paint our kitchen white, but we decided that would look too clinical.

clip.eng_def: a small object usually made of metal or plastic, used for fastening things together or holding them in position
a short part of a film or television programme
clip.chi_def: （電影或電視節目的）剪輯，片段
clip.eg: I've seen a clip from the movie.
We set off at a good clip, but we gradually slowed down.

clip.eng_def: a container that is fastened to a gun, from which bullets go into the gun to be fired
the act of cutting something in order to make it tidy
a quick hit on the side of someone's head
clip.eg: You do that once more and you'll get a clip round the ear, my lad.

clip.eng_def: to cut something with scissors or a similar sharp tool, especially to make it tidier
clip.eg: I'm going to clip the hedge this weekend.

clip.eng_def: to reduce something by the stated amount
clip.eg: Christie has clipped a tenth of a second off the record.

clip.eng_def: to hit something or someone with a short sharp movement
clip.eg: He clipped the edge of the kerb with his front tyre.

clip.eng_def: to fasten something with a clip
clip.eg: You can always tell a real bow tie from one that clips on.

clock.eng_def: a device for measuring and showing time, usually found in or on a building and not worn by a person
clock.eg: We have an antique clock on our mantelpiece.

clock.eng_def: to change the time on your clocks to an hour earlier, at an officially chosen time of year
clock.chi_def: （按照官方時間）把時鐘撥慢一小時
clock.eg: Don't forget to turn the clocks back tonight.

clock.eng_def: to change the time on your clocks to an hour later, at an officially chosen time of year
clock.chi_def: （按照官方時間）把時鐘撥快一小時

clock.eng_def: a speedometer (= a device that measures speed)
clock.eg: I was only doing 30 mph on the clock.

clock.eng_def: a milometer (= a device for recording distance travelled)
clock.eg: My car's only got 10,000 miles on the clock.

clock.eng_def: to take a particular time exactly to do or complete something
clock.eg: He clocked ten seconds in the 100 metres (= he ran it in ten seconds).

clock.eng_def: to show or reach a particular speed or distance on a measuring device
clock.chi_def: 顯示，達到（某一速度或里程）
clock.eg: The police clocked him doing 80 mph in a 50 mph area.

clock.eng_def: to hit someone, especially on the head or face
clock.chi_def: 打，揍，擊（尤指頭部或臉部）
clock.eg: Then the other guy turned round and clocked him one (= hit him).

clockwise.eng_def: in the direction in which the hands (= thin parts that point) of a clock move
clockwise.eg: Turn the knob clockwise/in a clockwise direction.

clone.eng_def: a plant or animal that has the same genes as the original from which it was produced
clone.chi_def: （動植物的）無性繁殖，克隆，複製

clone.eng_def: someone or something that looks very much like someone or something else
clone.chi_def: 複製品；酷似的人（或物）；…的翻版
clone.eg: Most people saw her as just another blond-haired, red-lipped Marilyn Monroe clone.

clone.eng_def: a computer that operates in a very similar way to the one that it was copied from
clone.chi_def: （電腦的）克隆機，仿製機，相容機

clone.eng_def: to create a clone of a plant or animal
clone.eg: Scientists have already cloned a sheep.

close.eng_def: to (cause something to) change from being open to not being open
close.eg: Could you close the door/window please?

close.eng_def: When a shop, restaurant, or public place closes, people cannot go into it.
close.chi_def: （商店或餐館）關門，不營業，打烊；（公共場所）不開放
close.eg: The banks had closed (to customers) so I couldn't get any money out.
The play closed with the tragic death of both hero and heroine.

close.eng_def: to (cause a business, organization, or business arrangement to) stop operating
close.chi_def: （使）（生意或組織）倒閉；關閉（使）（業務）停止
close.eg: I closed that bank account when I came to London.

close.eng_def: to make a successful business arrangement with someone
close.eg: We closed a deal with a major supermarket.

close.eng_def: the end of something, or the time when you end it
close.eg: I tried to bring the conversation to a close.

close.eng_def: a road, usually with private houses, that vehicles can only enter from one end
close.chi_def: （通常通向私人住宅的）街道，死巷，死胡同

close.eng_def: having direct family connections or shared beliefs, support, and sympathy
close.eg: There weren't many people at the funeral - just close family/relatives.

close.eng_def: People who are close know each other very well and like each other a lot, or who see and talk to each other a lot.
close.chi_def: 親密的；親近的；聯繫緊密的
close.eg: Mira is one of my closest friends.

close.eng_def: looking at or listening to someone or something very carefully
close.eg: Police are paying close attention to the situation.

close.eng_def: unwilling to talk about things to other people
close.eg: He's so close about his past - it seems like he's hiding something.

close.eng_def: used to describe weather or air conditions in which it is difficult to breathe and it is uncomfortably warm
close.chi_def: 封閉的；密不透風的；悶熱的
close.eg: Can I open the window? It's very close in here.

close.eng_def: not far in position or time
close.chi_def: （空間或時間上）接近的（地），靠近的（地）
close.eg: Don't get too close to that dog, Rosie.
Shall we call in on Miranda? You know she lives quite close by.

close.chi_def: 接近的，只有細微差別的
close.eg: The election results were so close they had to vote again.
I think there are close on three million unemployed at present.

closet.eng_def: a cupboard or a small room with a door, used for storing things, especially clothes
closet.chi_def: （尤指放衣服的）壁櫥，壁櫃，儲藏室

closet.eng_def: to put yourself in a place, especially a closed space, and stay there
closet.eg: Two weeks before my exams I closeted myself (away) in my room with my books and I didn't speak to anyone.

closet.eng_def: used to refer to a belief, activity, or feeling that is kept secret from the public, usually because you are frightened of the results of it becoming known
closet.chi_def: 私下的，秘密的，不公開的

closure.eng_def: the fact of a business, organization, etc. stopping operating
the feeling or act of bringing an unpleasant situation, time, or experience to an end, so that you are able to start new activities

cloth.eng_def: a small piece of material, used in cleaning to remove dirt, dust, or liquid

clothe.eg: It costs a lot to feed and clothe five children.

clothes.eng_def: things such as dresses and trousers that you wear to cover, protect, or decorate your body

clothing.eng_def: clothes, especially clothes of a particular type or those worn in a particular situation
clothing.chi_def: 衣服；（尤指某種用途的）服裝
clothing.eg: You can only take three articles/items of clothing into the changing room.

cloud.eng_def: a grey or white mass in the sky, made up of very small floating drops of water
cloud.eg: Do you think those are rain clouds on the horizon?

cloud.eng_def: a mass of something such as dust or smoke that looks like a cloud
cloud.chi_def: 一團（塵土、煙霧等）；雲狀物
cloud.eg: On the eastern horizon, a huge cloud of smoke from burning oil tanks stretched across the sky.

cloud.eng_def: a computer network where files and programs can be stored, especially the internet
cloud.eg: All the photographs are kept on the cloud rather than on hard drives.

cloud.eng_def: If something transparent clouds, or if something clouds it, it becomes difficult to see through.
to make someone confused, or make something more difficult to understand
cloud.chi_def: 使迷惑；使不清楚；使難以理解
cloud.eg: When it came to explaining the lipstick on his collar, he found that drink had clouded (= confused) his memory.

cloudy.eg: The beer was cloudy and dark.

clover.eng_def: a small plant with three round leaves on each stem, often fed to cows
clover.chi_def: （常作牛飼料的）苜蓿，三葉草，車軸草

clown.eng_def: an entertainer who wears funny clothes, has a painted face, and makes people laugh by performing tricks and behaving in a silly way
someone who behaves in a silly way, often intentionally
clown.chi_def: （常指故意）出洋相的人；愚蠢可笑的人

clown.eng_def: to act stupidly, often to make other people laugh
clown.eg: Left alone, the class threw books, pulled faces, and generally clowned around.

club.eng_def: an organization of people with a common purpose or interest, who meet regularly and take part in shared activities
club.eg: I've just joined the local golf/squash/tennis club.
The Orioles are an exciting club this year.

club.eng_def: a building in which a club meets
a place that people go to in order to dance and drink in the evening
club.eg: I went to that new club that's just opened.

club.eng_def: a long, thin stick used in golf to hit the ball
a heavy stick used as a weapon
one of the four suits in playing cards, represented by a symbol with three round leaves
a playing card from the suit of clubs
club.eg: Now you have to play a club if you have one.

club.eng_def: to beat a person or an animal, usually repeatedly, with a heavy stick or object
club.eg: He was clubbed over the head.

clue.eng_def: a sign or some information that helps you to find the answer to a problem, question, or mystery
clue.eg: Police are still looking for clues in their search for the missing girl.

clumsy.eg: The first mobile phones were heavy and clumsy to use, but nowadays they are much easier to handle.

clumsy.eng_def: A clumsy person often has accidents because they do not behave in a careful, controlled way.
clumsy.eg: That's the third glass you've smashed this week - you're so clumsy!

cluster.eng_def: a group of similar things that are close together, sometimes surrounding something
cluster.eg: Have a look at the cluster of galaxies in this photograph.

cluster.eng_def: a group of two or more consonant sounds that are together and have no vowel sound between them
cluster.chi_def: 子音叢（連在一起的兩個或以上的子音）
cluster.eg: The /str/ at the beginning of "stray" is a cluster.

clutch.eng_def: to take or try to take hold of something tightly, usually in fear, worry, or pain
clutch.chi_def: （通常指因恐懼、焦慮或痛苦而）緊抓，緊握
clutch.eg: Silent and pale, she clutched (onto) her mother's hand.

clutch.eng_def: a device that allows turning movement to be sent from one part of a machine to another
clutch.eg: I've booked the car into the garage because the clutch is slipping.

clutch.eng_def: the pedal or handle in a vehicle that is used to operate the engine's clutch
clutch.chi_def: 離合器踏板；離合器手柄
clutch.eg: Push the clutch in, put the car into gear, rev the engine, and then gently let the clutch out.

clutch.eng_def: a small group of eggs produced by the same bird, especially in a nest
a small group of people or things

clutch.eg: He is in/has fallen into the clutches of that woman.

clutch.eng_def: able to do something when it is especially needed
clutch.chi_def: 在危機時刻可以信賴的，在緊急關頭做出的
clutch.eg: Moose, always reliable under pressure, was an amazing clutch hitter.

coach.eng_def: someone whose job is to teach people to improve at a sport, skill, or school subject
coach.chi_def: 教練；輔導老師；私人教師；家庭教師

coach.eng_def: someone whose job is to train and organize a sports team
coach.eg: Gus Poyet was appointed as head coach.

coach.eng_def: a long motor vehicle with comfortable seats, used to take groups of people on journeys
coach.eg: We're going to the airport by coach.

coach.eng_def: an old-fashioned carriage pulled by horses, now used mainly in official or royal ceremonies
coach.chi_def: （老式）四輪大馬車（現主要用於官方或皇家典禮中）

coach.eng_def: any of the separate parts of a train in which the passengeras sit

coach.chi_def: 乘坐（飛機）經濟艙；乘坐（火車）普通車廂（同 coach class）

coach.eng_def: to give special classes in sports or a school subject, especially privately, to one person or a small group
coach.chi_def: 訓練；培訓；指導；（尤指私人）輔導
coach.eg: She coaches students in French, usually for exams.

coach.eng_def: to train and organize a sports team
coach.eg: He coached the Blue Devils during their last championship season.

coach.eng_def: the cheapest type of seats on a plane or train
coach.eg: Even the company's director flies coach most of the time.

coal.eng_def: a hard, black substance that is dug from the earth in pieces, and can be burned to produce heat or power, or a single piece of this
coal.eg: How much coal was mined here?

coarse.eng_def: rough and not smooth or soft, or not in very small pieces
coarse.chi_def: 粗糙的；不光滑的；不柔軟的；粗大的

coast.eng_def: the land next to or close to the sea
coast.eg: Rimini is a thriving resort on the east coast of Italy.

coast.eng_def: from one side of the country to the other
coast.eg: We travelled across America coast to coast.

coast.eng_def: in every part of a country
coast.eg: The visiting politician received coast-to-coast media attention.

coast.eng_def: to move forward in a vehicle without using the engine, usually down a hill
coast.chi_def: （通常指下山時憑藉慣性）滑行，下滑
coast.eg: At the top of the hill I switched off the engine and we just coasted down the other side.

coast.eng_def: to progress or succeed without any effort or difficulty
coast.chi_def: 毫不費力取得進展；輕而易舉取得勝利
coast.eg: While I struggled, my sister coasted through school with top grades.

coastline.eng_def: the particular shape of the coast, especially as seen from above, from the sea, or on a map
coastline.chi_def: （尤指從空中、海上或地圖上看到的）海岸線

coat.eng_def: an outer piece of clothing with sleeves that is worn over other clothes, usually for warmth
coat.chi_def: （通常指保暖的）外套，外衣，大衣
coat.eg: Do your coat up, Joe, or you'll freeze.

coat.eng_def: the hair, wool, or fur covering an animal
a layer of a substance, especially paint, that covers something
coat.chi_def: 塗上的一層；覆蓋上的一層，外加的一層
coat.eg: I'll give the walls a quick coat of paint.

coat.eng_def: to cover something with a layer of a particular substance
coat.chi_def: 給…塗上一層；使覆蓋上一層，外加一層
coat.eg: When the biscuits are cool, you coat them in/with melted chocolate.

cock.eng_def: used with the name of a bird to refer to the adult male of that type
a friendly form of address, used especially by a man talking to another man
cock.chi_def: （親熱的稱呼，尤用於男子之間）老兄，夥計

cock.eng_def: to move a part of your body upwards or in a particular direction
cock.eg: He cocked his head on one side with a slight frown.

cock.eng_def: to push the necessary piece of a gun up into position so that it is ready to fire
cock.chi_def: 扣上（槍的）扳機；扳起（槍的）擊鐵；拉起（槍的）槍栓
cock.eg: He cocked his rifle and took aim.

cockroach.eng_def: a flat, brown or black insect sometimes found in the home

cocktail.eng_def: a drink, usually an alcoholic one, made by mixing two or more drinks together
cocktail.eg: We were all in the bar sipping cocktails.

cocktail.eng_def: a mixture of different things, often an unexpected, dangerous, or exciting one
cocktail.chi_def: （常指非常規的、危險的或令人興奮的）混合物
cocktail.eg: The inquest heard that the guitarist died from a cocktail of drink and drugs.

cocktail.eng_def: a cold dish, often eaten at the start of a meal, consisting of small pieces of food

cocoa.eng_def: a dark brown powder made from cocoa beans, used to make chocolate and add a chocolate flavour to food and drink
a sweet chocolate drink that is made with cocoa powder
cocoa.eg: a nice hot mug of cocoa

coconut.eng_def: a large fruit like a nut with a thick, hard, brown shell containing hard, white flesh that can be eaten and a clear liquid
the white flesh of the coconut, often used in cooking

cocoon.eng_def: the covering made of soft, smooth threads that surrounds and protects particular insects during the pupa stage as they develop into adult form

cocoon.chi_def: 安全寧靜的地方；避風港
cocoon.eg: the warm, safe cocoon of childhood

cocoon.eng_def: to protect someone or something from pain or an unpleasant situation
cocoon.eg: As a student you're cocooned against/from the real world.

code.eng_def: a system of words, letters, or signs used to represent a message in secret form, or a system of numbers, letters, or signals used to represent something in a shorter or more convenient form
code.eg: The message was written in code.

code.eng_def: a set of rules that are accepted as general principles, or a set of written rules that say how people in a particular organization or country should behave
code.eg: Clinics will be subject to a new code of conduct and stronger controls by local authorities.

code.eng_def: a set of principles that are accepted and used by society or a particular group of people
an arrangement of genetic material in DNA (= the chemical that carries genetic information in cells)
to represent a message in code so that it can only be understood by the person who is meant to receive it

coffee.eng_def: a dark brown powder with a strong flavour and smell that is made by crushing coffee beans, or a hot drink made from this powder

coffin.eng_def: a long box in which the body of a dead person is buried or burned

coherent.eng_def: If an argument, set of ideas, or a plan is coherent, it is clear and carefully considered, and each part of it connects or follows in a natural or reasonable way.
coherent.chi_def: （論據、觀點、計劃）有條理的，連貫的，前後一致的

coherent.eng_def: If someone is coherent, you can understand what that person says.
coherent.chi_def: （講話）條理清晰的，清楚明白的
coherent.eg: When she calmed down, she was more coherent (= able to speak clearly and be understood).

coil.eng_def: a length of rope, hair, or wire, arranged into a series of circles, one above the other
coil.eg: A coil of rope lay on the beach.

coil.eng_def: a twisted length of wire through which an electric current travels
an IUD (= a medical device to stop a woman becoming pregnant)
to arrange something in a coil
coil.eg: She coiled her hair into a neat bun on top of her head.

coin.eng_def: a small, round piece of metal, usually silver or copper coloured, that is used as money
money in the form of metal coins
to invent a new word or expression, or to use one in a particular way for the first time
coin.chi_def: 創造，杜撰（新詞或新的表達方式）；首次使用（某一詞語）
coin.eg: Allen Ginsberg coined the term "flower power".

coin.eng_def: to be earning a lot of money quickly
coin.chi_def: 輕鬆地賺大錢，發大財，暴富

coincide.eng_def: to happen at or near the same time
coincide.eg: I timed my holiday to coincide with the children's.

coincide.eng_def: to be the same or similar
coincide.eg: Our views coincide on a range of subjects.

coincidence.eng_def: an occasion when two or more similar things happen at the same time, especially in a way that is unlikely and surprising
coincidence.chi_def: 同時發生；（尤指令人吃驚的）巧合，碰巧的事
coincidence.eg: You chose exactly the same wallpaper as us - what a coincidence!
Just by coincidence, I met my old schoolmate again 50 years later.

cola.eng_def: a sweet, brown fizzy drink (= one with bubbles) that does not contain alcohol
cola.eg: Coke and Pepsi are types of cola.

cold.eng_def: at a low temperature, especially when compared to the temperature of the human body, and not hot, or warm
cold.chi_def: （尤指相對於體溫而言）冷的，寒冷的，溫度低的

cold.eng_def: not showing kindness, love, or emotion and not friendly
cold.eg: His handshake was cold, and his eyes lifeless.

cold.eng_def: a common infection, especially in the nose and throat, that often causes a cough, a slight fever, and sometimes some pain in the muscles

cold.eg: Don't stand out there in the cold, come in here and get warm.

collapse.eng_def: to fall down suddenly because of pressure or having no strength or support
collapse.chi_def: （由於壓力、無力或缺乏支持而）倒塌，坍塌；崩潰，垮掉
collapse.eg: Thousands of buildings collapsed in the earthquake.

collapse.eng_def: If someone collapses, they fall down because of being sick or weak.
collapse.eg: He collapsed and died of a heart attack.

collapse.eng_def: to fold something into a smaller shape, usually so it can be stored, or (especially of furniture) to fold in this way
collapse.eg: All chairs collapse for easy storage.

collapse.eng_def: (of people and business) to suddenly be unable to continue or work correctly
collapse.eg: Lots of people lost their jobs when the property market collapsed.

collapse.eng_def: the sudden failure of a system, organization, business, etc.
collapse.chi_def: （系統、組織、企業等的）崩潰，瓦解，失敗
collapse.eg: I don't know what caused the collapse of her marriage.

collapse.eng_def: the sudden falling movement of a person or structure that has become too weak to stand
collapse.chi_def: 昏倒，昏迷；（建築物的）倒塌，坍塌
collapse.eg: He was taken to hospital after his collapse on the pitch.

collar.eng_def: the part around the neck of a piece of clothing, usually sewn on and sometimes made of different material
a strap made of leather or other strong material that is put around the neck of an animal, especially a dog or cat
collar.chi_def: （尤指套在狗、貓等動物脖子上的）頸圈，項圈
collar.eg: I grabbed the dog by the collar and dragged it out of the room.

collar.eng_def: a type of necklace (= a piece of jewellery worn around the neck)
an area around the neck of an animal that is coloured differently from the other parts of the body
collar.chi_def: （動物頸部顏色不同的）色圈，頸鎖形條紋
collar.eg: The bird has grey feathers with a lighter collar.

collar.eng_def: a strip of strong material that is put around a pipe or a piece of machinery to make it stronger or to join two parts together
collar.chi_def: （管子或機器上的）箍，卡圈，套管

collar.eng_def: to catch and hold someone so that they cannot escape
collar.eg: She was collared by the police at the airport.

collar.eng_def: to find someone and stop them from going somewhere, often so that you can talk to that person about something
collar.eg: I was collared by Pete as I was coming out of the meeting this morning.

colleague.eng_def: one of a group of people who work together
colleague.eg: We're entertaining some colleagues of Carol's tonight.

collect.eng_def: to get and keep things of one type such as stamps or coins as a hobby
to go to a place and bring someone or something away from it
collect.eg: Your shoes will be repaired and ready for you to collect on Thursday.

collect.eng_def: to bring something together from different places or over a period of time
collect.eg: After the party I collected (up) bottles from various parts of the house.

collect.eng_def: to ask people to give you money for something, for example a charity
to take money such as taxes, rents, etc.
collect.eg: The state collected about $1.2 million in taxes in January.

collect.eng_def: to come together from different places or over a period of time
collect.eg: A large crowd of reporters collected outside the prime minister's house.

collect.eng_def: to get control of your feelings and thoughts, especially after shock, surprise, or laughter
collect.chi_def: （尤指在震驚、驚訝或大笑後）鎮定下來，定神，集中思想
collect.eg: I was so stunned by what he'd said I had to collect myself before I could reply.

collect.eng_def: a short prayer that is said during some Christian religious ceremonies
collect.chi_def: （某些基督教儀式上的）短禱文

collect.eng_def: When you call collect or make a collect phone call, the person you call pays for the call.
collect.eg: I'd like to make a collect call.

collection.eng_def: a group of objects of one type that have been collected by one person or in one place
an amount of money collected from several people, or the act of collecting money
collection.chi_def: 募集的錢；捐的款；募捐的錢
collection.eg: We're having a collection for Tom's retirement present.

collection.eng_def: a lot of things or people
collection.eg: There's quite a collection of toothbrushes in the bathroom.

collection.eng_def: a range of new clothes produced by one clothes designer
collection.chi_def: （某位服裝設計師的）一系列新裝作品

collection.eng_def: the act of taking something away from a place
collection.eg: The photos will be ready for collection on Tuesday afternoon.

collective.eng_def: of or shared by every member of a group of people
an organization or business that is owned and controlled by the people who work in it
collective.chi_def: 聯合組織；企業集團；集體企業

collector.eng_def: someone who collects objects because they are beautiful, valuable, or interesting
someone whose job is to collect tickets or money from people
the person who is in charge of the local government in a particular town or area of the country

college.eng_def: a university where you can study for an undergraduate (= first) degree
college.eg: I met my husband when we were in college.

college.eng_def: any place for specialized education after the age of 16 where people study or train to get knowledge and/or skills
college.chi_def: 學院；職業學校；技術學校；高等專科學校

college.eng_def: one of the separate and named parts into which some universities are divided
in Britain and Australia, used in the names of some schools for children, especially private schools (= where education is paid for by parents)
college.chi_def: 公學，學校（用於英國和澳大利亞某些私立學校的名稱）

college.eng_def: a group of people with a particular job, purpose, duty, or power who are organized into a group for sharing ideas, making decisions, etc.

collide.eng_def: (especially of moving objects) to hit something violently
collide.eg: The two vans collided at the crossroads.

collision.eng_def: an accident that happens when two vehicles hit each other with force
collision.eg: There has been a collision on the southbound stretch of the motorway.
There was a collision of interests/opinions.

colloquial.eng_def: (of words and expressions) informal and more suitable for use in speech than in writing
colloquial.chi_def: （詞語或表達方式）口語的，俗語的，非正式的

colonel.eng_def: an officer of high rank in the army or air force
colonel.eg: Colonel is the military rank between lieutenant-colonel and brigadier.

colonial.eng_def: relating to a colony or colonialism
colonial.eg: Turkey was once an important colonial power.

colonial.eng_def: Colonial furniture or buildings are in the style of a period when a country was a colony.
colonial.chi_def: （傢俱或建築物）具有殖民地風格的，殖民地時期風格的

colonial.eng_def: a person from another country who lives in a colony, especially as part of its system of government
colonial.chi_def: （尤指來自宗主國的）殖民地居民

colony.eng_def: a country or area controlled politically by a more powerful country that is often far away
colony.eg: Australia and New Zealand are former British colonies.

colony.eng_def: a group of people who live in a colony
a group of people with a shared interest or job who live together in a way that is separate from other people
colony.chi_def: （具有共同愛好或工作的）聚居人群，群體

colony.eng_def: a group of animals, insects, or plants of the same type that live together
colony.chi_def: （動物、昆蟲或植物的）群，群落；生物群

colony.eng_def: an area surrounded by fences or walls that contains a group of houses, for example houses that have been built by an employer for its workers
colony.chi_def: （有籬笆或圍牆環繞的）住宅區

column.eng_def: one of several vertical blocks of print into which a page of a newspaper or magazine is divided
column.eg: I didn't have time to read the whole article - just the first column.

column.eng_def: a piece of writing in a newspaper or magazine, usually on a particular subject, that is always written by the same person and appears regularly
column.eg: She writes a weekly fashion/gossip column for the Evening Standard.

column.eng_def: any vertical block of words or numbers
column.eg: Add the column of figures and divide the sum by three.

column.eng_def: a tall, vertical stone post, used as a support for a roof or in classical buildings (= in the style of ancient Greece or Rome) for decoration, or standing alone as a monument (= a symbol of respect for a special person or event)
column.eg: The roof of the temple was held up by a row of thick stone columns.

column.eng_def: something with a tall, narrow shape
column.eg: A column of smoke rose from the chimney.

column.eng_def: a line of moving people or vehicles
column.chi_def: 一隊，一列（移動的人或車輛）

columnist.eng_def: someone who writes a regular article for a newspaper or magazine

comb.eng_def: a flat piece of plastic, wood, or metal with a thin row of long, narrow parts along one side, used to tidy and arrange your hair
a small comb-shaped object that women put in their hair to hold their hair away from their face or for decoration
a soft, red, growth on a chicken's head
to tidy your hair using a comb
comb.eg: She combed her hair and put on some lipstick.

comb.eng_def: to search a place or an area very carefully in order to find something
comb.eg: The police combed the whole area for evidence.

combat.eng_def: a fight, especially during a war
combat.eg: There was fierce combat between the two sides.

combat.eng_def: a fight between two people or things
combat.eg: The film explores the combat between good and evil.

combat.eng_def: to try to stop something unpleasant or harmful from happening or increasing
combat.chi_def: 與…戰鬥；與…作鬥爭；打擊；制止

combination.eng_def: the mixture you get when two or more things are combined
combination.eg: Strawberries and cream - a perfect combination.

combination.eng_def: an arrangement in a particular order
combination.eg: From the letters X Y Z, we can get three combinations of two letters: XY, XZ, and YZ.

combination.eng_def: a set of letters or numbers in a particular order that can be used to open some types of locks
combination.chi_def: （用於開某些鎖的）數碼組合，密碼

combine.eng_def: to (cause to) exist together, or join together to make a single thing or group
combine.chi_def: （使）結合；（使）聯合；（使）合併；（使）綜合
combine.eg: None of us has much money so let's combine what we've got.

combine.eng_def: If someone combines two or more qualities, they have both of those qualities.
combine.eg: As a writer, he combined wit and/with passion.

combine.eng_def: to do two activities at the same time
combine.chi_def: 兼辦，兼做，同時做（兩種活動）
combine.eg: She manages to successfully combine family life and/with a career.

combine.eng_def: a group of people or organizations acting together in business
a large farming machine that cuts the plant, separates the seed from the stem, and cleans the grain as it moves across a field

come.eng_def: to move or travel towards the speaker or with the speaker
to move or travel in the direction of the person being spoken to
to get to a particular place

come.eg: I had to come away from the party early.

come.eng_def: to change or develop so as to be in a different position or condition
come.eg: Those pictures will have to come down (= be removed from the wall).

come.eng_def: to have or achieve a particular position in a race, competition, list, etc.
come.eg: She came second (US came in second) in the 100 metres.
Do these trousers come in any other colour?
I've come to like her over the months.

comedian.eng_def: a person whose job is to make people laugh by telling jokes and funny stories or by copying the behaviour or speech of famous people

comedy.eng_def: a (type of) film, play, or book that is intentionally funny either in its characters or its action
comedy.eg: His latest movie is described as a "romantic comedy".

comedy.eng_def: the humorous part of a situation
comedy.eg: The vicar's forgetting his lines in the middle of the speech provided some good comedy.

comedy.eng_def: a type of comedy in which the social behaviour of a particular group of people is made to appear silly

comet.eng_def: an object that moves around the sun, usually at a great distance from it, that is seen on rare occasions from the earth as a bright line in the sky

comfort.eng_def: a pleasant feeling of being relaxed and free from pain
the state of feeling better after feeling sad or worried, or something that makes you feel better in this way
comfort.chi_def: 安慰，慰藉，寬慰；使人感到寬慰的事物
comfort.eg: The letters that people wrote after his death gave me a lot of comfort.

comfort.eng_def: the state of having a pleasant life with enough money for everything that you need
comfort.eg: He could retire now and live in comfort for the rest of his life.

comfort.eng_def: something that makes your life easy and pleasant
comfort.chi_def: 令人舒適愉悅的事物；舒適的設施（或條件）
comfort.eg: After the trip, it was nice getting back to a few home comforts.

comfort.eng_def: to make someone feel better when they are sad or worried
comfort.eg: The girl's mother was at home today, being comforted by relatives.

comfortable.eng_def: Comfortable furniture and clothes provide a pleasant feeling and do not give you any physical problems.
comfortable.chi_def: （傢俱和衣服）舒適的，舒服的，令人愜意的
舒服的；舒坦的；輕鬆自在的
comfortable.eg: Are you comfortable or shall I turn the heat down?

comfortable.eng_def: If an ill or injured person in hospital is comfortable, they are is not feeling too much pain.
comfortable.chi_def: （醫院的病人或傷者）感覺不太痛的

comfortable.eng_def: If you are comfortable with a situation, you are not worried about it.
comfortable.eg: I'm not comfortable with the idea of leaving her on her own.

comfortable.eng_def: having enough money for a good standard of living
comfortable.eg: They're not fabulously rich or anything, but they're quite comfortable.

comfortable.eng_def: If you win a game or competition by a comfortable amount, you win easily.
comfortable.chi_def: （在比賽中）輕鬆的，輕而易舉的

comic.eng_def: funny and making you want to laugh
a magazine or book that contains a set of stories told in pictures with a small amount of writing
comic.chi_def: （尤指以兒童為對象的）連環畫雜誌，漫畫雜誌

comic.eng_def: someone who entertains people by telling jokes
comic.chi_def: 逗笑的人；喜劇演員，滑稽演員

comic.eng_def: the section of a newspaper where comic strips appear
comic.eg: Dad read the front page while the kids read the comics.

comma.eng_def: the symbol , used in writing to separate parts of a sentence showing a slight pause, or to separate the single things in a list

command.eng_def: an order, especially one given by a soldier
command.eg: You will run forward at (= when you hear) my command.

command.eng_def: control over someone or something and responsibility for him, her, or it
command.eg: Colonel Sailing has command over/is in command of the Guards Regiment.

command.eng_def: an instruction to a computer to perform a particular action
a great knowledge of a subject and an ability to use that knowledge
command.eg: She has an impressive command of the English language.
the castle's position with its command of the surrounding countryside
The officer commanded his men to shoot.

command.eng_def: to control someone or something and tell him, her, or it what to do
command.eg: Colonel Sailing commands the Guards Regiment.

command.eng_def: to deserve and get something good, such as attention, respect, or a lot of money
command.eg: She was one of those teachers who just commanded respect.
The master bedroom commands a view of rolling green hills.

command.eng_def: a group of soldiers or an area controlled by a commander

commander.eng_def: an officer who is in charge of a military operation, or an officer of a particular rank in many countries' naval forces

commemorate.eng_def: to remember officially and give respect to a great person or event, especially by a public ceremony or by making a statue or special building
commemorate.chi_def: （尤指舉行公開儀式或豎立雕塑或特別建築）紀念，緬懷
commemorate.eg: Gathered all together in this church, we commemorate those who lost their lives in the war.

commence.eg: We will commence building work in August of next year.

comment.eng_def: something that you say or write that expresses your opinion
comment.eg: I don't want any comments on/about my new haircut, thank you!

comment.eng_def: used to say that you do not want to answer someone's question

comment.eg: My mum always comments on what I'm wearing.

commentary.eng_def: a spoken description of an event on the radio or television that is broadcast as the event happens
commentary.chi_def: （廣播或電視所播事件的）評論，解說，實況報道
commentary.eg: The commentary on the Olympic Games was much better on the other channel.

commentary.eng_def: a set of written remarks on an event, book, or person that explains its subject or expresses an opinion on it
commentary.eg: There's good arts coverage in the newspaper, but not much political commentary.

commentary.eng_def: a continuous description of events as they are happening
commentary.chi_def: 實況追蹤報道，現場評述

commentator.eng_def: a reporter for radio or television who provides a spoken description of and remarks on an event, especially a sports competition, as it happens
commentator.chi_def: （廣播或電視的）解說員，評論員

commerce.eng_def: the activities involved in buying and selling things
commerce.eg: the world of commerce and industry

commercial.eng_def: related to buying and selling things
used to describe a record, film, book, etc. that has been produced with the aim of making money and as a result has little artistic value
commercial.chi_def: （唱片、電影、書等）商業化的，以營利為目的的

commercial.eng_def: A commercial product can be bought by or is intended to be bought by the general public.
used to refer to radio or television paid for by advertisements that are broadcast between and during programmes
commercial.chi_def: （廣播或電視）商業性的，靠廣告收入維持的

commercial.eng_def: an advertisement that is broadcast on television or radio

commission.eng_def: to formally choose someone to do a special piece of work, or to formally ask for a special piece of work from someone
commission.eg: The newspaper commissioned a series of articles on the worst excesses of the fashion industry.

commission.eng_def: to give someone the official authority to be an officer in the armed forces
commission.eg: Grandfather was commissioned as Group Captain in the RAF just before the war.

commission.eng_def: a group of people who have been formally chosen to discover information about a problem or examine the reasons why the problem exists
commission.chi_def: （負責調查問題真相或原因的）委員會
commission.eg: a commission on alcohol abuse/racial tension

commission.eng_def: a payment to someone who sells goods that is directly related to the amount sold, or a system that uses such payments
commission.eg: Is she paid a regular wage or is it on/by commission only?
