commission.eng_def: a request to do a special piece of work
commission.eg: She's just got a commission to paint Sir Ellis Pike's wife.

commission.eng_def: the act of committing a crime
the official authority to be an officer in the armed forces

commit.eng_def: to do something illegal or something that is considered wrong
commit.chi_def: 做（違法或錯誤的事）；犯（罪、錯）
commit.eg: He was sent to prison for a crime that he didn't commit.

commit.eng_def: to promise or give your loyalty, time, or money to a particular principle, person, or plan of action
commit.chi_def: 承諾，保證；（使）忠於；（使）致力於；投入（時間或金錢）
commit.eg: Like so many men, he has problems committing himself to a relationship.

commit.eng_def: to express an opinion or to make a decision that you tell people about
commit.eg: I think I can come but I won't commit myself till I know for sure.

commit.eng_def: to make certain that you remember something

commit.eg: Perhaps we should commit these ideas to paper before we forget them.

commit.eng_def: to send someone officially to prison or hospital
commit.eg: He's been committed to prison for fraud.

commitment.eng_def: a willingness to give your time and energy to something that you believe in, or a promise or firm decision to do something
commitment.chi_def: 忠誠；投入；奉獻；承諾，保證，諾言
commitment.eg: Players must make a commitment to play for a full season.

commitment.eng_def: something that you must do or deal with that takes your time

committee.eng_def: a small group of people chosen to represent a larger organization and either make decisions or collect information for it
committee.chi_def: （代表較大的組織決策或搜集資訊的）委員會
committee.eg: She sits on/is on the school's development committee.

commodity.eng_def: a substance or product that can be traded, bought, or sold
commodity.eg: The country's most valuable commodities include tin and diamonds.
If you're going into teaching, energy is a necessary commodity.

common.eng_def: the same in a lot of places or for a lot of people
common.chi_def: 常見的；經常的；普遍的；普通的；平常的
common.eg: It's quite common to see couples who dress alike.

common.eng_def: the basic level of politeness that you expect from someone

common.eg: It's common knowledge that they live together.

common.eng_def: belonging to or shared by two or more people, or things
If something is done for the common good, it is done to help everyone.
to act together with someone in order to achieve something
common.eg: Environmental protesters have made common cause with local people to stop the motorway being built.

common.eng_def: typical of a low social class
common.eg: My mum thinks dyed blonde hair is a bit common.

common.eng_def: an area of grass that everyone is allowed to use, usually in or near a village
common.chi_def: （通常在村子裡或附近的）公地，共用草地

common.eng_def: to share interests, experiences, or other characteristics with someone or something
common.chi_def: 有相同（興趣、經歷或特點）
common.eg: We don't really have much in common.

common.eng_def: in the same way as someone or something
common.eg: In common with many mothers, she feels torn between her family and her work.

commonplace.eng_def: happening often or often seen or experienced and so not considered to be special
commonplace.chi_def: 平常的；常見的；普通的；普遍的

commonplace.eng_def: a boring remark that is used very often and does not have much meaning
commonplace.chi_def: 陳腔濫調；寒暄客套；老生常談
commonplace.eg: We exchanged commonplaces about the weather over cups of tea.

communicate.eng_def: to share information with others by speaking, writing, moving your body, or using other signals
communicate.eg: We can now communicate instantly with people on the other side of the world.

communicate.eng_def: to talk about your thoughts and feelings, and help other people to understand them
communicate.chi_def: 傳達，表達，傳遞，溝通（思想或感情）
communicate.eg: I find I just can't communicate with her.

communicate.eng_def: to pass a disease from one person or animal to another
If one room communicates with another, it connects with it through a door.
communicate.eg: The bedroom communicates with both bathroom and hall.

communication.eng_def: the act of communicating with people
communication.chi_def: 交流；溝通；交際；傳達；傳播；通訊
communication.eg: Television is an increasingly important means of communication.
We received your communication of 11 March and are sorry to inform you that we won't be attending the conference.

communication.eng_def: the various methods of sending information between people and places, especially phones, computers, radio, etc.
communication.chi_def: （尤指郵政、廣播、電話等官方的）通訊，通訊系統

communication.eng_def: ways of moving between one place and another
communication.eg: Its commercial success as a city is partly due to its excellent rail and road communications.

communicative.eng_def: willing to talk to people and give them information
communicative.chi_def: 健談的；樂意提供資訊的
communicative.eg: He was in a bad mood at breakfast and wasn't very communicative.
The communicative ability of the whale is thought to be highly developed.

communism.eng_def: the belief in a society without different social classes in which the methods of production are owned and controlled by all its members and everyone works as much as they can and receives what they need

community.eng_def: the people living in one particular area or people who are considered as a unit because of their common interests, social group, or nationality
community.eg: He's well known in the local community.

community.eng_def: a group of animals or plants that live or grow together

community.eg: Unlike the present government, we believe in serving the community.

commute.eng_def: to make the same journey regularly between work and home
commute.chi_def: 上下班往返；往返於工作地點與家之間；通勤
commute.eg: It's exhausting commuting from Brighton to London every day.

commute.eng_def: to change one thing into another
commute.eg: People used to believe that you could commute base metals into gold.

commute.eng_def: to exchange one type of payment for a different type
commute.eg: I think I'll commute my life insurance into an annuity.

commute.eng_def: to change a punishment to one that is less severe
commute.eg: Her sentence was commuted from death to life imprisonment.

commute.eng_def: a regular journey between work and home
commute.chi_def: 上下班往返；往返於工作地點與家之間；通勤
commute.eg: It's at least an hour's commute to work.

commuter.eng_def: someone who regularly travels between work and home
commuter.chi_def: 上下班往返的人，通勤者
commuter.eg: The train was packed with commuters.

compact.eng_def: consisting of parts that are positioned together closely or in a tidy way, using very little space
a small, flat case that contains women's face powder
compact.chi_def: （裝女性敷面用香粉的）帶鏡粉盒

compact.eng_def: a formal agreement between two or more people, organizations, or countries
compact.eg: They made a compact not to reveal any details.

compact.eng_def: to press something together in a tight and solid way
compact.eg: Cars had compacted the snow until it was like ice.

companion.eng_def: a person you spend a lot of time with often because you are friends or because you are travelling together
companion.eg: The dog has been her constant companion these past ten years.

companion.eng_def: in the past, a young woman who was paid to care for and provide friendship for an old or ill woman, especially while she was travelling
companion.chi_def: 陪護（舊時受僱陪伴老太太或女性病人旅行的年輕女子）

companion.eg: I've still got one of the candlesticks but I've lost its companion.

companion.eng_def: used in the title of a type of book that gives you information on a particular subject or tells you how to do something

companionship.eng_def: the enjoyment of spending time with other people
companionship.eg: I lived on my own for a while but I missed the companionship of others.

company.eng_def: an organization that sells goods or services in order to make money
company.eg: He works for a software company/a company that makes software.

company.eng_def: the fact of being with a person or people, or the person or people you are with
to be pleasant and entertaining to be with
company.eg: You'll like Rosie - she's good company.

company.eng_def: If you do something for company, you do it to make you feel as if you are not alone.
company.chi_def: 為了有個伴，為了不冷清
company.eg: I usually have the radio on for company.

company.eng_def: to stay with someone so that they are not alone
company.eg: I'll keep you company till the train comes.

company.eng_def: a group of actors, singers, or dancers who perform together
company.eg: She's in the National Theatre Company.

company.eng_def: a large group of soldiers. especially a division of a battalion
company.chi_def: （尤指軍隊中營下轄的）連，連隊

company.eng_def: an organized group of young women who are Guides
company.eg: My cousin and I joined the same Guide company.

comparable.eng_def: similar in size, amount, or quality to something else
comparable.chi_def: （大小、數量或品質上）類似的，相當的，可比的
comparable.eg: The girls are of comparable ages.

comparative.eng_def: the form of an adjective or adverb that expresses a difference in amount, number, degree, or quality

comparative.eg: She's carrying out a comparative study of health in inner cities and rural areas.

comparative.eng_def: a situation that is comfortable, free, silent, etc. when compared to another situation or what is normal
comparative.chi_def: 相對的舒適（自由，安靜等）
comparative.eg: I enjoyed the comparative calm of his flat after the busy office.

comparative.eng_def: relating to the form of an adjective or adverb that expresses a difference in amount, number, degree, or quality

compare.eng_def: to examine or look for the difference between two or more things
compare.eg: If you compare house prices in the two areas, it's quite amazing how different they are.

compare.eng_def: to judge, suggest, or consider that something is similar or of equal quality to something else
compare.chi_def: 將…比作；拿…與…相比；認為…和…相似（或不相上下）
compare.eg: The poet compares his lover's tongue to a razor blade.

compare.eng_def: If something or someone does not compare with something or someone else, the second thing is very much better than the first.
compare.eg: Instant coffee just doesn't compare with freshly ground coffee.

compare.eng_def: If something compares favourably with something else, it is better than it.
compare.eg: The hotel certainly compared favourably with the one we stayed in last year.

compare.eng_def: so good that everyone or everything else is of worse quality
compare.chi_def: 無與倫比；無可比擬；舉世無雙

comparison.eng_def: the act of comparing two or more people or things
comparison.eg: They made a comparison of different countries' eating habits.

comparison.eng_def: the fact of considering something similar or of equal quality to something else
comparison.eg: She drew a comparison between life in the army and life in prison.

compass.eng_def: a device for finding direction with a needle that can move easily and that always points to magnetic north
a V-shaped device that is used for drawing circles or measuring distances on maps
a particular range (of ability, activity, interest, etc.)
compass.chi_def: （能力、活動、興趣等的）界限，範圍，範疇
compass.eg: It's a musical instrument made of brass, somewhat like a cornet and with a similar compass.

compassion.eng_def: a strong feeling of sympathy and sadness for the suffering or bad luck of others and a wish to help them
compassion.eg: I was hoping she might show a little compassion.

compatible.eng_def: able to exist, live together, or work successfully with something or someone else
compatible.chi_def: 可共存的；協調的；相容的
compatible.eg: It was when we started living together that we found we just weren't compatible.

compel.eng_def: to force someone to do something
compel.eg: As a schoolboy he was compelled to wear shorts even in winter.

compel.eng_def: to produce a strong feeling or reaction
compel.chi_def: （有時指並非所願地）激起，引發
compel.eg: Over the years her work has compelled universal admiration and trust.

compensate.eng_def: to pay someone money in exchange for something that has been lost or damaged or for some problem
compensate.eg: Victims of the crash will be compensated for their injuries.

compensate.eng_def: to provide something good or useful in place of something or to make someone feel better about something that has failed or been lost or missed
compensate.eg: Nothing will ever compensate for his lost childhood.

compensation.eng_def: money that is paid to someone in exchange for something that has been lost or damaged or for some problem
compensation.eg: She received £40,000 in compensation for a lost eye.

compensation.eng_def: something that makes you feel better when you have suffered something bad
compensation.eg: I have to spend three months of the year away from home - but there are compensations like the chance to meet new people.

compensation.eng_def: the combination of money and other benefits (= rewards) that an employee receives for doing their job
compensation.chi_def: 報酬（僱員獲得的金錢和其他福利的總和）
compensation.eg: Annual compensation for our executives includes salary and bonus under our incentive plan.

compete.eng_def: to try to be more successful than someone or something else
compete.eg: It's difficult for a small shop to compete against/with the big supermarkets.

compete.eng_def: to take part in a race or competition
compete.chi_def: 參加賽跑；參與競爭；爭奪
compete.eg: Are you competing in the 100 metres?

competence.eng_def: the ability to do something well
competence.eg: Her competence as a teacher is unquestionable.

competent.chi_def: 有能力的；能幹的；稱職的

competition.eng_def: a situation in which someone is trying to win something or be more successful than someone else
an organized event in which people try to win a prize by being the best, fastest, etc.
the person or people you are trying to be better than
competition.eg: The competition on the track looked fierce and her heart sank.

competitive.eng_def: wanting very much to win or be more successful than other people
competitive.eg: You're very competitive - it's meant to be a friendly match!

competitive.eng_def: Competitive prices, services, etc. are as good as or better than other prices, services, etc.

competitor.eng_def: a person, team, or company that is competing against others
competitor.eg: Their prices are better than any of their competitors.

compile.eng_def: to collect information from different places and arrange it in a book, report, or list
compile.eg: We're compiling some facts and figures for a documentary on the subject.

compile.eng_def: to change a computer program into a machine language

complain.eng_def: to say that something is wrong or not satisfactory
complain.eg: Lots of people have complained about the noise.

complain.eng_def: to tell someone formally that something is wrong
complain.eg: If the service was so bad why didn't you complain to the manager?

complaint.eng_def: a statement that something is wrong or not satisfactory
complaint.eg: We've received a complaint from one of our listeners about offensive language.

complement.eng_def: to make something else seem better or more attractive when combining with it
complement.chi_def: 補充；補足；使完善；為…增色
complement.eg: Strawberries and cream complement each other perfectly.

complement.eng_def: a part of a clause that usually follows the verb in English and adds more information about the subject or object

complete.eg: Complete the sentence with one of the adjectives provided.

complete.eng_def: to write all the details asked for on a form or other document
complete.eg: Have you completed your application form yet?
He's just completed filming his 17th feature film.

complete.eng_def: very great or to the largest degree possible

complete.eg: the complete works of Oscar Wilde

completion.eng_def: the act of finishing something that you are doing or making
completion.eg: You'll be paid on completion of the project.

complex.eng_def: involving a lot of different but related parts
complex.chi_def: 由許多相關的不同部分組成的；構造複雜的

complex.eng_def: difficult to understand or find an answer to because of having many different parts
complex.chi_def: 難懂的，費解的；錯綜複雜的
complex.eg: It's a very complex issue to which there is no straightforward answer.

complex.eng_def: a large building with various connected rooms or a related group of buildings
a particular anxiety or unconscious fear that a person has, especially as a result of an unpleasant experience that they have had in the past or because they have a low opinion of their own worth
complex.chi_def: （尤指由過去的不快經歷或自我評價不高造成的）情結，心理負擔，病態心理

complexion.eng_def: the natural appearance of the skin on a person's face, especially its colour or quality

complexion.eg: These are radical changes which will alter the complexion of the British contemporary dance scene.

complexity.eng_def: the state of having many parts and being difficult to understand or find an answer to
the features of something that make it difficult to understand or find an answer to
complexity.chi_def: 複雜的事物；使某物難以理解之處，令問題難以解答（或解決）的方面
complexity.eg: There are a lot of complexities surrounding this issue.

complicate.eng_def: to make something more difficult to deal with, do, or understand
complicate.chi_def: 使複雜化；使更難懂；使更麻煩
complicate.eg: It will only complicate the situation if we invite his old girlfriend as well.

complicate.eng_def: If one illness complicates another illness, it makes the other illness worse.
complicate.eg: The breathing problem has now been complicated by a chest infection.

complication.eng_def: something that makes a situation more difficult, or the act of doing this
complication.chi_def: 使情況複雜化的事物；複雜化
complication.eg: Dave couldn't find his passport at the airport and then there were further complications when Fiona lost her baggage.

complication.eng_def: an extra medical problem that makes it more difficult to treat an existing illness
complication.eg: If there are no complications, the doctor says that she'll be able to come home within two weeks.

compliment.eng_def: a remark that expresses approval, admiration, or respect
compliment.eg: He complained that his husband never paid him any compliments anymore.

compliment.eng_def: an action that expresses approval or respect
compliment.eg: You should take it as a compliment when I fall asleep in your company - it means I'm relaxed.

compliment.eng_def: an expression of your admiration or respect
compliment.eg: That was an excellent meal! My compliments to the chef.

compliment.eng_def: If you give something to someone with your compliments, you give it to that person free.
compliment.eg: We enclose a copy of our latest brochure, with our compliments.

compliment.eng_def: to praise or express admiration for someone
compliment.eg: I was just complimenting Robert on his wonderful food.

component.eng_def: a part that combines with other parts to form something bigger

compose.eng_def: to produce music, poetry, or formal writing
compose.chi_def: 作曲；創作（樂曲、詩歌）；著（書）
compose.eg: Prokofiev started composing at the age of five.

compose.eng_def: to be formed from various things
compose.eg: Air is composed mainly of nitrogen and oxygen.

compose.eng_def: to be the parts that something is made of
compose.eg: At that time, women composed only 1.6 percent of the US forces.

compose.eng_def: to make yourself calm again after being angry or upset
compose.chi_def: 使自己鎮定；使自己平靜下來
compose.eg: She finally stopped crying and composed herself.

compose.eng_def: to try to make yourself look or feel calm after being angry or upset
compose.eg: I tried to compose my features into a smile.

compose.eng_def: to arrange words, sentences, pages, etc. in preparation for printing

composition.eng_def: a piece of music that someone has written
composition.eg: This concerto is one of her earlier/later compositions.

composition.eng_def: the process or skill of writing music
composition.chi_def: 音樂創作（技巧），作曲（技巧）
composition.eg: At music school I studied piano and composition.

composition.eng_def: the way that people or things are arranged in a painting or photograph
composition.chi_def: （繪畫或照片的）構圖，構思，佈局

composition.eng_def: a short piece of writing about a particular subject, done by a student
the parts, substances, etc. that something is made of

compound.eng_def: a chemical that combines two or more elements
compound.eg: Salt is a compound of sodium and chlorine.

compound.eng_def: something consisting of two or more different parts
compound.eg: Then there was his manner, a curious compound of humour and severity.

compound.eng_def: a word that combines two or more different words. Often, the meaning of the compound cannot be discovered by knowing the meaning of the different words that form it. Compounds may be written either as one word or as separate words
compound.eg: 'Bodyguard' and 'floppy disk' are two examples of compounds.

compound.eng_def: an area surrounded by fences or walls that contains a group of buildings
compound.eg: The gates opened and the troops marched into their compound.

compound.eng_def: to make a problem or difficult situation worse
compound.eg: Her terror was compounded by the feeling that she was being watched.
Most tyres are made of rubber compounded with other chemicals and materials.

compound.eng_def: consisting of two or more parts

used to refer to a system of paying interest in which interest is paid both on the original amount of money invested (= given to companies hoping to get more back) or borrowed and on the interest that has collected over a period of time

comprehend.eg: I fail to comprehend their attitude.

comprehension.eng_def: the ability to understand completely and be familiar with a situation, facts, etc.
comprehension.eg: He has no comprehension of the size of the problem.

comprehension.eng_def: a test to find out how well students understand written or spoken language

comprehensive.eng_def: complete and including everything that is necessary
comprehensive.chi_def: 全面的；綜合的；包羅萬象的；詳盡的
comprehensive.eg: We offer you a comprehensive training in all aspects of the business.

comprise.eng_def: to have as parts or members, or to be those parts or members
comprise.eg: The course comprises a class book, a practice book, and a CD.

compromise.eng_def: an agreement in an argument in which the people involved reduce their demands or change their opinion in order to agree
compromise.eg: It is hoped that a compromise will be reached in today's talks.

compromise.eng_def: to accept that you will reduce your demands or change your opinion in order to reach an agreement with someone
compromise.eg: Party unity is threatened when members will not compromise.

compromise.eng_def: to allow your principles to be less strong or your standards or morals to be lower
compromise.eg: Don't compromise your beliefs/principles for the sake of being accepted.

compromise.eng_def: to risk having a harmful effect on something
compromise.eg: We would never compromise the safety of our passengers.

compute.eng_def: to calculate an answer or amount by using a machine
compute.eg: Compute the ratio of the object's height to its weight.

computer.eng_def: an electronic machine that is used for storing, organizing, and finding words, numbers, and pictures, for doing calculations, and for controlling other machines

computerize.eng_def: to use a computer to do something that was done by people or other machines before
computerize.eg: They've just computerized the whole system.

comrade.eng_def: a friend, especially one who you have been involved in difficult or dangerous, usually military, activities with
comrade.chi_def: （尤指共患難過的）朋友，同志；（通常指）戰友
comrade.eg: Many of his comrades were killed in the battle.

comrade.eng_def: a member of the same political group, especially a communist or socialist group or a trade union
comrade.chi_def: （尤指共產主義、社會主義組織或工會的）同志，同仁
comrade.eg: I know my opinion is shared by many of my comrades in the Labour movement.

comrade.chi_def: 朋友般的；戰友般的；友好的
comrade.eg: He gave me a comradely slap on the back.

conceal.eng_def: to prevent something from being seen or known about
conceal.eg: The listening device was concealed in a pen.

concede.eng_def: to admit, often unwillingly, that something is true
concede.eg: The government has conceded (that) the new tax policy has been a disaster.

concede.eng_def: to admit that you have lost in a competition
concede.eg: He kept on arguing and wouldn't concede defeat.

concede.eng_def: to allow someone to have something, even if you do not want to
concede.eg: The president is not expected to concede these reforms.

concede.eng_def: to fail to stop an opposing team or person from winning a point or game
concede.chi_def: 沒能阻止對方進球（或得分）
concede.eg: The team conceded two goals (to the other side) in the first five minutes of the game.

conceit.eng_def: the state of being too proud of yourself and your actions
conceit.eg: The conceit of that man is incredible!

conceit.eng_def: a clever or surprising comparison, especially in a poem
conceit.chi_def: （尤指詩歌中）巧妙的比喻，別出心裁的比喻

conceive.eg: I think my uncle still conceives of me as a four-year-old.

conceive.eng_def: to invent a plan or an idea
conceive.chi_def: 構想，想出，設想出（計劃或主意）
conceive.eg: He conceived the plot for this film while he was still a student.

conceive.eng_def: to become pregnant, or to cause a baby to begin to form
conceive.eg: Do you know exactly when you conceived?

concentrate.eng_def: to direct your attention or your efforts towards a particular activity, subject, or problem
concentrate.chi_def: 專注，專心；全神貫注；集中（注意力）
concentrate.eg: Come on, concentrate! We don't have all day to do this.

concentrate.eng_def: to bring or come together in a large number or amount in one particular area
concentrate.eg: Most of the country's population is concentrated in the north.

concentrate.eng_def: to make a liquid or substance stronger and reduce its size by removing water from it
a liquid from which some of the water has been removed
an ore from which rock has been removed

concentration.eng_def: the ability to think carefully about something you are doing and nothing else
concentration.eg: The noise outside made concentration difficult.

concentration.eng_def: a large number or amount of something in the same place
concentration.eg: There is a heavy concentration of troops in the area.

concentration.eng_def: the exact amount of one particular substance that is found in another substance
concentration.eg: a concentration of one part per million

concept.eg: The concept of free speech is unknown to them.
I don't think you have any concept of the pain you have caused her.

conception.eng_def: an idea of what something or someone is like, or a basic understanding of a situation or a principle
conception.eg: People from different cultures have different conceptions of the world.

conception.eng_def: the process of a male and a female sex cell joining and causing a baby to start to form

concern.eg: The state of my father's health concerns us greatly.

concern.eng_def: to be important to someone or to involve someone directly
concern.chi_def: 對…很重要；與…相關；涉及到…，關係到…
concern.eg: Matters of pollution and the environment concern us all.

concern.eng_def: If a story, film, or article concerns a particular subject, person, etc., it is about that person or subject.
concern.chi_def: （故事、電影或文章）涉及，是關於…的
concern.eg: The documentary concerns a woman who goes to China as a missionary.

concern.eng_def: to become involved with something, or worried about something
concern.eg: There's no need for you to concern yourself with what happened.

concern.eng_def: something you write at the start of a formal letter or notice when you do not know exactly who it should be sent to
concern.chi_def: （用於正式信函開頭處）敬啟者

concern.eng_def: a worried or nervous feeling about something, or something that makes you feel worried
concern.chi_def: 擔心；憂慮；掛念；憂慮的事情
concern.eg: Concern for the safety of the two missing teenagers is growing.

concern.eng_def: something that is important to you, or the fact of being important
concern.chi_def: 重要的事；關心的事，關切的事；關心，關切
concern.eg: His concern to appear sophisticated amused everyone.

concern.eng_def: something that involves or affects you or is important to you
concern.chi_def: 關切的事；關心的事；有利害關係的事
concern.eg: What were the major concerns of the writers from this period?
The results of the election are of concern to us all.

concerning.eg: I've had a letter from the tax authorities concerning my tax payments.
The increase in crime in the area is very concerning.

concert.eng_def: a performance of music by one or more musicians or singers

concession.eng_def: something that is allowed or given up, often in order to end a disagreement, or the act of allowing or giving this
concession.chi_def: （常指為結束爭端而作出的）認可，讓步，妥協
concession.eg: Both sides involved in the conflict made some concessions in yesterday's talks.
The former president's concession came even before all the votes had been counted.

concession.eng_def: a reduction in the usual price of something, made available to students, old people, etc.
concession.chi_def: （對學生、老少或失業人士的）價格優惠，減價
concession.eg: You can get travel concessions if you are under 26.

concession.eng_def: a special right to property or land
concession.chi_def: （財產、土地等的）特許權；許可使用權

concession.eng_def: the right to sell a product in a particular area
concession.chi_def: 特許經營權；特許銷售權

concise.eng_def: short and clear, expressing what needs to be said without unnecessary words
concise.chi_def: 簡潔的；簡明的；簡練的；簡明扼要的
concise.eg: Make your answers clear and concise.

conclude.eng_def: to end a speech, meeting, or piece of writing
conclude.eg: She concluded the speech by reminding us of our responsibility.

conclude.eng_def: to complete an official agreement or task, or arrange a business deal
to judge or decide something after thinking carefully about it
conclude.chi_def: 斷定；決定；推斷出；作出（結論）
conclude.eg: The jury concluded from the evidence that the defendant was innocent.

conclusion.eg: Be careful not to introduce new ideas in the conclusion of your essay.
In conclusion, I would like to thank our guest speaker.

conclusion.eng_def: the act of arranging or agreeing something formally
the opinion you have after considering all the information about something
conclusion.eg: Did you come to/reach/draw any conclusions at the meeting this morning?

concrete.eng_def: a very hard building material made by mixing together cement, sand, small stones, and water

concrete.eg: Why did you concrete over that nice garden?

concrete.eng_def: clear and certain, or real and existing in a form that can be seen or felt
concrete.chi_def: 確定的，確實的；具體的，有形的，實在的
concrete.eg: They think she killed her husband, but they have no concrete evidence.

condemn.eng_def: to criticize something or someone strongly, usually for moral reasons
condemn.chi_def: （通常指出於道義而）譴責，指責
condemn.eg: The terrorist action has been condemned as an act of barbarism and cowardice.

condense.eng_def: to reduce something, such as a speech or piece of writing, in length
condense.eg: I condensed ten pages of comments into/to two.

condense.eng_def: to make a liquid thicker by removing some of the water
to change or make something change from a gas to a liquid or solid state
condense.chi_def: （使氣體）變成液體或固體；（使）凝固；（使）凝結
condense.eg: Water vapour in the air condenses into fog.

condition.eng_def: the particular state that something or someone is in
condition.eg: Mum's still got our pram - it's very old, but it's in perfect condition.

condition.eng_def: the physical situation that someone or something is in and affected by
condition.chi_def: 物質條件；情況；實際環境

condition.eng_def: any of different types of diseases
condition.eg: to suffer from a heart/skin condition

condition.eng_def: not healthy enough for hard physical exercise, as a result of not taking part in sport or other physical activities
condition.chi_def: （由於不參加鍛煉或其他體力活動而）身體狀況不佳，不在狀態

condition.eng_def: an arrangement that must exist before something else can happen
condition.eg: One of the conditions in the contract is that we don't build on the land.
I'll come to the party on the condition that you don't wear those ridiculous trousers!

condition.eng_def: to train or influence a person or animal mentally so that they do or expect a particular thing without thinking about it
condition.chi_def: 訓練；使習慣於；使適應；使（人或動物）形成條件反射

condition.eng_def: to try to improve the quality or appearance of your hair, skin, etc. by putting a conditioner on it
condition.chi_def: （使用護髮或護膚品）改善，保養（發質、皮膚等）

conduct.eng_def: to organize and perform a particular activity
conduct.eg: We are conducting a survey to find out what our customers think of their local bus service.

conduct.eng_def: to behave in a particular way, especially in a public or formal situation, or to organize the way in which you live in a particular way
conduct.chi_def: （尤指在公共或正式場合中）舉止，表現；為人
conduct.eg: How should I conduct myself at these dinners? I know nothing about etiquette.

conduct.eng_def: to lead someone to a particular place
conduct.eg: May I conduct you to your table, sir, or would you prefer to have a drink at the bar first?

conduct.eng_def: If you conduct a tour of a place, you take people around the place and show it to them.
conduct.eg: A guide conducts tours of the cathedral every afternoon at 2.00.

conduct.eng_def: to direct the performance of musicians or a piece of music
conduct.eg: The orchestra was conducted by Mira Shapur.

conduct.eng_def: to allow electricity or heat to go through
conduct.eg: Copper conducts electricity, but plastic does not.

conduct.eng_def: the way in which an activity is organized and performed
conduct.eg: He was criticized for his conduct of the inquiry.

conductor.eng_def: someone who directs the performance of musicians or a piece of music
a railway official who travels on and is responsible for a train
someone whose job is to sell tickets on a bus, train, or other public vehicle
conductor.chi_def: （公共汽車、火車或其他交通工具上的）售票員

conductor.eng_def: a substance that allows heat or electricity to go through it
conductor.eg: Metal is a good conductor of heat.

cone.eng_def: a shape with a flat, round or oval base and a top that becomes narrower until it forms a point
the hard oval-shaped fruit of a conifer
a container made of very light thin biscuit, or one of these containing ice cream

confer.eng_def: to exchange ideas on a particular subject, often in order to reach a decision on what action to take
confer.chi_def: （常指爲達成行動決議而）商討，商議，協商
confer.eg: I need some time to confer with my lawyer.

confer.eng_def: to give an official title, honour, or advantage to someone
confer.chi_def: 授予（稱號、榮譽）；賦予（優勢）
confer.eg: An honorary doctorate was conferred on him by Columbia University.

conference.eng_def: an event, sometimes lasting a few days, at which there is a group of talks on a particular subject, or a meeting in which especially business matters are discussed formally
conference.chi_def: 會議，大會；討論會，協商會

conference.eg: Ms O'Neill isn't available at the moment. She's in conference.

confess.eng_def: to admit that you have done something wrong or something that you feel guilty or bad about
confess.chi_def: 坦白；供認，招認；承認（錯誤或罪行）
confess.eg: She confessed to her husband that she had sold her wedding ring.

confess.eng_def: in the Christian religion, especially the Roman Catholic Church, to tell God or a priest what you have done wrong so that you can be forgiven
confess.chi_def: （基督教、尤指天主教中向上帝或神父）懺悔

confession.eng_def: the act of admitting that you have done something wrong or illegal
confession.eg: I have a confession to make - I've lost that book you lent me.

confession.eng_def: an occasion when a Christian tells God or, especially in the Roman Catholic Church, tells a priest formally and privately, what they have done wrong so that they can be forgiven
confession.eg: Have you been to confession recently?

confidence.eng_def: the quality of being certain of your abilities or of having trust in people, plans, or the future
confidence.chi_def: 自信；信心，把握；信賴，信任
confidence.eg: He has the confidence to walk into a room of strangers and immediately start a conversation.

confidence.eng_def: a secret that you tell someone
If you tell something to someone in confidence, you do not want them to tell anyone else.
to share your secrets with someone, trusting them not to tell other people
confidence.chi_def: 向…透露自己的心事，將秘密告訴…
confidence.eg: I should never have taken him into my confidence.

confident.chi_def: 自信的；有信心的；確信的；有把握的；信任的
confident.eg: Be a bit more confident in yourself!

confidential.eng_def: secret, often in a formal, business, or military situation
confidential.eg: All information will be treated as strictly confidential.

confine.eng_def: to limit an activity, person, or problem in some way
confine.eg: Let's confine our discussion to the matter in question, please!

confine.eng_def: to keep someone closed in a place, often by force
confine.eg: The hostages had been confined for so long that they couldn't cope with the outside world.

confine.eng_def: to exist only in a particular area or group of people
confine.eg: We know that the illness is not confined to any one group in society.

confirm.eng_def: to make an arrangement or meeting certain, often by phone or writing
confirm.eg: Six people have confirmed that they will be attending and ten haven't replied yet.

confirm.eng_def: to prove that a belief or an opinion that was previously not completely certain is true
confirm.eg: The smell of cigarette smoke confirmed what he had suspected: there had been a party in his absence.

confirm.eng_def: to accept someone formally as a full member of the Christian Church at a special ceremony

conflict.eng_def: an active disagreement between people with opposing opinions or principles
conflict.eg: There was a lot of conflict between him and his father.

conflict.eng_def: fighting between two or more groups of people or countries
conflict.eg: We wish to avoid conflict between our countries if at all possible.

conflict.eng_def: If beliefs, needs, or facts, etc. conflict, they are very different and cannot easily exist together or both be true.
conflict.chi_def: 不一致；發生抵觸；相矛盾；衝突
conflict.eg: The results of the new research would seem to conflict with existing theories.
If the two sides conflict with each other again, it will be disastrous for party unity.

conform.eng_def: to behave according to the usual standards of behaviour that are expected by a group or society
conform.chi_def: 順從；遵從；隨大流，順應習俗
conform.eg: At our school, you were required to conform, and there was no place for originality.

confront.eng_def: to face, meet, or deal with a difficult situation or person
confront.chi_def: 面對，面臨；遭遇；直面，正視
confront.eg: As she left the court, she was confronted by angry crowds who tried to block her way.

confrontation.eg: Some couples seem to like confrontation, but Josh and I hardly ever argue.

confuse.eng_def: to mix up someone's mind or ideas, or to make something difficult to understand
confuse.eg: You're confusing him! Tell him slowly and one thing at a time.

confuse.eng_def: to mix up two separate things or people in your mind, imagining that they are one
confuse.eg: You're confusing me with my sister - she's the singer.

confusion.eng_def: a situation in which people do not understand what is happening, what they should do or who someone or something is
confusion.chi_def: 困惑，糊塗；迷惑不解；混淆
confusion.eg: There seems to be some confusion over who is actually giving the talk.

confusion.eng_def: a situation, often with a lot of activity and noise, in which people do not know what to do
confusion.eg: In the confusion after the bomb blast, I lost my bag and wasn't able to stop and look for it.

congratulate.eng_def: to praise someone and say that you approve of or are pleased about a special or unusual achievement
congratulate.eg: I was just congratulating Ceri on winning/on having won her race.

congratulation.eng_def: something that you say when you want to congratulate someone

congratulation.eg: He sent her a note of congratulation on her election victory.

congress.eng_def: a large formal meeting of representatives from countries or societies at which ideas are discussed and information is exchanged
the elected group of politicians in the US who are responsible for making the law, consisting of the Senate and the House of Representatives
congress.eg: Both houses of Congress have rejected the recent presidential proposal on gun control.

congressman.eng_def: a man who belongs to a congress, especially a member of the US House of Representatives
congressman.chi_def: 國會議員；（尤指美國）衆議院議員

congresswoman.eng_def: a woman who belongs to a congress, especially a member of the US House of Representatives
congresswoman.chi_def: 女國會議員；（尤指美國）女衆議院議員

conjunction.eng_def: a word such as 'and', 'but', 'while', or 'although' that connects words, phrases, and clauses in a sentence
the situation in which events or conditions combine or happen together
conjunction.eg: An unfortunate conjunction of circumstances led to his downfall.

conjunction.eng_def: in astrology, the situation in which two planets appear to be in the same part of the sky as seen from earth
conjunction.eg: Mars and Venus will be in exact conjunction on 1 September.

connect.eng_def: to join or be joined with something else
connect.eg: Can I connect my printer to your computer?

connect.eng_def: to consider or show a person or thing to be related to someone or something else
connect.eg: She's an actress I connect with the theatre rather than films.

connect.eng_def: to feel close to someone or have a good relationship with them
connect.eg: She has a remarkable ability to connect with a wide variety of people.

connect.eng_def: to make it possible for you to speak to someone else by phone
connect.eg: Could you connect me with/to a number in Paris, please? I'm not getting through.

connect.eng_def: If two buses, trains, etc. connect, they arrive at times that allow passengers to get off one and onto another.
connect.eg: Your flight arrives at 12.30, when it connects with a bus service to your hotel.

connection.eng_def: the state of being related to someone or something else
connection.eg: The connection between smoking and heart disease is well known.
They want to talk to you in connection with an unpaid tax bill.

connection.eng_def: the act of joining or being joined to something else, or the part or process that makes this possible
connection.eg: The electricity company guarantees connection within 24 hours.

connection.eng_def: the state of being joined or connected in some way
connection.chi_def: （人或事物之間的）聯繫，關聯，關係

connection.eng_def: the people you know and who can help you
connection.chi_def: 社會關係；人際關係；可資利用的熟人
connection.eg: He only got the job because of his connections!

connection.eng_def: the way that two people can speak to each other by phone
connection.eg: Sorry, could you repeat that? This is a very bad connection.

connection.eng_def: a bus, train, plane, etc. that arrives at a time that allows passengers to get on after getting off another one, so that they can continue their journey
connection.chi_def: （供中轉旅客換乘的）接駁交通工具（如公車、火車、飛機等）
connection.eg: If the flight is late, we'll miss our connection.

conquer.eng_def: to take control or possession of foreign land, or a group of people, by force
conquer.eg: The Spanish conquered the New World in the 16th century.

conquer.eng_def: to deal with or successfully fight against a problem or an unreasonable fear
conquer.chi_def: 解決（問題）；戰勝，克服（恐懼）
conquer.eg: He has finally conquered his fear of spiders.

conquest.eng_def: the act of conquering a country, area, or situation
someone you have had sex with but probably not a relationship
conquest.eg: I was determined not to become just another one of his conquests.

conscience.eng_def: the part of you that judges how moral your own actions are and makes you feel guilty about bad things that you have done or things you feel responsible for

conscientious.eng_def: putting a lot of effort into your work
conscientious.chi_def: 認真的；盡心盡責的；一絲不苟的

conscious.eng_def: to notice that a particular thing or person exists or is present
conscious.eg: My tooth doesn't exactly hurt, but I'm conscious of it (= I can feel it) all the time.

conscious.eng_def: awake, thinking, and knowing what is happening around you
conscious.chi_def: 有意識的；神志清醒的；有知覺的
conscious.eg: He's still conscious but he's very badly injured.
He's obviously making a conscious effort to be nice to me at the moment.

conscious.eng_def: used after nouns and adverbs to mean "knowing about and worried about a particular thing", or "thinking that something is important"
conscious.chi_def: （用於名詞或副詞後）有…意識的，看重…的

consensus.eng_def: a generally accepted opinion or decision among a group of people
consensus.eg: The general consensus in the office is that he can't do his job.

consent.eg: They can't publish your name without your consent.

consent.chi_def: 大多數人同意；普遍認可
consent.eg: Her latest novel, by common consent, is her best yet.

consent.eng_def: to agree to do something, or to allow someone to do something
consent.eg: Very reluctantly, I've consented to lend her my car.

consequence.eng_def: a result of a particular action or situation, often one that is bad or not convenient
consequence.chi_def: （常指不好或不利的）結果，後果
consequence.eg: Not making a will can have serious consequences for your children and other family members.

consequence.chi_def: 不重要的；無足輕重的；無關緊要的
consequence.eg: The money was of little consequence to Tony.

consequent.eng_def: happening as a result of something
consequent.chi_def: 作爲結果的；隨之而來的；由此引起的
consequent.eg: Our use of harmful chemicals and the consequent damage to the environment is a very serious matter.

conservation.eng_def: the protection of plants and animals, natural areas, and interesting and important structures and buildings, especially from the damaging effects of human activity
conservation.chi_def: （對動植物、自然地區、歷史建築等的）保育

conservation.eng_def: carefully using valuable natural substances that exist in limited amounts in order to make certain that they will be available for as long a time as possible
conservation.chi_def: （對自然資源等的）保護，保存，節約

conservative.eng_def: not usually liking or trusting change, especially sudden change
If you are conservative in your appearance, you usually do not like fashionable or modern clothes or hairstyles.
conservative.chi_def: （外表上）保守的，傳統的，不趕潮流的
conservative.eg: He's a very conservative dresser - he always looks like he's wearing his father's clothes!

conservative.eng_def: A conservative guess or calculation is likely to be less than the real amount.
conservative.eg: If I said there were three million unemployed, that would be a conservative estimate.

conservative.eng_def: belonging to or supporting the British political party that traditionally supports business and opposes high taxes and government involvement in industry

conserve.eng_def: to keep and protect something from damage, change, or waste
conserve.chi_def: 保護；保藏；保存；保留；節約
conserve.eg: To conserve electricity, we are cutting down on our heating.

conserve.eng_def: a type of jam in which the fruit is whole or in large pieces

consider.eng_def: to spend time thinking about a possibility or making a decision
consider.eg: Don't make any decisions before you've considered the situation.

consider.eng_def: to give attention to a particular subject or fact when judging something else
consider.eg: You've got to consider the time element when planning the whole project.

consider.eng_def: to care about or respect other people or their feelings and wishes
consider.eg: Did you consider your mother and how she's going to feel about you leaving?

consider.eng_def: to believe someone or something to be, or think of him, her, or it as something
consider.eg: He is currently considered (to be) the best British athlete.

consider.chi_def: 受人尊敬；爲人重視；受到高度評價
consider.eg: I don't like her books, but I know she's very highly considered.

considerable.chi_def: 相當大的；相當多的；非常可觀的；相當重要的
considerable.eg: The fire caused considerable damage to the church.

considerate.eg: It wasn't very considerate of you to drink all the milk.

consideration.eng_def: the act of thinking about something carefully
consideration.eg: After some consideration, we've decided to sell the house.

consideration.eng_def: a particular subject or fact that needs to be thought about when judging something
consideration.chi_def: 考慮（或注意）的事（或因素、原因）

consideration.eng_def: behaviour that is kind and considers people's feelings
consideration.eg: You have no consideration for others!
For a small consideration, sir, I'll show you the way there myself.

consistent.eng_def: always behaving or happening in a similar, especially positive, way
consistent.chi_def: 一貫的；堅持的；始終如一的
consistent.eg: There has been a consistent improvement in her attitude.

consistent.eng_def: in agreement with other facts or with typical or previous behaviour, or having the same principles as something else
consistent.eg: What the witness said in court was not consistent with the statement he made to the police.

consolation.eng_def: something that makes someone who is sad or disappointed feel better
consolation.chi_def: 安慰；慰藉；給人帶來安慰的事物
consolation.eg: If it's (of) any consolation (to you), you're not the only one he was nasty to.

console.eng_def: to make someone who is sad or disappointed feel better by giving them comfort or sympathy
console.eg: He tried to console her, but she kept saying it was all her own fault.

console.eng_def: a surface on which you find the controls for a piece of electrical equipment or a machine
console.chi_def: （電子設備或機器的）操縱臺，控制臺，儀表板

consonant.eng_def: one of the speech sounds or letters of the alphabet that is not a vowel. Consonants are pronounced by stopping the air from flowing easily through the mouth, especially by closing the lips or touching the teeth with the tongue.

conspiracy.eng_def: the activity of secretly planning with other people to do something bad or illegal
conspiracy.eg: The three men are accused of conspiracy.

conspiracy.eng_def: a general agreement to keep silent about a subject for the purpose of keeping it secret

constant.eng_def: happening a lot or all the time
constant.chi_def: 經常發生的；連續發生的；連續不斷的
constant.eg: He's in constant trouble with the police.

constant.eng_def: staying the same, or not getting less or more
constant.eg: We ran at a fairly constant speed.

constant.eng_def: A constant companion or friend who is loyal to you.
constant.chi_def: （伴侶或朋友）忠實的，忠貞不渝的，始終如一的

constant.eng_def: a particular number or amount that never changes

constituent.eng_def: one of the parts that a substance or combination is made of
constituent.eg: What are the basic constituents of the mixture?

constituent.eng_def: a voter (= person who can vote) in a particular area of the country
constituent.eg: The MP worked hard, always talking to his constituents and listening to their problems.

constitute.eng_def: to be or be considered as something
constitute.eg: This latest defeat constitutes a major setback for the Democrats.
Women constitute about ten percent of Parliament.

constitution.eng_def: the set of political principles by which a state or organization is governed, especially in relation to the rights of the people it governs
the general state of someone's health
constitution.eg: He has a very strong constitution.

constitution.eng_def: how something is made up of different parts
constitution.eg: the constitution of a chemical compound

constitutional.eng_def: allowed by or contained in a constitution
constitutional.chi_def: 憲法（或章程）允許的，符合憲法（或章程）的
constitutional.eg: Such a policy would not be constitutional.

constitutional.eng_def: relating to someone's general state of health
a walk that you often do to keep yourself healthy
constitutional.eg: She's nearly 86 and still takes a constitutional every morning.

construct.eng_def: to build something or put together different parts to form something whole
an idea or an imaginary situation
construct.eg: His reputation as an eccentric is largely a media construct.

construction.eng_def: the work of building or making something, especially buildings, bridges, etc.
construction.eg: She works in construction/in the construction industry.

construction.eng_def: the particular type of structure, materials, etc. that something has
construction.eg: The bridge is of lightweight construction.
What's that concrete and metal construction over there?

construction.eng_def: the way in which the words in a sentence or phrase are arranged
construction.eg: The writer has used several complex grammatical constructions.

construction.eng_def: to understand something in a particular way
construction.eg: How can they put such a damning construction on a perfectly innocent phrase?

construction.eng_def: to understand something as having a particular meaning, especially other people's actions and statements
construction.eg: I don't want them to put the wrong construction on my actions.

constructive.eng_def: If advice, criticism, or actions are constructive, they are useful and intended to help or improve something.
constructive.chi_def: 建設性的；有益的；有用的；積極的
constructive.eg: She criticized my writing, but in a way that was very constructive.

consult.eng_def: to get information or advice from a person, book, etc. with special knowledge on a particular subject
consult.eg: If the symptoms get worse, consult your doctor.

consult.eng_def: to discuss something with someone before you make a decision
consult.eg: Why didn't you consult me about this?

consultant.eng_def: someone who advises people on a particular subject
a  specialist  (= doctor with special training and knowledge in a particular area of medicine)
consultant.chi_def: 高級顧問醫師；會診醫師；醫學專家

consultation.eng_def: a meeting to discuss something or to get advice
consultation.eg: After consultations with our accountants, we've decided how to cut costs within the company.

consultation.eng_def: the process of discussing something with someone in order to get their advice or opinion about it
consultation.eg: He made the decision in consultation with his parents and teachers.

consume.eng_def: to use fuel, energy, or time, especially in large amounts
consume.eg: Our high living standards cause our current population to consume 25 percent of the world's oil.

consume.eng_def: to eat or drink, especially a lot of something
consume.eg: He consumes huge amounts of bread with every meal.

consume.eng_def: If a fire consumes something, it destroys it completely.
to have so much of a feeling that it affects everything you do

consumer.eng_def: a person who buys goods or services for their own use
consumer.eg: The new rates will affect all consumers, including businesses.

consumption.eg: As a nation, our consumption of junk food is horrifying.

consumption.eng_def: the act of using, eating, or drinking something
consumption.eg: The meat was clearly unfit for human consumption (= not safe for people to eat).

consumption.eng_def: the situation in which information, entertainment, etc. is intended for a particular group of people
consumption.chi_def: （資訊、娛樂等供某類人的）專用
consumption.eg: This memo is for internal consumption only.

consumption.eng_def: old-fashioned for tuberculosis  (= a serious disease of the lungs)

contact.eng_def: communication with someone, especially by speaking or writing to them regularly
contact.chi_def: （尤指經常透過交談、書信的）聯繫，聯絡，交往
contact.eg: "Have you been in contact with Andrew recently?" "Only by phone."

contact.eng_def: the fact of two people or things touching each other
contact.eg: Don't let that glue come into contact with your skin.

contact.eng_def: a person, especially someone in a high position, who can give you useful information or introductions that will help you at work or socially
contact.chi_def: （尤指身居高位，能提供有用資訊或引見的）熟人，（社會）關係
contact.eg: I don't really know how she got the job, but I think her mother has contacts.

contact.eng_def: a part in a circuit that makes the circuit complete when it touches another part
a small round curved piece of transparent plastic, worn on the surface of the eye to improve your sight
a photograph produced by allowing light to pass through the film onto paper that is pressed tightly to it
to communicate with someone by calling or sending them a letter, email, etc.
contact.chi_def: （透過電話或寫電子郵件等）聯繫，聯絡
contact.eg: I tried to contact him at his office, but he wasn't in.

contagious.eng_def: A contagious disease can be caught by touching someone who has the disease or a piece of infected clothing.
contagious.eg: The infection is highly contagious, so don't let anyone else use your towel.

contagious.eng_def: A contagious person has a contagious disease.
contagious.eg: Keep him out of school until he's not contagious anymore.

contagious.eng_def: A contagious feeling spreads quickly among people.

contain.eng_def: to have something inside or include something as a part
contain.eg: How much liquid do you think this bottle contains?

contain.eng_def: to keep something harmful within limits and not allow it to spread
contain.chi_def: 控制，遏制，制止（有害物蔓延）
contain.eg: Farms in the area have been closed off in an attempt to contain the disease.

contain.eng_def: to control or hide a strong emotion, such as excitement or anger
contain.eg: She could no longer contain her anger and started yelling at him.

container.eng_def: a hollow object, such as a box or a bottle, that can be used for holding something, especially to carry or store it
container.chi_def: （尤指用於運輸或儲存的）容器

container.eng_def: a very large metal box used for transporting goods

contaminate.eng_def: to make something less pure or make it poisonous
contaminate.eg: Much of the coast has been contaminated by nuclear waste.

contemplate.eng_def: to spend time considering a possible future action, or to consider one particular thing for a long time in a serious and quiet way
contemplate.eg: I'm contemplating going abroad for a year.

contemplation.eng_def: serious and quiet thought for a period of time
contemplation.eg: She was staring out over the lake, lost in contemplation.

contemporary.eng_def: belonging to the same or a stated period in the past
contemporary.eg: Almost all of the contemporary accounts of the event have been lost.

contemporary.eng_def: someone living during the same period as someone else
contemporary.eg: Was he a contemporary of Shakespeare's?

contemporary.eng_def: a person who is of the same age as you
contemporary.eg: She didn't mix with her contemporaries, preferring the company of older people.

contempt.eng_def: a strong feeling of disliking and having no respect for someone or something
contempt.eg: At school she had complete contempt for all her teachers.

contempt.eng_def: to feel contempt for someone or something
behaviour that is illegal because it does not obey or respect the rules of a law court
contempt.eg: The tobacco companies may be guilty of contempt of court for refusing to produce the documents.

contend.eng_def: to compete in order to win something
contend.eg: There are three world-class tennis players contending for this title.

contend.eng_def: to say that something is true or is a fact
contend.eg: The lawyer contended (that) her client had never been near the scene of the crime.

content.eng_def: pleased with your situation and not hoping for change or improvement
content.eg: He seems fairly content with (his) life.

content.eng_def: the articles or parts contained in a magazine or book, with the number of the page they begin on
content.eg: the table of (= list of) contents

content.eng_def: the ideas that are contained in a piece of writing, a speech, or a film
content.eg: It's a very stylish and beautiful film, but it lacks content.

content.eng_def: everything that is contained within something
content.chi_def: 所含之物；容納的東西；內容
content.eg: The contents of his bag spilled all over the floor.

content.eng_def: the amount of a particular substance contained in something
content.eg: Chocolate has a high fat content.

content.eng_def: to make someone feel happy and satisfied
content.eg: You're quite easily contented, aren't you?

contest.eng_def: a competition to do better than other people, usually in which prizes are given
an attempt, usually against difficulties, to win an election or to get power or control
contest.chi_def: （為贏得選舉或權力而進行的）爭取，爭奪
contest.eg: The contest for the leadership of the party was very bitter.

contest.eng_def: If you contest a formal statement, a claim, a judge's decision, or a legal case, you say formally that it is wrong or unfair and try to have it changed.
contest.eg: We will certainly contest any claims made against the safety of our products.
The medal is being keenly contested by eight gymnasts.

contest.eng_def: to attempt to win an election or to get power or control
contest.chi_def: 爭取，爭奪（選舉勝利或權力）
contest.eg: She could win, since only two people are contesting the seat and the other candidate is very unpopular.

contestant.eng_def: someone who competes in a contest
contestant.eg: In tonight's quiz, our contestants have come from all over the country.

contestant.eng_def: someone who attempts to win an election or get power or control
contestant.eg: Two main candidates are emerging as contestants for the presidency.

context.eng_def: the situation within which something exists or happens, and that can help explain it
context.eg: It is important to see all the fighting and bloodshed in his plays in historical context.

context.eng_def: the text or speech that comes immediately before and after a particular phrase or piece of text and helps to explain its meaning
context.eg: In this exercise, a word is blanked out and you have to guess what it is by looking at the context.

context.eng_def: If words are used out of context, only a small separate part of what was originally said or written is reported, with the result that their meaning is not clear or is not understood.
context.eg: The reporter took my remarks completely out of context.

continent.eng_def: one of the seven large land masses on the earth's surface, surrounded, or mainly surrounded, by sea and usually consisting of various countries
able to control when you urinate and empty your bowels
able to control your sexual desires
Europe, especially western Europe, but not including the British Isles
continent.chi_def: 歐洲大陸；（尤指不包括不列顛群島的）西歐
continent.eg: Driving on the Continent is very different to driving in Britain.

continent.eng_def: someone who comes from Europe but not the British Isles

continental.eng_def: one of the seven large land masses on the earth's surface, surrounded, or mainly surrounded, by sea and usually consisting of various countries
able to control when you urinate and empty your bowels
able to control your sexual desires
Europe, especially western Europe, but not including the British Isles
continental.chi_def: 歐洲大陸；（尤指不包括不列顛群島的）西歐
continental.eg: Driving on the Continent is very different to driving in Britain.

continental.eng_def: someone who comes from Europe but not the British Isles

continual.eng_def: happening repeatedly, usually in an annoying or not convenient way
continual.chi_def: （通常指令人討厭或引起不便地）頻頻的，頻繁的，再三的
continual.eg: I've had continual problems with this car ever since I bought it.

continue.eng_def: to keep happening, existing, or doing something, or to cause something or someone to do this
continue.eg: It's said that as the boat went down the band continued to play.

continue.eng_def: to start to do something again after a pause
continue.eg: After stopping for a quick drink, they continued on their way.

continuity.eng_def: the fact of something continuing for a long period of time without being changed or stopped
continuity.eg: There has been no continuity in that class - they've had six different teachers.

continuity.eng_def: the way in which different parts of a film or television programme are joined together so that the action happens without any pause or change
continuity.chi_def: （電影、電視的）場景串聯，節目串聯，銜接

contract.eng_def: a legal document that states and explains a formal agreement between two different people or groups, or the agreement itself
to have formally agreed to work for a company or person on a stated job for a stated period of time
contract.chi_def: 簽訂合同（為某公司或某人工作）；有合同約束

contract.eng_def: to make or become shorter or narrower or generally smaller in size
contract.eg: In spoken English, "do not" often contracts to "don't".

contract.eng_def: to catch or become ill with a disease
contract.eg: He contracted malaria while he was travelling.

contract.eng_def: to make a legal agreement with someone to do work or to have work done for you
contract.eg: Our company was contracted to build shelters for the homeless.

contractor.eng_def: a person or company that arranges to supply materials or workers for building or for moving goods
contractor.chi_def: 承辦人；承辦商；承包方；訂約人

contradict.eng_def: (of people) to say the opposite of what someone else has said, or (of one fact or statement) to be so different from another fact or statement that one of them must be wrong
contradict.chi_def: 反駁，否定；（事實或聲明）（與…）相矛盾，（與…）有抵觸
contradict.eg: If you're both going to lie, at least stick to the same story and don't contradict each other!

contradiction.eng_def: the fact of something being the complete opposite of something else or very different from something else, so that one of them must be wrong
contradiction.eg: You say that you're good friends and yet you don't trust him. Isn't that a contradiction?

contradiction.eng_def: a combination of words that is nonsense because some of the words suggest the opposite of some of the others
contradiction.eg: Many people think that an honest politician is a contradiction in terms.

contrary.chi_def: 相反；反面；對立面；相反事物
contrary.eg: I was worried that it might be too hard for me but it turned out the contrary was true.

contrary.eng_def: used to show that you think or feel the opposite of what has just been stated
contrary.eg: "I thought you said the film was exciting?" "On the contrary, I nearly fell asleep half way through it!"
For a long time it was thought to be a harmless substance, but we now have proof/evidence to the contrary.

contrary.chi_def: 相反的，對立的；完全不同的

contrary.eng_def: in a different way from what most people believe
contrary.chi_def: 與大多數人的看法不同
contrary.eg: Contrary to popular opinion, I don't dye my hair!

contrary.eng_def: A contrary person wants to disagree with and annoy other people.
contrary.chi_def: 乖戾的；故意作對的；執拗的
contrary.eg: He doesn't really mean it - he's just being contrary.

contrast.eng_def: an obvious difference between two or more things
contrast.eg: I like the contrast of the white trousers with the black jacket.

contrast.eng_def: to compare two people or things in order to show the differences between them
contrast.eg: If you contrast some of her early writing with her later work, you can see just how much she improved.

contrast.eng_def: If one thing contrasts with another, it is very different from it.
contrast.chi_def: 形成對照；顯出明顯的差異
contrast.eg: The styles of the two film makers contrast quite dramatically.

contribute.eng_def: to give something, especially money, in order to provide or achieve something together with other people
contribute.eg: Aren't you going to contribute towards Jack's leaving present?

contribute.eng_def: to write articles for a newspaper, magazine, or book

contribution.eng_def: something that you contribute or do to help produce or achieve something together with other people, or to help make something successful
contribution.chi_def: 貢獻，奉獻；捐款；捐助（物）；投稿
contribution.eg: All contributions (= presents of money), no matter how small, will be much appreciated.

control.eng_def: to order, limit, or rule something, or someone's actions or behaviour
control.eg: If you can't control your dog, put it on a lead!

control.eng_def: the act of controlling something or someone, or the power to do this
control.chi_def: 掌握；控制（權）；克制（力）；支配（權）
control.eg: She doesn't have any control over that child - it's embarrassing.

control.eng_def: being dealt with or limited successfully
control.eg: It seems that the disease is now under control.

control.eng_def: a switch or other device used to operate a machine such as a vehicle
control.eg: The main instruments are in the centre of the control panel.

control.eng_def: a key on a computer keyboard that you press at the same time as other keys to make the keyboard operate in a particular way
control.eg: Press and hold down the control key while you press 9.

control.eng_def: in an experiment, an object or system that is not changed so that you can compare it with similar objects or systems that are intentionally changed

controller.eng_def: a person who controls something, or someone who is responsible for what a particular organization does

controversy.eng_def: a lot of disagreement or argument about something, usually because it affects or is important to many people
controversy.eg: There was a big controversy surrounding/over the use of drugs in athletics.

convenience.eg: I like the convenience of living close to work.
The goods will be delivered at your convenience.

convenience.eng_def: as soon as you like or can
convenience.eg: Please return the completed form at your earliest convenience.

convenience.eng_def: a device or machine, usually in the house, that operates quickly and needs little effort
convenience.chi_def: （通常指房子裡的）便利設施；方便裝置
convenience.eg: The house has every modern convenience.

convenient.eng_def: suitable for your purposes and needs and causing the least difficulty
convenient.eg: Our local shop has very convenient opening hours.

convenient.eng_def: near or easy to get to or use
convenient.chi_def: 近的；容易得到的；好用的

convention.eng_def: a large formal meeting of people who do a particular job or have a similar interest, or a large meeting for a political party
a usual or accepted way of behaving, especially in social situations, often following an old way of thinking or a custom in one particular society
convention.chi_def: 傳統；（尤指社會）習俗，常規，慣例
convention.eg: They defied/flouted/broke with convention by giving up their jobs and becoming self-sufficient.

convention.eng_def: a common way of showing something in art or writing
a formal agreement between country leaders, politicians, and states on a matter that involves them all

conventional.eng_def: used to refer to weapons that are not nuclear, or to methods of fighting a war that do not involve nuclear weapons

conversation.eng_def: (a) talk between two or more people in which thoughts, feelings, and ideas are expressed, questions are asked and answered, or news and information is exchanged
conversation.eg: She had a strange conversation with the man who moved in upstairs.

converse.eg: In the US, you drive on the right-hand side of the road, but in the UK the converse applies.

converse.eng_def: to have a conversation with someone
converse.eg: She's so shy that conversing with her can be pretty hard.

convert.eng_def: to (cause something or someone to) change in form or character
convert.chi_def: （使）改變，（使）轉變；（使）改信；（使）皈依
convert.eg: Could we convert the small bedroom into a second bathroom?

convert.eng_def: to change to a new religion, belief, opinion, etc., or to make someone do this
convert.chi_def: 改變信仰（或態度）；歸附，皈依
convert.eg: He converted to (= started believing in) Catholicism when he got married.

convert.eng_def: in sport , to score extra points such as a conversion, free throw, or penalty shot
someone who changes their beliefs, habits, or way of living
convert.chi_def: 改變信仰（或習慣、生活方式）的人

convey.eng_def: to express a thought, feeling, or idea so that it is understood by other people
convey.chi_def: 表達，傳達（思想、感情或想法）
convey.eg: His poetry conveys a great sense of religious devotion.

convey.eng_def: to take or carry someone or something to a particular place
convey.eg: The goods are usually conveyed by rail.

convict.eng_def: to decide officially in a law court that someone is guilty of a crime
convict.chi_def: （在法庭上）宣判…有罪，證明…有罪
convict.eg: He has twice been convicted of robbery/arson.

convict.eng_def: someone who is in prison because they are guilty of a crime
convict.chi_def: 已決犯，既決犯；（服刑中的）囚犯

conviction.eng_def: the fact of officially being found to be guilty of a particular crime, or the act of officially finding someone guilty
conviction.eg: Since it was her first conviction for stealing, she was given a less severe sentence.

conviction.chi_def: 堅定的看法；堅定的信念；堅定的信仰

conviction.eng_def: a feeling of being certain about something
conviction.eg: He said he was enjoying his new job, but his voice lacked conviction.

convince.eng_def: to persuade someone or make someone certain
convince.eg: He managed to convince the jury of his innocence.

cook.eng_def: When you cook food, you prepare it to be eaten by heating it in a particular way, such as baking or boiling, and when food cooks, it is heated until it is ready to eat.
cook.eg: I don't cook meat very often.

cook.eng_def: someone who prepares and cooks food

cooker.eng_def: a large box-shaped device that is used to cook and heat food, either by putting the food inside or by putting it on the top

cooker.chi_def: 烹飪用的蘋果（一種大蘋果，味很酸）（同 cooking apple）

cookie.eng_def: a small, flat, sweet food made from flour and sugar
a person of the type mentioned
a piece of information stored on your computer about internet documents that you have looked at
cookie.chi_def: 「甜餅」記憶塊，魔塊，網路跟蹤器（記錄上網用戶資訊的文件）

cool.eng_def: slightly cold in a pleasant way
cool.eg: It was a lovely cool evening.

cool.eng_def: used to describe a temperature that is slightly too cold
cool.eg: It's a bit cool in here, isn't it? I think I'll close the window.

cool.eng_def: calm and not worried or frightened; not influenced by strong feeling of any kind
cool.eg: He was very cool when we broke the window, and didn't shout or get mad.

cool.eng_def: to be happy to accept a situation or suggestion
cool.chi_def: 樂於接受（某一情況或建議）
cool.eg: Yeah, we could leave later - I'm cool with that.

cool.eng_def: Cool colours, such as blue or green, make you feel calm and relaxed.
cool.chi_def: （顔色）冷色調的，給人涼爽感覺的
cool.eg: The bedroom was painted a lovely cool blue.

cool.eng_def: unfriendly or not showing kindness or interest in something or someone
cool.chi_def: 不友好的；冷淡的；冷漠的
cool.eg: She was decidedly cool towards me.
Angie's got some cool new sunglasses.

cool.chi_def: 好極了（的），棒極了（的），頂呱呱（的）
cool.eg: "So how was the concert?" "It was cool!"

cool.eng_def: the pleasant, slightly cold temperature of a place
cool.eg: He loved the cool of the early morning.

cool.eng_def: a person's ability to stay calm and not become angry or excited
to become or cause something to become slightly colder
cool.eg: Leave the cake to cool for an hour before cutting it.

cool.eng_def: If a feeling cools or cools off, it starts to become less strong.
cool.chi_def: （感情）冷靜下來，平靜下來，冷淡下來
cool.eg: They were completely in love in the beginning, but I think it's starting to cool off now.

cool.eng_def: If the economy, a business, etc. cools or cools off, it grows less fast than before.
cool.eg: The stock market has cooled off after hitting new highs last week.

cooperate.eng_def: to act or work together for a particular purpose, or to be helpful by doing what someone asks you to do
cooperate.eg: A two-year old is likely to refuse to cooperate when you tell her to get dressed.

cooperation.eng_def: the act of working together with someone or doing what they ask you
cooperation.eg: This documentary was made with the cooperation of the victims' families.

cooperative.eng_def: willing to help or do what people ask
cooperative.chi_def: 樂於合作的；協作的；配合的
cooperative.eg: I asked them to turn down their music, but they're not being very cooperative.

cooperative.eng_def: a company that is owned and managed by the people who work in it
cooperative.eg: The magazine is run as a cooperative.

coordinate.eng_def: to make many different things work effectively as a whole
coordinate.eg: We need someone to coordinate the whole campaign.

coordinate.eng_def: to match or look attractive together
coordinate.eg: The bed linen coordinates with the bedroom curtains.

coordinate.eng_def: one of a pair of numbers and/or letters that show the exact position of a point on a map or graph
clothes, especially for women, that are made in matching colours or styles so that they can be worn together
coordinate.chi_def: （尤指顔色、樣式協調的女性）配套服裝，套裝

cop.eg: Quick, run - there's a cop coming!
His last book wasn't much cop.

cop.eng_def: →  it's a fair cop UK informal

cover.eg: This leaflet covers what we've just discussed in more detail.

cover.eng_def: to report the news about a particular important event
cover.eg: She's covering the American election for BBC television.

cover.eng_def: to protect someone against loss, damage, accident, or having something stolen, by having insurance
cover.eg: Does your travel insurance cover you against/for the loss or theft of cash?

cover.eng_def: to do something to protect yourself from blame or criticism in the future
cover.chi_def: 採取措施保護自己（不在未來因此受到責怪或批評）
cover.eg: I kept copies of my expense receipts, just to cover myself.

cover.eng_def: to travel a particular distance
cover.eg: We covered 400 km in three hours.

cover.eng_def: to be enough money to pay for something
cover.eg: The selling price barely covered the cost of the raw materials.

cover.eng_def: to aim a gun or shoot at someone to try to stop them from shooting or escaping, or to protect someone else
cover.chi_def: 以槍瞄準（以防射擊或逃跑）；（用槍炮）掩護
cover.eg: The police officer was covered by her colleagues while she ran towards the gunman's hideout.

cover.eng_def: When soldiers or police officers cover a place such as a road or building, they are in a position from which they can watch and defend it.
cover.chi_def: 守住；封鎖（道路、建築物等）
cover.eg: All the exits are covered, so they can't escape.

cover.eng_def: to prevent a member of the opposing team from taking control of the ball by staying close to them all the time
to do someone else's job or duty when they are absent
cover.chi_def: 代替，頂替（某人的工作或職責）
cover.eg: I'm going to the doctor's tomorrow, so do you think you could cover my shift for me?

cover.eng_def: to make a recording of a song or tune that has already been recorded by someone else
cover.eg: I think more singers have covered "Yesterday" than any other song.

cover.eng_def: something that is put on or over something else, usually to protect it, to keep something in, etc.
cover.chi_def: 蓋子；罩子；遮蓋物；覆蓋物
cover.eg: I keep my computer printer under a protective plastic cover.

cover.eng_def: the stiff outside part of a book or magazine, usually made of thick paper or cardboard
cover.eg: Who should we put on the cover of the magazine this month?

cover.eng_def: to read a book, magazine, etc. all the way through from the beginning to the end
an envelope
to send something in a plain/separate envelope
the blankets, sheets, etc. on a bed
cover.eg: Martha threw back the covers and bounced out of bed.

cover.eng_def: shelter or protection in an unpleasant or dangerous situation
cover.eg: We took cover from the storm in a bus shelter.

cover.eng_def: plants, especially bushes, that are used as shelter by animals
cover.chi_def: （尤指動物藏身的）覆蓋植物，灌木叢

cover.eng_def: protection by someone who has a gun
cover.chi_def: （持槍者為另一人所作的）掩護；保護
cover.eg: We needed more cover from the enemy aircraft.

cover.eng_def: financial protection so that you get money if something bad happens
cover.eg: I've got £20,000 worth of cover for the contents of my house.

cover.eng_def: a performance or recording of a song or tune that has already been recorded by someone else
cover.eg: How many cover versions have been made of "My Way"?

coverage.eng_def: the reporting of a particular important event or subject
coverage.eg: What did you think of the BBC's election coverage?
