coverage.eng_def: the fact of dealing with or directing attention to something
coverage.eg: These books give very good grammar coverage (= they deal with grammar very well).

coverage.eng_def: financial protection so that you get money if something bad happens
coverage.eg: They have a national program that provides health/medical coverage for every citizen.

covet.eng_def: to want to have something very much, especially something that belongs to someone else
covet.chi_def: 覬覦，垂涎（尤指他人之物）；貪求，渴望
covet.eg: She always coveted power but never quite achieved it.

cow.eng_def: a large female farm animal kept to produce meat and milk
a large female adult mammal such as an elephant, a whale, or a seal

cow.eg: It's been a cow of a day.

cow.eng_def: to frighten someone into doing something, using threats or violence
cow.chi_def: （以威脅或暴力）使害怕，嚇唬，恐嚇
cow.eg: The protesters refused to be cowed into submission by the army.

coward.eng_def: a person who is not brave and is too eager to avoid danger, difficulty, or pain
coward.eg: They branded her a coward for informing on her colleagues during the interrogation.

cowboy.eng_def: a person, especially in the western US, whose job is to take care of cattle, and who usually rides a horse, or a similar character in a film
cowboy.eg: The ranch employed ten or twelve cowboys.

cowboy.eng_def: someone who is not honest, careful, or skilful in their trade or business, or someone who ignores rules that most people obey and is therefore not considered to be responsible
cowboy.chi_def: 弄虛作假的商人；粗心大意的人；不負責任的人，莽撞鬼
cowboy.eg: Those builders are a bunch of cowboys - they made a terrible job of our extension.

crab.eng_def: a sea creature with five pairs of legs and a round, flat body covered by a shell, or its flesh eaten as food
crab.eg: We walked along the beach collecting small crabs.

crab.eng_def: small insects that can live in the hair around the sex organs
the sign of the zodiac  Cancer

crack.eng_def: to break something so that it does not separate, but very thin lines appear on its surface, or to become broken in this way
crack.eg: A stone hit the window and cracked the glass.

crack.eng_def: to become mentally and physically weak
crack.eg: Stress and overwork are causing teachers to crack (up).

crack.eng_def: to fail as a result of problems
crack.chi_def: 出現隔閡，出現問題；失敗
crack.eg: Their relationship began to crack (up) after their child died.

crack.eng_def: If someone cracks, that person begins to feel weak and agrees that they have been defeated.
crack.eg: He cracked during questioning and told us where to find the stolen goods.

crack.eng_def: to break something open, especially in order to reach or use what is inside
crack.chi_def: （尤指爲得到或使用內部的東西而）使破裂，打開，砸開
crack.eg: Crack three eggs into a bowl and mix them together.

crack.eng_def: to get into someone else's computer system without permission and get information or do something illegal
to copy computer programs or recorded material illegally
crack.chi_def: 非法複製（電腦程式或資料）

crack.eng_def: to find a solution to a problem
crack.eg: They cracked the code and read the secret message.

crack.eng_def: to hit something or someone
crack.eg: I cracked my head on/against the door.

crack.eng_def: to make a sudden, short noise, or to cause something to make this noise
crack.eg: The whip cracked over the horses' heads.

crack.eng_def: If a voice cracks, its sound changes because the person is upset.
crack.eg: Her voice cracked with emotion as she told the story.

crack.eng_def: to make a joke or funny remark
crack.chi_def: 說俏皮話；開玩笑；說笑話

crack.eng_def: a very narrow space between parts of something
crack.eg: Cracks had appeared in the dry ground.

crack.eng_def: so that there is a very small space
crack.eg: She opened the door just a crack to listen to the conversation.

crack.eng_def: a sudden loud sound
crack.eg: the crack of a rifle/whip/breaking branch

crack.eng_def: an attempt
crack.eg: It was her first crack at beating the record.

crack.eng_def: a powerful form of the drug cocaine
crack.eg: Several kilos of crack were found in her luggage.

crack.eng_def: →  craic Irish English
crack.chi_def: 愉快時光；（尤指）令人快樂的交談

crack.eng_def: a method of getting into someone else's computer system
crack.chi_def: 非法侵入（電腦系統）的方法
crack.eg: Find cracks for your shareware programs.

crack.eng_def: a  wisecrack informal
crack.chi_def: （尤指用來批評的）妙語，俏皮話

crack.eng_def: excellent, or of the highest quality
crack.chi_def: 優秀的；頂呱呱的；第一流的

cracker.eng_def: a thin, flat, hard biscuit, especially one eaten with cheese
cracker.chi_def: （尤指與起司一起食用的）薄脆餅乾

cracker.eng_def: a paper tube with small toys, small pieces of sweet food, etc. inside, that is covered with bright paper and makes a short, sharp sound when both ends are pulled
cracker.chi_def: 彩包爆竹，彩色拉炮（裝有小玩具、糖果等的彩紙筒，抓著兩端拉開時會劈啪作響）
cracker.eg: Who wants to pull a cracker with me?

cracker.eng_def: a firework that explodes with a loud noise
a person or thing that is very good or has a special exciting quality
cracker.chi_def: 出色的人（或物），頂呱呱的人（或物）
cracker.eg: She's written five books, and every one is a cracker.

cradle.eng_def: a small bed for a baby, especially one that moves from side to side
the object that you put a phone, camera, etc. into in order to recharge (= put power into) its batteries
cradle.chi_def: （行動電話、相機、掌上型電腦等的）傳輸座（用來充電或把設備與電腦相連）

cradle.eng_def: a frame that hangs on the side of a building, ship, etc. for people to work from
cradle.chi_def: （懸掛在建築物、船等側面供工作用的）腳手架，吊架，吊籃

cradle.eng_def: to hold something or someone gently, especially by supporting with the arms
cradle.eg: She cradled him tenderly in her arms.

craft.eng_def: skill and experience, especially in relation to making objects; a job or activity that needs skill and experience, or something produced using skill and experience
craft.chi_def: （尤指製作東西的）工藝，手藝；技術

craft.eng_def: a vehicle for travelling on water or through the air
to make objects, especially in a skilled way
craft.eg: These bracelets were crafted by Native Americans.

cram.eng_def: to force a lot of things into a small space
cram.eg: Eight children were crammed into the back of the car.

cram.eng_def: to do many things in a short period of time
cram.eg: I had to cram three countries into a week's business trip.

cram.eng_def: to try to learn a lot very quickly before an exam
cram.eg: She's cramming for her history exam.

cramp.eng_def: a sudden painful tightening in a muscle, often after a lot of exercise, that limits movement
cramp.chi_def: 痙攣，抽筋（常出現在大量運動後）
cramp.eg: Several runners needed treatment for cramp (US cramps) and exhaustion.

cramp.eng_def: pains in the lower stomach caused by a woman's period
to limit someone, especially to prevent them from enjoying a full life
cramp.eg: Worry and lack of money cramp the lives of the unemployed.

crane.eng_def: a tall metal structure with a long horizontal part, used for lifting and moving heavy objects
crane.eg: The crane lifted the container off the ship.

crane.eng_def: a tall bird with long, thin legs and a long neck
to stretch in order to look at something
crane.eg: He craned forward to see the procession.

crash.eng_def: If a vehicle crashes or someone crashes it, it is involved in an accident, usually a serious one in which the vehicle is damaged and someone is hurt.
crash.eg: We skidded on the ice and crashed.

crash.eng_def: to hit something, often making a loud noise or causing damage
crash.chi_def: （使）猛撞（常發出巨大聲響或造成破壞）
crash.eg: We could hear waves crashing on/against the shore.

crash.eng_def: If something such as a business crashes, it suddenly fails or becomes unsuccessful.
crash.eg: Investors were seriously worried when the stock market began to crash.

crash.eng_def: If a computer or system crashes, it suddenly stops operating.
to sleep at someone else's house for the night, especially when you have not planned it
crash.chi_def: （尤指事先無計劃而留在別人家裡）過夜，睡覺
crash.eg: They crashed on my floor after the party.

crash.eng_def: to go to a party or other event without an invitation
crash.eg: We tried to crash the party, but the bouncers wouldn't let us in.

crash.eng_def: an accident involving a vehicle, usually a serious one in which the vehicle is damaged or someone is hurt
a sudden loud noise made when something breaks or falls
crash.chi_def: （物體破裂或掉落時發出的）哢嚓聲，嘩啦聲
crash.eg: I heard a loud crash in the kitchen.

crash.eng_def: a sudden large fall in the value of a country's businesses
crash.eg: They lost a lot of money in the Stock Market crash.

crash.eng_def: a situation when a computer or system suddenly stops operating
crash.chi_def: （電腦或系統的）突然癱瘓，死機

crash.eng_def: quick and involving a lot of effort
crash.chi_def: 迅速全面的；速成的；應急的
crash.eg: The company undertook a crash programme of machine replacement.

crater.eng_def: the round hole at the top of a volcano, or a hole in the ground similar to this

crawl.eng_def: to move slowly or with difficulty, especially with your body stretched out along the ground or on hands and knees
crawl.chi_def: 緩慢移動；艱難前行；爬行；匍匐前進
crawl.eg: The child crawled across the floor.

crawl.eng_def: to try hard to please in order to get an advantage
crawl.chi_def: 巴結，討好；阿諛奉承；卑躬屈膝
crawl.eg: I don't like people who crawl.

crawl.eng_def: to be completely covered with or full of a particular type of thing
crawl.eg: After the bomb scare, the airport was crawling with police.

crawl.eng_def: a style of swimming in which you move your arms over your head and kick with straight legs

crawl.eg: Traffic moved forward at a crawl.

crayon.eng_def: a small stick of coloured wax used for drawing or writing
to draw something with a crayon
crayon.eg: When I left her she was busy crayoning.

crazy.chi_def: 精神失常的，瘋狂的，發瘋的
crazy.eg: I seriously think she'll go crazy if she doesn't have a holiday soon.
The constant noise drove me crazy (= made me become angry).

creak.eng_def: When a door, floorboard, etc. creaks, it makes a long low sound when it moves or is moved.
creak.eg: The door creaked on its hinges.

creak.eng_def: a noise made when something creaks
creak.eg: I heard a creak on the stairs.

cream.eng_def: the thick, yellowish-white liquid that forms on the top of milk
a soft substance that you rub into your skin
a type of sweet that is soft inside
a thick liquid used for cleaning things
soup that has been made into a smooth thick liquid and usually has cream in it

cream.chi_def: 奶油色的，淡黃色的，米黃色的

cream.eng_def: to make food into a smooth, thick liquid
cream.eg: Cream the butter and sugar together.

create.eng_def: to make something new, or invent something
create.eg: Charles Schulz created the characters "Snoopy" and "Charlie Brown".

create.eng_def: to show that you are angry
create.eg: If she sees you with an ice cream she'll only start creating.

creation.eng_def: the act of creating something, or the thing that is created
creation.chi_def: 創造；創立；産生；創造物，作品
creation.eg: the creation of a new political party

creation.eng_def: in the Bible, the making of the world by God
creation.chi_def: 《聖經》中上帝的創世，創造天地

creative.eng_def: producing or using original and unusual ideas
creative.chi_def: 有創造力的；創造性的；有創意的

creative.eng_def: a person whose job involves producing original ideas or doing artistic work
creative.chi_def: 有創造力的員工；創意人員
creative.eg: Several leading creatives are involved in the advertising campaign.

creator.eg: He's the creator of a successful cartoon series.

creature.eng_def: any large or small living thing that can move independently
creature.eg: Rainforests are filled with amazing creatures.

creature.eng_def: used to refer to a life form that is unusual or imaginary
creature.chi_def: （神秘不尋常的）怪物，生物；（想像出來的）生物
creature.eg: The unicorn is a mythical creature.

creature.eng_def: used to refer to a person when an opinion is being expressed about them

credibility.eng_def: the fact that someone can be believed or trusted
credibility.eg: His arrest for lewd behaviour seriously damaged his credibility as a religious leader.

credible.eng_def: able to be believed or trusted
credible.eg: They haven't produced any credible evidence for convicting him.

credit.eg: She got no credit for solving the problem.

credit.eng_def: to do something that makes a person, group, or organization feel proud or receive praise
credit.eg: She is a credit to her family.

credit.eng_def: to cause someone who has been or is responsible for you to receive praise by your good behaviour or successful actions
credit.chi_def: 為家庭（父母，老師等）增光

credit.eng_def: used to show that you think a person deserves a lot of praise for something that they have done
credit.eg: All credit to her, she did it all herself.

credit.eng_def: a method of paying for goods or services at a later time, usually paying interest as well as the original money
credit.eg: They decided to buy the car on credit.
I was relieved to see from my statement that my account was in credit.

credit.eng_def: a unit that represents a successfully finished part of an educational course
credit.eg: Each of these classes is worth three credits.

credit.eng_def: a list of people who helped to make a film or a television or radio programme, that is shown or announced at the beginning or the end of it
credit.chi_def: （電影、電視或廣播節目的）演職人員名單

credit.eng_def: to pay money into a bank account
credit.eg: They credited my account with $20 after I pointed out the mistake.

credit.eng_def: to believe something that seems unlikely to be true
credit.chi_def: 信任，相信（不大可能的事）
credit.eg: He even tried to pretend he was my son - can you credit it?

creek.eng_def: a narrow area of water that flows into the land from the sea, a lake, etc.

creep.eng_def: to move slowly, quietly, and carefully, usually in order to avoid being noticed
creep.chi_def: （通常指爲避免注意而）緩慢行進，悄悄移動，潛行
creep.eg: She turned off the light and crept through the door.

creep.eng_def: someone who tries to make someone more important like them by being very polite and helpful in a way that is not sincere
creep.chi_def: 諂媚者，奴顔婢膝者，阿諛奉承者
creep.eg: Making coffee for the boss again? You creep!

creep.eng_def: an unpleasant person, especially a man
creep.chi_def: 討厭鬼，令人噁心的人（尤指男人）
creep.eg: He was such a creep - he was always staring at me in the canteen.

creep.eng_def: to cause someone to have uncomfortable feelings of nervousness or fear
creep.chi_def: 使…毛骨悚然；使…緊張害怕
creep.eg: Living next to a graveyard would give me the creeps.

crew.eng_def: a group of people who work together, especially all those who work on and operate a ship, aircraft, etc.
crew.chi_def: 全體工作人員；（尤指）全體船員，全體機組人員，全體乘務人員

crew.eng_def: the people who work on a ship, aircraft, etc. who are not officers
crew.chi_def: （除官員之外的）全體船員；全體機組人員，乘務員
crew.eg: Apart from the ten officers, a crew of 90 takes care of the 300 passengers.

crew.eng_def: If you crew a boat, or crew for someone on their boat, you help to sail it.

crib.eng_def: a small bed for a baby or young child with high bars around the sides so that the child cannot fall out
a model of the people and animals present at the birth of Jesus Christ, used as a decoration at Christmas
crib.chi_def: 耶穌誕生塑像（用作聖誕節裝飾）

crib.eng_def: Someone's crib is their home or the place where they are living at present.
to copy or take someone else's work
crib.eg: I sometimes wonder what TV show he cribbed that line from.

cricket.eng_def: a sport in which two teams of eleven players try to score runs (= points) by hitting a small, hard ball with a bat, and running between two sets of small wooden posts
a brown or black insect that makes short, loud noises by rubbing its wings together

crime.eg: He has admitted committing several crimes, including fraud.

crime.eng_def: an unacceptable or very silly act or situation
crime.chi_def: 不能接受的行為；愚蠢的做法
crime.eg: To have hundreds of homeless people sleeping in the streets of a rich city like London is a crime .

criminal.eg: It's criminal to charge so much for a book.

cripple.eng_def: a person who cannot use their arms or legs in a normal way
someone who finds it difficult to have or express feelings
cripple.chi_def: 感情殘廢者，感情有缺陷的人

cripple.eng_def: to injure someone so that they are unable to walk or move in a normal way
to cause serious damage to someone or something, making him, her, or it weak and not effective
Someone who is crippled has serious injuries that affect their ability to walk or move.
cripple.eg: Will she be crippled for life?

cripple.eng_def: Something that is crippling causes someone serious injuries or harm.
cripple.chi_def: 嚴重的；造成嚴重傷害的
cripple.eg: A crippling attack of malaria kept him in bed for months.

crisis.eng_def: a time of great disagreement, confusion, or suffering
crisis.eg: The country's leadership is in crisis.

crisis.eng_def: an extremely difficult or dangerous point in a situation
a moment during a serious illness when there is the possibility of suddenly getting either better or worse
crisis.eg: He's passed the crisis - the fever's started to go down.
With inflation at 500 percent, the country faces a crisis of confidence.

crisp.eng_def: hard enough to be broken easily
used to describe cooked foods, such as pastry and biscuits, that are well cooked so that they are just dry and hard enough
Crisp fruit or vegetables are fresh and firm.
Crisp paper or cloth is stiff and smooth.
crisp.eg: a crisp new £5 note/a crisp white tablecloth

crisp.eng_def: A crisp sound or image is very clear.
crisp.eg: The sound from the new speakers is very crisp.

crisp.eng_def: A crisp way of speaking, writing, or behaving is quick, confident, and effective.
crisp.chi_def: （說話、寫作或行爲）乾脆俐落的，利索的，明快的

crisp.eng_def: Crisp weather is cold, dry, and bright.
Crisp air is cold, dry, and fresh.
crisp.eg: I breathed in deeply the crisp mountain air.

crisp.eng_def: a very thin, often round piece of fried potato, sometimes with a flavour added, sold especially in plastic bags
crisp.eg: a packet of salt and vinegar crisps

crisp.eng_def: a sweet dish made from fruit covered in a mixture of flour, butter, and sugar rubbed together into small pieces, baked, and eaten hot

crispy.eng_def: Crispy food is hard enough to be broken easily.

criterion.eng_def: a standard by which you judge, decide about, or deal with something
criterion.chi_def: （作出評判、決定或處理的）標準，準則
criterion.eg: The Health Service should not be judged by financial criteria alone.

critic.eng_def: someone who says that they do not approve of someone or something
critic.eg: Her critics say she is leading the party to disaster.

critic.eng_def: someone whose job is to give their opinion about something, especially films, books, music, etc.
critic.chi_def: （尤指電影、書籍、音樂等的）批評家，評論家
critic.eg: She's a film/theatre critic for the "Irish Times".

critical.eng_def: saying that someone or something is bad or wrong
critical.chi_def: 批評的；批判的；挑剔的；謹嚴的

critical.eng_def: of the greatest importance to the way things might happen
critical.chi_def: 關鍵性的；決定性的；至關重要的
critical.eg: The president's support is critical (to this project).

critical.eng_def: giving opinions or judgments on books, plays, films, etc.
critical.eg: She has written a major critical appraisal/study of Saul Bellow's novels.
Both drivers are critical/in a critical condition (= so badly hurt that they might die) after the 120 mph crash.

criticism.eng_def: the act of saying that something or someone is bad
criticism.eg: The designs for the new mosque have attracted widespread criticism.

criticism.eng_def: the act of giving your opinion or judgment about the good or bad qualities of something or someone, especially books, films, etc.
criticism.chi_def: （尤指對書、電影等的）評論，評價

criticize.eng_def: to express disapproval of someone or something
criticize.eg: The government is being widely criticized in the media for failing to limit air pollution.

criticize.eng_def: to give an opinion or judgment about a book, film, etc.
criticize.eg: We're a group of artists who meet to discuss ideas and criticize each other's work.

crocodile.eng_def: a large reptile with a hard skin that lives in and near rivers and lakes in hot, wet parts of the world. It is like an alligator, but it usually has a longer and narrower nose
a line of people, especially children, who are walking in pairs
crocodile.chi_def: 兩人一排成縱隊行走的人（尤指兒童）

crook.eng_def: a very dishonest person, especially a criminal or a cheat
crook.eg: These politicians are just a bunch of crooks.

crook.eng_def: the inside part of your arm where it bends
a long stick with a curved end, especially one carried by a shepherd or a bishop
crook.chi_def: （尤指牧羊人或主教用的）曲柄手杖

crook.eg: I'm a bit crook at the moment.

crook.eng_def: to bend your arm or finger
crook.eg: She delicately crooked her little finger as she picked up her cup.

crooked.eng_def: not forming a straight line, or having many bends
crooked.eg: You have to drive slowly on these crooked country roads.

crop.eng_def: (the total amount collected of) a plant such as a grain, fruit, or vegetable grown in large amounts
crop.eg: The main crops grown for export are coffee and rice.

crop.eng_def: a group of people or things with something in common, that exist at a particular time
crop.chi_def: （同時湧現的）一批，一幫（人或事物）
crop.eg: The judges will select the best from this year's crop of first novels.
Her hair was cut in a short crop.

crop.eng_def: a part of the throat in many birds where food is stored before going into the stomach
a short stick used to control a horse by hitting it
to make something shorter or smaller, especially by cutting
crop.eg: He had his hair cropped when he went into the army.

crop.eng_def: When animals such as sheep or horses crop grass or other plants, they eat the top parts.
crop.chi_def: （羊、馬等）啃食（草或其他植物）的頂部

crop.eng_def: to remove some or all of the edges from a picture, leaving only the most important part
crop.eg: He cropped the photo so that only the face remained.

crop.eng_def: If a plant crops, it produces fruit, flowers, etc.
crop.eg: The carrots have cropped (= grown) well this year.

cross.eng_def: to go across from one side of something to the other
cross.eg: It's not a good place to cross the road.

cross.eng_def: If something crosses your mind, you think of it.
cross.eg: It crossed my mind yesterday that you must be short of staff.

cross.eng_def: to put one of your arms, fingers, or legs over the top of the other
cross.eg: She sat down and crossed her legs.

cross.eng_def: to annoy someone by not doing or saying what they want
cross.eg: I wouldn't cross him if I were you, not if you value your life.

cross.eng_def: If you cross a plant or animal with another of a different type, you cause them to breed together in order to produce a new variety (= type of plant or animal).
in some sports, to hit, kick, or throw the ball across the playing area to another player, not forwards or backwards
cross.eg: He crossed (the ball) to Bremer, who somehow failed to score from two metres out.

cross.eng_def: to draw two lines across the middle of a cheque to show that it needs to be paid into a bank account
cross.chi_def: 在（支票中間）上畫兩道線（表示需要轉入銀行帳戶）

cross.eng_def: When Catholics and some other types of Christians cross themselves, they move their hand down and then across their face or chest, making the shape of a cross.
a written mark (x or +) formed by two lines going across each other. The mark x is usually used to show where something is, or that something has not been written correctly.

an object made of one long upright piece of wood, with a smaller piece across it near the top. In the past, people were tied or fastened with nails to crosses as a punishment and left hanging on them until they died.
an object in the shape of a cross that people were killed on, used as a symbol of Christianity
cross.chi_def: （象徵基督教的）十字架，十字形物件

cross.eng_def: a medal in the shape of a cross
cross.eg: In Britain, the Victoria Cross is awarded for acts of great bravery during wartime.

cross.eng_def: a mixture of two different things that have been combined to produce something new
cross.eg: Police dogs are often a cross between a retriever and a German Shepherd.

cross.eng_def: in some sports, a kick, hit, or throw of the ball that goes from one side of the playing area to the other, not forwards or backwards
cross.eg: He headed the ball into the net, after a great cross from Pele.
My Dad gets cross (with me) if I leave the kitchen in a mess.

cross.chi_def: 由不同群體或學科組成的

crossing.eng_def: a place where something such as a road, river, etc. can be crossed safely, or a place where a road and a railway meet and cross each other
crossing.chi_def: 十字路口；交叉口；岔口，岔道；交彙處

crossing.eng_def: a journey across a large area of water, from one side to the other
crossing.chi_def: 跨海旅程，橫度海洋的旅程
crossing.eg: It was a really rough crossing - I threw up three times.

crouch.eng_def: to bend your knees and lower yourself so that you are close to the ground and leaning forward slightly
crouch.eg: She saw him coming and crouched (down) behind a bush.

crow.eng_def: a large, black bird with a loud, unpleasant cry
When a cock (= an adult male chicken) crows, it makes a very long and loud sharp cry.
crow.eg: We were woken at dawn by a cock crowing repeatedly.

crow.eng_def: When a baby crows, it makes sudden cries of happiness.
to talk in a proud and annoying way about something you have done
crow.eg: He's always crowing about his latest triumph.

crowd.eng_def: a large group of people who have come together
crowd.eg: A crowd of about 15,000 attended the concert.

crowd.eng_def: a group of friends or a group of people with similar interests
crowd.chi_def: （有共同愛好的）一幫朋友，一夥人，一群人
crowd.eg: She goes around with a friendly crowd.

crowd.eng_def: to make someone feel uncomfortable by standing too close to them or by watching them all the time
crowd.eg: I need some time to do this work properly, so don't crowd me.

crown.eng_def: a circular decoration for the head, usually made of gold and jewels (= precious stones), and worn by a king or queen at official ceremonies
the act of winning a sports competition
crown.eg: He plans to defend his Olympic crown.

crown.eng_def: the top part of a head, hat, or hill
crown.eg: A pink ribbon had been tied around the crown of the hat.

crown.eng_def: an artificial piece used to cover a damaged tooth
a British coin that is no longer used
to put a crown on someone's head in an official ceremony that makes that person king or queen
crown.eg: Queen Elizabeth II was crowned (queen) (= made queen in a special ceremony) in 1953.

crown.eng_def: If an event or achievement crowns something, it is the best or most successful part of it.
crown.eg: an acting career crowned by her final Oscar-winning performance

crown.eng_def: If something crowns something else, it is on or around the top of it.
crown.eg: The church was crowned with golden domes.

crown.eng_def: to hit someone on the head
to fit a crown (= tooth covering)
crown.eg: She's had her two front teeth crowned.

crown.eng_def: the royal governing power of a country that has a king or queen

crucial.chi_def: 至關重要的；關鍵的；決定性的

crude.eng_def: simple and not skilfully done or made
crude.chi_def: 粗糙的；簡陋的；粗製的；未加修飾的

crude.eng_def: oil from rocks underground in a natural state that has not yet been treated

cruel.eng_def: extremely unkind and unpleasant and causing pain to people or animals intentionally
cruel.chi_def: 殘忍的；殘酷的；刻毒傷人的
cruel.eg: Don't tease him about his weight - it's cruel.
His death was a cruel blow.

cruelty.eng_def: cruel behaviour or a cruel action
cruelty.chi_def: 殘忍，殘酷；殘酷行爲；虐待
cruelty.eg: The farmer was accused of cruelty to animals.

cruise.eng_def: a journey on a large ship for pleasure, during which you visit several places
to travel on ships for pleasure
If a ship or aircraft cruises, it travels at a continuous speed.
cruise.chi_def: （船隻或飛機）巡航，以平穩的速度航行

cruise.eng_def: to go around public places looking for someone to have sex with
cruise.chi_def: （在公共場所）尋覓性伴侶，尋花問柳，獵豔
cruise.eg: He spends the weekends cruising the bars.

cruiser.eng_def: a large fast ship used in war
a boat with an engine and a cabin in which people sail for pleasure

cruiser.eg: Two cops were sitting outside in a cruiser.

crumb.eng_def: a very small piece of bread, cake, or biscuit

crumble.eng_def: to break, or cause something to break, into small pieces
crumble.eg: She nervously crumbled the bread between her fingers.

crumble.eng_def: to become weaker in strength or influence
crumble.chi_def: （力量和影響力）減弱，崩潰，瓦解，敗落
crumble.eg: Support for the government is crumbling.

crumble.eng_def: a sweet dish made from fruit covered in a mixture of flour, butter, and sugar rubbed together into small pieces, baked, and eaten hot

crunch.eng_def: to crush hard food loudly between the teeth, or to make a sound as if something is being crushed or broken
crunch.eg: She was crunching noisily on an apple.

crunch.eng_def: the sound of hard food being crushed between the teeth, or like something being crushed or broken
crunch.eg: The woods were silent apart from the crunch of our feet in the snow.

crunch.eng_def: a difficult situation that forces you to make a decision or do something
crunch.chi_def: 嚴峻的形勢；緊要關頭；需要作出艱難抉擇的時刻
crunch.eg: The crunch came when she was forced to choose between her marriage and her career.

crunch.eng_def: an exercise in which you lie on your back on the floor with your knees bent and your feet flat on the floor, and then raise your head and shoulders
crunch.chi_def: 增強腹肌的鍛煉；仰臥起坐
crunch.eg: Doing crunches every day strengthens your abdominal muscles.

crunchy.eng_def: Crunchy food is firm and makes a loud noise when it is eaten.
crunchy.chi_def: （食物）脆生生的，鬆脆的，鮮脆的

crush.eng_def: to press something very hard so that it is broken or its shape is destroyed
crush.eg: The package had been badly crushed in the post.

crush.eng_def: to press paper or cloth so that it becomes full of folds and is no longer flat
crush.eg: My dress got all crushed in my suitcase.

crush.eng_def: If people are crushed against other people or things, they are pressed against them.
crush.eg: Tragedy struck when several people were crushed to death in the crowd.

crush.eng_def: to upset or shock someone badly
crush.eg: He was crushed by the news of the accident.
The president called upon the army to help crush the rebellion.

crush.eng_def: a strong but temporary feeling of liking someone
crush.eg: She has a crush on one of her teachers at school.

crush.eng_def: a crowd of people forced to stand close together
crush.eg: I had to struggle through the crush to get to the door.

crust.eng_def: a hard outer covering of something
crust.eg: pie crust (= the cooked pastry on top)

crust.eng_def: the outside layer of a loaf of bread
crust.eg: Could you cut the crusts off the sandwiches, please?

crutch.eng_def: a stick with a piece that fits under the arm, that you lean on for support if you have difficulty in walking because of a foot or leg injury
crutch.chi_def: （腿腳受傷的人使用的）T形拐杖
crutch.eg: Martin broke his leg and has been on crutches for the past six weeks.

crutch.eng_def: something that provides help and support and that you depend on, often too much
crutch.eg: As an atheist, he believes that religion is just an emotional crutch for the insecure.

cry.eng_def: to produce tears as the result of a strong emotion, such as unhappiness or pain
cry.eg: I could hear someone crying in the next room.

cry.eng_def: to cry for a long time until you start to sleep
a loud, high sound that expresses an emotion
a shout made to attract people's attention
cry.eg: They were wakened by cries of "Fire!" from the next room.

cry.eng_def: the noise that a bird or animal makes

cry.eg: "It's all right, have a good cry," he said, stroking her hair.

crystal.eng_def: transparent glass of very high quality, usually with its surface cut into delicate patterns
a transparent glass or plastic cover for a watch or clock
crystal.chi_def: （手錶或鐘錶的透明）玻璃（或塑膠）蓋片

crystal.eng_def: a piece of a substance that has become solid, with a regular shape
crystal.eg: When sea water is allowed to evaporate, salt crystals are deposited.

crystal.eng_def: clear, transparent rock that is used in jewellery, or a piece of this

cub.eng_def: a young lion, bear, wolf, etc.
a boy aged between eight and eleven years old who is a member of the international organization called the Scouts
cub.chi_def: （年齡在8至11歲之間的）幼年童子軍

cube.eng_def: a solid object with six square sides of equal size
cube.eg: Cut the cheese into small cubes.

cube.eng_def: the number made by multiplying a number twice by itself
If you cube a number, you multiply it twice by itself.
cube.eg: 2 cubed (= 2 x 2 x 2) equals 8, and is written 23.

cucumber.eng_def: a long, thin, pale green vegetable with dark green skin, usually eaten uncooked in salads

cue.eng_def: a word or action in a play or film that is used as a signal by a performer to begin saying or doing something
cue.chi_def: （戲劇或電影中用來暗示演員開始說或做某事的）尾白，提示

cue.eng_def: a signal for someone to do something
cue.eg: They started washing up, so that was our cue to leave the party.

cue.eng_def: If something happens on cue, it happens just after someone has said or thought it would happen.
cue.chi_def: 恰恰在這時，正好在此時
cue.eg: I was just wondering where Sarah was, when, right on cue, she came in.

cue.eng_def: to take notice of someone's words or behaviour so that you know what you should do
cue.eg: She watched his lips carefully and took her cue from him.

cue.eng_def: a long, thin wooden pole with a small piece of leather at one end, used for hitting the ball in games such as billiards or snooker
to give someone a signal to do something
cue.eg: With a nod of his head, the drummer cued the lead singer in.

cultivate.eng_def: to prepare land and grow crops on it, or to grow a particular crop
cultivate.eg: Most of the land there is too poor to cultivate.

cultivate.eng_def: to try to develop and improve something
cultivate.chi_def: 培養，培育；養成；陶冶；改進
cultivate.eg: She has cultivated an image as a tough negotiator.

cultivate.eng_def: If you cultivate a relationship, you make a special effort to establish and develop it, because you think it might be useful to you.
cultivate.eg: The new prime minister is cultivating relationships with East Asian countries.

cultural.eng_def: relating to the habits, traditions, and beliefs of a society
cultural.eg: The US is often accused of cultural imperialism.

cultural.eng_def: relating to music, art, theatre, literature, etc.

culture.eng_def: the way of life, especially the general customs and beliefs, of a particular group of people at a particular time
culture.chi_def: 文化（尤指某一群體在某一時期普遍的風俗習慣和信仰）

culture.eg: You won't find much culture in this sleepy little town, I'm afraid!

culture.eng_def: cells, tissues, organs, or organisms grown for scientific purposes, or the activity of breeding and keeping particular living things in order to get the substances they produce
culture.chi_def: 培養出的細胞（或組織、器官、生物體）；培養，養殖

culture.eng_def: to breed and keep particular living things in order to get the substances they produce

cumulative.eng_def: increasing by one addition after another
cumulative.eg: The cumulative effect of using so many chemicals on the land could be disastrous.

cunning.eng_def: Cunning people are clever at planning something so that they get what they want, especially by tricking other people, or things that are cleverly made for a particular purpose.
the quality or skill of being clever at planning something so you get what you want, especially by tricking other people
cunning.eg: We need to show some cunning if we want to defeat the enemy.

cup.eng_def: a small, round container, often with a handle, used for drinking tea, coffee, etc.
a container that holds slightly under a quarter of a litre of liquid, used for measuring when cooking
a specially designed cup, usually with two handles and often made of silver, given as a prize in a sports competition or in a game or match in which the winner receives such a cup
cup.eg: Sheila won this cup in the school squash championship.

cup.eng_def: one of the two parts that support the breasts in a woman's bra (= piece of underwear)
cup.eg: "What size bra do you wear?" "I wear a C cup."

cup.eng_def: a curved piece of hard plastic that is worn by men while playing sports to protect their outer sex organs
cup.chi_def: （男子運動時穿的）塑膠護罩，下體護身

cup.eng_def: a mixture of several types of drink, often including one that is alcoholic, often drunk at parties and usually served from a bowl
to hold your hands in the shape of a cup, often around something
cup.eg: She gently cupped the small injured bird in her hands.

cup.eng_def: abbreviation for carcinoma of uncertain primary origin: the situation when cancer is found in one or more places in the body but the place where it started is unknown
cup.chi_def: 原發部位不明癌（carcinoma of uncertain primary origin的縮寫）

cupboard.eng_def: a piece of furniture or a small part of a room with a door or doors behind which there is space for storing things, usually on shelves

curb.eng_def: to control or limit something that is not wanted
curb.eg: The government should act to curb tax evasion.

curb.eng_def: a limit on something that is not wanted
curb.eg: You must try to put a curb on your bad temper/spending habits.

cure.eng_def: to make someone with an illness healthy again
cure.eg: At one time doctors couldn't cure TB/cure people of TB.
The president and his advisors meet this week to discuss how to cure inflation.

cure.eng_def: to treat food, tobacco, etc. with smoke, salt, etc. in order to preserve it
cure.chi_def: （用煙熏或鹽醃等方法）保存（食物、煙草等）

cure.eng_def: something that makes someone who is sick healthy again
cure.eg: There's still no cure for cancer.
The best cure for boredom is hard work!

curiosity.eng_def: an eager wish to know or learn about something
something that is interesting because it is rare and unusual
curiosity.chi_def: 奇品，珍品；新奇罕有的事物
curiosity.eg: Cars like mine are curiosities nowadays.

curious.eng_def: interested in learning about people or things around you
curious.eg: I was curious to know what would happen next.

curious.chi_def: 稀奇的，古怪的，不尋常的
curious.eg: There was a curious-looking man standing outside.

curl.eng_def: a piece of hair that grows or has been formed into a curving shape, or something that is the same shape as this
the curved shape in which a ball moves when it is hit or kicked in a particular way
curl.eg: The curl on the shot sent it looping around the keeper into the far corner of the net.

curl.eng_def: to make something into the shape of a curl, or to grow or change into this shape
curl.eg: Does your hair curl naturally, or is it permed?

curl.eng_def: to make a ball move in a curved shape by hitting or kicking it in a particular way
curl.eg: He curled the ball into the top right hand corner.

curl.eng_def: to show by an upward movement of one side of your mouth that you feel no respect for something or someone
curl.eg: Her lip curled at what he said.

currency.eng_def: the money that is used in a particular country at a particular time
the state of being commonly known or accepted, or of being used in many places
currency.eg: His ideas enjoyed wide currency during the last century.

current.eg: Have you seen the current issue of (= the most recently published) Vogue magazine?

current.eng_def: a movement of water, air, or electricity in a particular direction
a particular opinion or feeling that a group of people have
current.eg: There is a growing current of support for environmental issues among voters.

curriculum.eng_def: the subjects studied in a school, college, etc. and what each subject includes

curry.eng_def: a dish, originally from South Asia, consisting of meat or vegetables cooked in a spicy sauce
curry.chi_def: （源自南亞的）咖喱食品，咖喱菜餚

curry.eng_def: to praise someone, especially someone in authority, in a way that is not sincere, in order to get some advantage for yourself
curry.chi_def: （尤指對當權者）討好，奉承，拍馬屁
curry.eg: He's always trying to curry favour with the boss.

curry.eng_def: to make a curry with something
to clean and brush a horse with a special comb

curse.eng_def: to use a word or an expression that is not polite and shows that you are very angry
curse.eg: We could hear him cursing and swearing as he tried to get the door open.

curse.eng_def: to say magic words that are intended to bring bad luck to someone
curse.eg: Things were going so badly - it was as if I'd been cursed.

curse.eng_def: magic words that are intended to bring bad luck to someone
curse.eg: In the story, a wicked witch puts a curse on the princess for a hundred years.

curse.eng_def: a cause of trouble and unhappiness
curse.eg: Noise is the curse of modern city life.

curse.eng_def: a woman's period (= flow of blood each month)

curtain.eng_def: a piece of material, especially cloth, that hangs across a window or opening to make a room or part of a room dark or private
curtain.eg: Heavy curtains blocked out the sunlight.

curtain.eng_def: a thick layer of something that makes it difficult to see anything behind it
curtain.eg: They could see nothing through the curtain of rain/smoke.

curtain.eng_def: the large screen of heavy material in a theatre that separates the stage from the area where people are watching

curve.eng_def: a line that bends continuously and has no straight parts
the curved shape in which a ball moves when it is hit or kicked in a particular way
curve.eg: The ball swung into a reverse curve.

curve.eng_def: to form a curve, or move in the shape of a curve
curve.eg: The road curves round to the left.

cushion.eng_def: a bag made of cloth, plastic, or leather that is filled with soft material, often has an attractive cover, and is used especially on chairs for sitting or leaning on
cushion.eg: She sank back against/into the cushions.

cushion.eng_def: a layer of air often used to support a machine or vehicle
cushion.eg: A hovercraft travels on a cushion of air.

cushion.eng_def: something that makes the effects of a bad situation less severe
cushion.chi_def: 起保護（或緩衝）作用的事物
cushion.eg: You should aim to build up a cushion of money in case of emergencies.

cushion.eng_def: to make the effect or force of something softer
cushion.chi_def: 對（某事物的影響或力量）起緩衝作用
cushion.eg: The soft grass cushioned his fall.

custom.eng_def: a way of behaving or a belief that has been established for a long time

custom.eg: He left the house at nine exactly, as is his custom.

custom.eng_def: the support given to a business, especially a shop, by the people who buy things or services from it
custom.eg: Most of our custom comes from tourists nowadays.

custom.eng_def: the place at a port, airport, or border where travellers' bags are looked at to find out if any goods are being carried illegally
used before another word to mean "specially designed for a particular person or purpose"

customary.eg: She's not her customary cheerful self today.
In my village, it is customary for a girl to take her mother's name.

customer.eng_def: a person who buys goods or a service

customs.eng_def: a way of behaving or a belief that has been established for a long time

customs.eg: He left the house at nine exactly, as is his custom.

customs.eng_def: the support given to a business, especially a shop, by the people who buy things or services from it
customs.eg: Most of our custom comes from tourists nowadays.

customs.eng_def: the place at a port, airport, or border where travellers' bags are looked at to find out if any goods are being carried illegally
used before another word to mean "specially designed for a particular person or purpose"

cut.eng_def: to break the surface of something, or to divide or make something smaller, using a sharp tool, especially a knife
cut.eg: to cut a slice of bread

cut.eng_def: to make something shorter, lower, smaller, etc.
to remove something from something else
cut.eg: The sex scenes had been cut out of the TV version of the film.

cut.eng_def: to move words or pictures from one place to another in a computer document
cut.chi_def: （電腦文檔中文字或圖片的）剪貼

cut.eng_def: to decide not to leave someone any of your money or possessions when you die
to not go, especially to a place where you should be
cut.eg: Your son has been cutting classes.

cut.eng_def: to stop or interrupt something
to stop someone from talking before they have finished what they were saying
cut.eg: He started to explain, but she cut him short.

cut.eng_def: used to tell someone to stop talking or stop behaving in an annoying way
cut.eg: Just cut it out! I've had enough of your time wasting.

cut.eng_def: (of a baby) to grow a new tooth
cut.eg: The baby's cutting a tooth. That's why she's crying.

cut.eng_def: to go through or across a place, especially in order to get somewhere quickly
to fail to keep to your own side of the road when going round a corner
to choose a playing card by dividing a pile of cards into two parts
cut.eg: Who's going to cut the cards?

cut.eng_def: to record music or speech on a record
cut.eg: When did the Stones cut their first record?

cut.eng_def: an injury made when the skin is cut with something sharp
a piece of meat cut from a particular part of an animal
cut.eg: Sirloin is the most expensive cut of beef.

cut.eng_def: the shape into which something is cut
cut.eg: I don't like the cut of these jeans.

cut.eng_def: a reduction in the number, amount, or rate of something
cut.eg: a cut in expenditure/interest rates/hospital waiting lists

cut.eng_def: reductions in public spending
cut.eg: Students and workers were out on the streets protesting against the cuts.

cut.eng_def: the act of removing a part from a book, film, etc., or a part that is removed
cut.eg: The movie contains some very violent scenes, so some cuts were made when it was shown on TV.

cut.eng_def: a share of something, usually money
cut.eg: When am I going to get my cut?

cut.eng_def: a deep, narrow passage made through a hill for a road, railway, or canal
cut.chi_def: （從山中開鑿出的）通道鐵路，河床

cute.eng_def: (especially of something or someone small or young) pleasant and attractive
cute.chi_def: （尤指小東西或小孩）可愛的，嬌小可愛的，逗人喜愛的
cute.eg: His baby brother is really cute.

cute.eng_def: trying to be clever, sometimes in a rude or unpleasant way
cute.chi_def: 裝乖巧的；滑頭的；精明的
cute.eg: Don't be cute with me, Vicki.

cycle.eng_def: a group of events that happen in a particular order, one following the other, and are often repeated
cycle.eg: the life cycle of a moth

cycle.eng_def: one in a series of movements that a machine performs
a group of plays, poems, songs, etc. written by one person and connected with each other by dealing with the same characters or ideas
cycle.chi_def: （表現相同人物或思想的）全套劇目，組詩
cycle.eg: It's one in a cycle of plays that are being performed on successive evenings.

dad.eg: Can you pick me up from the party tonight, Dad?

daddy.chi_def: 爸爸，爹爹（尤指兒童用語）

daffodil.eng_def: a yellow, bell-shaped flower with a long stem that is commonly seen in the spring

daily.eng_def: happening on or relating to every day
a person who is employed to clean someone else's home
daily.chi_def: （受僱為別人打掃家居的）清潔工，傭人

dairy.eng_def: used to refer to cows that are used for producing milk, rather than meat, or to foods that are made from milk, such as cream, butter, and cheese
dairy.chi_def: 奶牛的；奶製品的，乳品的

dairy.eng_def: a place on a farm where milk and cream are kept and cheese and butter are made, or a company that supplies milk and products made from milk
dairy.chi_def: 牛奶場，乳品場，製酪場；牛奶公司，奶製品公司

dairy.eng_def: foods that are made from milk, such as cream, butter, and cheese

dam.eng_def: a wall built across a river that stops the river's flow and collects the water, especially to make a reservoir (= an artificial lake) that provides water for an area
dam.eg: The Aswan High Dam is on the River Nile in Egypt.

dam.eng_def: to build a dam across a river in order to store water

damage.eg: Many buildings were badly damaged during the war.
Strong winds had caused serious damage to the roof.

damage.eng_def: money that is paid to someone by a person or organization who has been responsible for causing them some injury or loss
damage.eg: The politician was awarded £50,000 in damages over false allegations made by the newspaper.

damn.chi_def: 該死，可惡，真倒楣（表示憤怒或氣惱）
damn.eg: Damn, I've spilled coffee down my blouse!

damn.eng_def: used, especially when you are annoyed, to mean "very"
damn.eg: He knew damn well how much trouble it would cause.
I know damn all about computers.

damn.eng_def: to blame or strongly criticize something or someone
damn.eg: The inquiry into the disaster damns the company for its lack of safety precautions.

damn.eng_def: (especially of God) to force someone to stay in hell and be punished for ever
damn.eg: As a child she was taught that she would be damned for her sins.

damn.eng_def: used to express anger with someone or something
damn.chi_def: （表示對某人或某事物的憤怒或厭煩）討厭，該死，可惡
damn.eg: You got the last ticket - damn you, I wanted that!

damn.eng_def: used to express anger with someone or something

damp.eng_def: slightly wet, especially in a way that is not pleasant or comfortable

dance.eng_def: to move the body and feet to music

dance.eg: The daffodils were dancing in the breeze.

dance.eng_def: a particular series of movements that you perform to music or the type of music that is connected with it
dance.eg: The band played a slow dance.

dance.eng_def: a social occasion where people dance, especially a formal occasion in a large room
the act of moving your feet and body to music
the art of performing dances, especially as a form of entertainment
dance.eg: The performers tell the story through song and dance.

dancer.eng_def: someone who dances either as a job or for pleasure
dancer.eg: He's a dancer in the Royal Ballet.

dandruff.eng_def: small, white pieces of dead skin from the head that collect in the hair or fall on the clothes

danger.eng_def: the possibility of harm or death to someone
something or someone that may harm you
danger.eg: Icy roads are a danger to drivers.

danger.eng_def: the possibility that something bad will happen
danger.eg: If there's any danger of seeing Gary at the party, I'm not going.

dangerous.eng_def: A dangerous person, animal, thing, or activity could harm you.
dangerous.chi_def: 危險的，有威脅的；不安全的

dare.eng_def: to be brave enough to do something difficult or dangerous, or to be rude or silly enough to do something that you have no right to do
dare.eg: I was going to ask if his dog was better, but I didn't dare in case she had died.

dare.eng_def: to ask someone to do something that involves risk
dare.chi_def: 向…挑戰；問…有沒有膽量（做）；（用激將法）激
dare.eg: Wear the low-cut blouse with your pink shorts - go on, I dare you!

dare.eng_def: something you do because someone dares you to
dare.chi_def: 在激將法做出的事，應他人挑戰而做出的事
dare.eg: He jumped in the river at twelve o'clock last night as (also US on/UK for) a dare.

dark.eg: It was too dark to see much.

dark.eng_def: nearer to black than white in colour

dark.eg: Her husband's sudden death was the start of a dark chapter in her life.

dark.chi_def: 邪惡的，陰險的；有威脅的
dark.eg: There's a darker side to his character.
I've just been promoted, but keep it dark - I don't want everyone to know just yet.

dark.eng_def: the fact of there being no light somewhere
dark.eg: Cats can see in the dark.

dark.eng_def: before/after the sun has gone down
dark.eg: It isn't safe to leave the house after dark.

darken.eg: The sky darkened as thick smoke billowed from the blazing oil well.

darling.eng_def: a person who is very much loved or liked
darling.chi_def: 親愛的；寶貝；極受歡迎的人

darling.eng_def: used when talking to someone you love, for example in a letter, to say that you love them very much
darling.chi_def: （在書信等對喜愛之人的稱呼）親愛的，心愛的
darling.eg: Darling Martha, It was great to see you at the weekend.

darling.chi_def: 吸引人的，可愛的，迷人的
darling.eg: They've just bought a darling little apartment.

dart.eng_def: a small, thin object with a sharp point that is thrown by hand in a game, shot from a gun, or blown from a tube when used as a weapon
a game in which darts are thrown at a circular board. The number of points won depends on where the darts land on the board
a small fold, becoming narrower towards one end, that is sewn into a piece of clothing to make it fit better
dart.chi_def: （為使衣料更合身而縫出的）褶，皺褶

dart.eg: We made a dart for (= moved quickly towards) the exit.
I darted behind the sofa and hid.
She darted an angry look at me.

dash.eg: The dog ran off, and she dashed after him.

dash.eng_def: to hit something with great force, especially causing damage
dash.chi_def: 猛擊，猛撞；（尤指）撞碎，擊碎
dash.eg: The tidal wave dashed the ship against the rocks.

dash.eng_def: the act of running somewhere very quickly
dash.eg: I made a dash for the bathroom.

dash.eng_def: a race over a short distance
the symbol – used to separate parts of a sentence
a long sound or flash of light that is used with dots to send messages in Morse (code)
a small amount of something, especially liquid food, that is added to something else
dash.chi_def: （尤指添加的流質食品）少量，少許
dash.eg: Add some butter and a dash of salt.
Oh dash (it)! I've left my umbrella in the office.

data.eng_def: information, especially facts or numbers, collected to be examined and considered and used to help decision-making, or information in an electronic form that can be stored and used by a computer
data.eg: The data was/were collected by various researchers.

date.eng_def: a numbered day in a month, often given with a combination of the name of the day, the month, and the year
date.eg: What's the date (today)?/What date is it?/What's today's date?
The date on the coin is 1789.
The expiry (US expiration) date of this certificate is August 2017.

date.eng_def: a social meeting planned before it happens, especially one between two people who have or might have a romantic relationship
date.eg: He asked her out on a date.

date.eng_def: a person you have a romantic meeting with
date.eg: Who's your date for the prom?
They've just finished an exhausting 75-date European tour.

date.eng_def: the sweet fruit of various types of palm tree
to write the day's date on something you have written or made
date.chi_def: 在…上寫上日子，在…上標明日期
date.eg: Thank you for your letter dated 30 August.

date.eng_def: to say how long something has existed or when it was made
date.chi_def: 確定…的年代，推算…形成的時間
date.eg: Archaeologists have been unable to date these fossils.

date.eng_def: to regularly spend time with someone you have a romantic relationship with
date.eg: They dated for five years before they got married.

date.eng_def: to stop being fashionable or become old-fashioned
date.eg: Some James Bond films have dated more than others.

date.eng_def: to show the age of a person or thing
date.chi_def: 表明…的年齡；揭示…的年代
date.eg: I can remember watching live TV coverage of the first lunar landing, so that dates me (= shows how old I am).

daughter.eg: Liz and Phil have a daughter and three sons.

dawn.eng_def: the period in the day when light from the sun begins to appear in the sky
the start of a period of time or the beginning of something new
dawn.eg: The fall of the Berlin Wall marked the dawn of a new era in European history.
We worked from dawn to dusk, seven days a week.

dawn.eng_def: If a day or period of time dawns, it begins.
dawn.eg: He left the house just as the day was dawning.

dawn.chi_def: 見分曉，水落石出；變得明朗
dawn.eg: Gradually the truth about him dawned.

day.eng_def: a period of 24 hours, especially from twelve o'clock one night to twelve o'clock the next night
used to refer to the period in 24 hours when it is naturally light
the time that you usually spend at work or at school
a day when you do not have to work or do something that you normally do
day.eg: I won't be in on Thursday - it's my day off.
Didn't I see you in the post office the other day?

day.eng_def: used to talk about the present time, in comparison with the past
day.eg: Vegetarianism is very popular these days.
In those days people used to write a lot more letters.

day.eng_def: very soon, especially within the next few days
day.chi_def: 很快，過不了多久；（尤指）就這幾天
day.eg: The baby's due any day now.
The same problems keep coming up day after day.
You can hear the traffic from your room day and night.

day.eng_def: every day, or more and more as each day passes
day.eg: Day by day he became weaker.

day.eng_def: If something changes (from) day to day, it changes often.
day.eg: The symptoms of the disease change from day to day.

day.chi_def: 一天又一天（表示不知道未來會怎樣），過一天算一天
day.eg: I never know what I’ll be doing from one day to the next.
How did people communicate in the days before email?

day.eng_def: up to and including the present moment
day.eg: To this day nobody knows what happened to him.

dazzle.eng_def: If light dazzles you, it makes you unable to see for a short time.
dazzle.chi_def: 使感到刺眼，使感到目眩
dazzle.eg: I was dazzled by the sunlight.

dazzle.eng_def: If you are dazzled by someone or something, you think they are extremely good and exciting.
dazzle.eg: I was dazzled by his charm and good looks.

dead.eg: She's been dead for 20 years now.

dead.eng_def: If a part of your body is dead, you cannot feel it.
dead.chi_def: （身體局部）失去知覺的，麻木的
dead.eg: I've been sitting with my legs crossed for so long, my right leg has gone dead.

dead.eng_def: If glasses and bottles that were previously full are dead, they are now empty.
In some sports, if a ball is dead, it is outside the area of play.
If a place is dead, it is too quiet and nothing interesting happens there.
dead.eg: The city centre is quite lively during the day, but it's totally dead at night.

dead.eng_def: If a piece of equipment is dead, it is not working.

dead.eg: The conductor waited for dead silence before commencing the performance.

dead.eng_def: to be completely opposed to something
dead.eg: He's dead set against living in the city.

dead.eng_def: to be very determined to do or have something
dead.eg: Martha's dead set on having a new bike.
Three children were among the dead.

deadline.eng_def: a time or day by which something must be done
deadline.eg: There's no way I can meet that deadline.

deadly.eg: They have been deadly enemies ever since Mark stole Greg's girlfriend.

deadly.chi_def: 極其乏味的，非常無聊的

deadly.eg: I thought she was joking but she was deadly serious.

deaf.eng_def: unable to hear, either completely or partly
deaf.chi_def: 耳聾的，聽不見的，失聰的
deaf.eg: He's been totally/partially deaf since birth.
The local council has remained deaf to all the objections to its proposals.

deaf.eng_def: people who are unable to hear
deaf.eg: Many of the TV programmes are broadcast with subtitles for the deaf.

deafen.eng_def: If a very loud noise deafens you, it makes you deaf, or makes you temporarily unable to hear the other sounds near you.
deafen.eg: The explosion permanently deafened her in her right ear.

deal.eng_def: an agreement or an arrangement, especially in business

deal.eg: She spends a good deal of her time in China.

deal.eng_def: the act of dealing (= sharing out) something, especially playing cards
deal.chi_def: 分出；分發；（尤指）分牌，發牌
deal.eg: It's your deal (= turn to deal).
We only deal with companies which have a good credit record.

deal.eng_def: to give or share out something, especially playing cards
deal.chi_def: 分出；分發；（尤指）分牌，發牌
deal.eg: Whose turn is it to deal?

deal.eng_def: to cause someone or something, usually a plan or hope, to fail or to be affected very badly
deal.chi_def: 使（計劃或希望）破滅；使受挫，使失敗
deal.eg: The latest trade figures have dealt a severe blow to hopes of an early economic recovery.

dealer.eng_def: a person who trades in something
the person who deals the cards in a game

dear.eg: She was a very dear friend.

dear.eng_def: used at the beginning of a letter to greet the person you are writing to
dear.chi_def: （用於信的開頭作問候語）親愛的，尊敬的

dear.eg: The food was good but very dear.

dear.eng_def: used in expressions of anger, disappointment, sadness, or surprise
dear.chi_def: 天哪（表示憤怒、失望、傷心、吃驚等）
dear.eg: Oh dear! I've lost my keys again.

dear.chi_def: 善良的人，和善之人，好人
dear.eg: Annie's such a dear - she's brought me breakfast in bed every morning this week.

dear.eng_def: used to address someone you love or are being friendly to, not used between men
dear.chi_def: 親愛的（親切友好的稱呼，不用於男子之間）

death.eg: The disease causes thousands of deaths a year.
The animals burned to death in the barn.

death.eng_def: the cause of the end of life, or the end or destruction of something
death.eg: The failure of the family business was the death of him.

debate.eng_def: (a) serious discussion of a subject in which many people take part
debate.eg: Education is the current focus of public debate.

debate.eng_def: to discuss a subject in a formal way
debate.eg: In Parliament today, MPs debated the Finance Bill.

debate.eng_def: to try to make a decision about something
debate.eg: We debated whether to take the earlier train.

debt.eng_def: something, especially money, that is owed to someone else, or the state of owing something
debt.eg: He managed to pay off his debts in two years.

decade.eng_def: a period of ten years, especially a period such as 2010 to 2019

decay.eng_def: to become gradually damaged, worse, or less; to cause something to do this

deceive.eng_def: to persuade someone that something false is the truth, or to keep the truth hidden from someone for your own advantage
deceive.eg: The company deceived customers by selling old computers as new ones.

deceive.eng_def: to refuse to accept the truth
deceive.eg: She thinks he'll come back, but she's deceiving herself.

decent.chi_def: 正派的；體面的，正經的；像樣的，相當不錯的
decent.eg: Everyone should be entitled to a decent wage/standard of living.

decide.eng_def: to choose something, especially after thinking carefully about several possibilities
decide.chi_def: （尤指仔細考慮後）決定，決斷，確定
decide.eg: They have to decide by next Friday.

decide.eng_def: to be the reason or situation that makes a particular result happen
decide.chi_def: 決定（事情的結果），導致…的結果
decide.eg: The weather decided the outcome of the tennis match.

decision.eng_def: a choice that you make about something after thinking about several possibilities
decision.eg: She has had to make some very difficult decisions.

decision.eng_def: the ability to decide quickly and without pausing because you are not certain
decision.eg: She acted with decision, closing the bank account and calling the police.

decisive.eng_def: able to make decisions quickly and confidently, or showing this quality
decisive.chi_def: 果斷的，乾脆俐落的，明確的；有決斷力的
decisive.eg: You need to be more decisive.

decisive.eng_def: strongly affecting how a situation will progress or end
decisive.chi_def: 決定性的，具有決定意義的
decisive.eg: These results could prove decisive in establishing the criminal's identity.

deck.eng_def: a flat area for walking on, built across the space between the sides of a boat
deck.eg: We sat on deck until it was dark.

deck.eng_def: one of the floors of a bus
deck.eg: the upper/top deck of the bus

deck.eng_def: a wooden floor built outside, where people can sit and relax
on a level of a ship below the main deck
a set of cards used for playing card games
to decorate or add something to something to make an effect
deck.eg: The room was decked with flowers.

deck.eng_def: to hit someone, especially to hit someone and knock them down
deck.chi_def: 打擊；（尤指）擊倒，把…打趴下
deck.eg: Do that again and I'll deck you.

declaration.eng_def: an announcement, often one that is written and official
declaration.eg: Members of Congress have to make a declaration of their business interests.

declaration.eng_def: in cricket, a situation in which a team stops batting (= hitting the ball) because they think they already have enough runs (= points) to win
declaration.chi_def: （板球比賽中，一方因已達足夠分數獲勝而在一局未結束前的）宣佈停止擊球，宣佈結束賽局

declare.eng_def: to announce something clearly, firmly, publicly, or officially
declare.eg: They declared their support for the proposal

declare.eng_def: to officially tell someone the value of goods you have bought, or the amount of money you have earned because you might have to pay tax
declare.chi_def: 申報（應納稅的貨物價值或收入）

declare.eng_def: If a cricket team declares, they stop batting (= hitting the ball) because they think they already have enough runs (= points) to win.
declare.chi_def: （板球比賽中，一方因已達足夠分數獲勝而在一局未結束前的）宣佈停止擊球，宣佈結束賽局

decline.eng_def: to gradually become less, worse, or lower
decline.eg: His interest in the project declined after his wife died.
I invited him to the meeting but he declined.

decline.eng_def: If a noun, pronoun, or adjective declines, it has different forms to show if it is the subject or object, etc. of a verb or if it is singular or plural, etc. If you decline such a word, you list its various forms.
decline.chi_def: （根據名詞，代詞或形容詞在句子中的作用）變格；（使）發生詞形變化
decline.eg: In Latin we learned how to decline nouns.

decline.eng_def: when something becomes less in amount, importance, quality, or strength

decorate.eng_def: to add something to an object or place, especially in order to make it more attractive
decorate.eg: They decorated the wedding car with ribbons and flowers.

decorate.eng_def: to paint the inside or outside of a house or put paper on the inside walls
decorate.eg: We're going to decorate the kitchen next week.

decorate.eng_def: to reward or honour a person by giving them something, especially a medal
decorate.eg: They were decorated for their part in the rescue.

decoration.eng_def: the activity of making something look more attractive by putting things on it or around it, or something that you use to do this
decoration.chi_def: 裝飾，裝潢；裝飾品，裝飾物

decoration.eng_def: the activity of covering the walls or other surfaces of rooms or buildings with paint or paper
decoration.eg: This place is badly in need of decoration.

decoration.eng_def: a medal given to someone and worn as an honour
decoration.chi_def: （作為榮譽而佩戴的）獎章，勳章
decoration.eg: The Victoria Cross and George Cross are British decorations for bravery.

decrease.eng_def: to become less, or to make something become less
decrease.eg: Our share of the market has decreased sharply this year.
There has been a steady decrease in the number of visitors.

dedicate.eng_def: to give all of your energy, time, etc.
dedicate.chi_def: 奉獻，獻出（全部精力、時間等）
dedicate.eg: He has dedicated his life to scientific research.

dedicate.eng_def: If you dedicate a book, play, performance, etc. to someone, you publicly say that it is in that person's honour.
dedicate.eg: The book is dedicated to the author's husband.

dedicate.eng_def: When a building, especially a religious building, is dedicated, there is a ceremony at which it is formally opened for use and its particular purpose is stated.
dedicate.chi_def: 為（尤指宗教建築）舉行奉獻典禮；為…舉行落成儀式
dedicate.eg: The church was dedicated on 1 March 1805 to the local Saint Jude.

dedication.eng_def: the willingness to give a lot of time and energy to something because it is important
dedication.eg: He has always shown great dedication to the cause.

dedication.eng_def: a statement that says in whose honour something has been written, made, performed, etc.
dedication.eg: The dedication at the front of the book read "For my Father".

dedication.eng_def: a ceremony in which a building, especially a religious building, is opened for use and its purpose is stated
dedication.chi_def: （尤指宗教建築的）落成典禮，啟用儀式

deed.eng_def: an intentional act, especially a very bad or very good one
deed.chi_def: （尤指很壞或很好的）事情，行為
deed.eg: It seems to me that a lot of evil deeds are done in the name of religion.

deed.eng_def: a legal document that is an official record of an agreement or official proof that someone owns land or a building
deed.chi_def: （土地或建築的）契約，所有權證書

deem.eng_def: to consider or judge something in a particular way
deem.eg: The area has now been deemed safe.

deep.eng_def: going or being a long way down from the top or surface, or being of a particular distance from the top to the bottom
deep.chi_def: 深的，向下延伸的；有…深的

deep.eng_def: very strongly felt or experienced and usually lasting a long time
deep.eg: Their son has been a deep disappointment to them.

deep.eng_def: showing or needing serious thought, or not easy to understand
deep.eg: His films are generally too deep for me.

deep.eng_def: If something is deep, it has a large distance between its edges, especially between its front and back edges.
deep.eg: Is the alcove deep enough for bookshelves?

deep.eng_def: near the middle of something, and a long distance from its edges
deep.chi_def: 在…的中心附近；在…的深處
deep.eg: Little Red Riding Hood's grandmother lived in a house deep in the forest.

deep.eng_def: a long way from the top or surface
deep.eg: The submarine sailed deep under the ice cap.

deep.eng_def: If a football player or team plays deep, they stay a long way inside their own half of the field.
deep.chi_def: （足球比賽中）在己方後場運球；後撤防守，移後防守
deep.eg: Some midfielders play deep, having a more defensive role, while others go forward.

deepen.eng_def: to make something deeper, or to become deeper
deepen.eg: One way of preventing further flooding would be to deepen the river bed.

deepen.eng_def: to become more strongly felt or experienced, or to make something this way
deepen.chi_def: （使）感受更強烈；（使）深入，（使）加深
deepen.eg: Over the years, her love for him deepened.

deepen.eng_def: to make something increase or become more serious
deepen.eg: It certainly helped to deepen my understanding of the situation.
Boys' voices deepen in their early to mid-teens.
The shadows deepened as the sun dropped below the horizon.

deer.eng_def: a quite large animal with four legs that eats grass and leaves. The male has antlers (= wide horns like branches) . The female is called a hind or a doe and the male a stag or buck

defeat.eng_def: to win against someone in a fight, war, or competition
defeat.eg: Napoleon was defeated by the Duke of Wellington at the battle of Waterloo.

defeat.eng_def: to cause someone or something to fail
defeat.eg: The proposal to change the rules was narrowly defeated (= by a very small number) by 201 votes to 196.

defeat.eng_def: the fact of losing against someone in a fight or competition, or when someone or something is made to fail
defeat.eg: In the last election, they suffered a crushing/humiliating defeat.

defeat.eng_def: to accept that you cannot do something
defeat.eg: I thought I could fix the radio myself, but I had to admit defeat.

defect.eng_def: a fault or problem in something or someone that spoils that thing or person or causes it, him, or her not to work correctly
defect.eg: All the company's aircraft have been grounded, after a defect in the engine cooling system was discovered.

defect.eng_def: a physical condition in which something is wrong with a part of someone's body
defect.eg: She suffers from a heart/sight/speech defect.

defect.eng_def: to leave a country, political party, etc., especially in order to join an opposing one
defect.chi_def: （尤指為加入敵對國家、政黨等）脫離，退出，叛逃
defect.eg: When the national hockey team visited the US, half the players defected.

defend.eng_def: to protect someone or something against attack or criticism; to speak in favour of someone or something
defend.eg: How can we defend our homeland if we don't have an army?

defend.eng_def: to act as a lawyer for someone who has been accused of something in a court of law and try to prove that they are not guilty
defend.chi_def: （在法庭上）為…辯護，當…的辯護律師
defend.eg: I can't afford a lawyer, so I shall defend myself (= argue my own case in a court of law).

defend.eng_def: to compete in a sports competition that you won before and try to win it again
defend.eg: He will defend his 1,500 metre title this weekend.

defend.eng_def: to try to prevent the opposing player or players from scoring points, goals, etc. in a sport
defend.eg: In the last ten minutes of the game, we needed to defend.

defensible.eng_def: able to be protected from attack, or able to be supported by argument
defensible.chi_def: 有防衛能力的；合乎情理的，有正當理由的
defensible.eg: A city built on an island is easily defensible.

defensive.eng_def: used to protect someone or something against attack
defensive.eg: These are purely defensive weapons, not designed for attack.

defensive.eng_def: too quick to protect yourself from being criticized
defensive.chi_def: 自衛的；戒備的，懷有戒心的
defensive.eg: When asked about his decision, he got very defensive.

defensive.eng_def: in a sports event, trying to prevent the opposing player or players from scoring points, goals, etc.
defensive.eg: He's currently the best defensive player on the team.

defensive.eng_def: ready to protect yourself because you are expecting to be criticized or attacked
defensive.chi_def: 處於防衛狀態，處於戒備狀態

deficiency.eng_def: a state of not having, or not having enough, of something that is needed
deficiency.eg: Pregnant women often suffer from iron deficiency.

define.eng_def: to say what the meaning of something, especially a word, is
define.chi_def: 給（尤指單詞）下定義；說明，解釋
define.eg: In the dictionary, "reality" is defined as "the state of things as they are, rather than as they are imagined to be".

define.eng_def: to explain and describe the meaning and exact limits of something
define.eg: Your rights and responsibilities are defined in the citizens' charter.

define.eng_def: to show clearly the edge of something
define.chi_def: 顯示出…的輪廓；確定…的界線
define.eg: The outline of the castle on the hill was clearly defined against the evening sky.

definite.eg: The date for the meeting is now definite: 5 March .

definite.eng_def: something that is certain to happen
definite.eg: Let's make the 9th a definite - we'll have dinner and then go to the movies.

definition.eng_def: a statement that explains the meaning of a word or phrase
a description of the features and limits of something
definition.eg: The legal definition of what is and what is not pornography is very unsatisfactory.

definition.chi_def: 根據自身特點；從本質上來說
definition.eg: Psychology is by definition an inexact science.

definition.eng_def: how clear an image or sound is
definition.chi_def: （圖像或聲音的）清晰度，保真度

degrade.eng_def: to cause people to feel that they or other people have no value and do not have the respect or good opinion of others
degrade.chi_def: 貶低；降低…的身份；侮辱…的人格

degrade.eng_def: to spoil or destroy the beauty or quality of something
degrade.eg: Every day the environment is further degraded by toxic wastes.

degrade.eng_def: If the quality of something electrical or electronic degrades or is degraded, it becomes less good or less correct.
degrade.chi_def: （使）（無線電信號、靈敏度等）降低

degrade.eng_def: (of a substance) to change into a more simple chemical structure
degrade.eg: These chemicals quickly degrade into harmless compounds.

degree.eg: This job demands a high degree of skill.

degree.eng_def: any of various units of measurement, especially of temperature or angles, usually shown by the symbol ° written after a number
degree.chi_def: 度，度數（尤指溫度或角度的度量單位，通常在數字後用符號 °來表示）

degree.eng_def: a course of study at a college or university, or the qualification given to a student after he or she has completed his or her studies
degree.eg: She has a physics degree/a degree in physics from Edinburgh.

degree.eng_def: used with an ordinal number to show how serious something is
degree.chi_def: …度，…級（與序數並用，表示某事物的嚴重性）
degree.eg: She suffered first-/second-/third-degree (= least serious/serious/very serious) burns on her legs.

delay.eng_def: to make something happen at a later time than originally planned or expected
delay.eg: My plane was delayed by an hour.

delay.eng_def: to cause someone or something to be slow or late
to not act quickly or immediately
delay.eg: If you delay now, the opportunity might be lost.

delay.eng_def: the situation in which you have to wait longer than expected for something to happen, or the time that you have to wait
delay.chi_def: 延遲，延誤，延期；延遲（或延誤）的時間
delay.eg: This situation needs to be tackled without delay.

delegate.eng_def: a person chosen or elected by a group to speak, vote, etc. for them, especially at a meeting
delegate.eg: Delegates have voted in favour of the motion.

delegate.eng_def: to give a particular job, duty, right, etc. to someone else so that they do it for you
delegate.eg: As a boss you have to delegate (responsibilities to your staff).

delegate.eng_def: to choose or elect someone to speak, vote, etc. for a group, especially at a meeting
delegate.eg: A group of four teachers were delegated to represent their colleagues at the union conference.

delegation.eg: The delegation from Spain has/have arrived for a month.

delegation.eng_def: the act of delegating a particular job, duty, right, etc. to someone
delegation.chi_def: （工作、職務或權力等）分配；委派；授權
delegation.eg: Delegation of responsibility is a key part of a manager's job.

deliberate.eng_def: (often of something bad) intentional or planned
deliberate.chi_def: （常指壞事）有意的，故意的，蓄意的

deliberate.eng_def: A deliberate movement, action, or thought is done carefully without hurrying.
deliberate.chi_def: 慢吞吞的；小心謹慎的；沉穩的
deliberate.eg: From her slow, deliberate speech I guessed she must be drunk.

deliberate.eng_def: to think or talk seriously and carefully about something
deliberate.eg: The jury took five days to deliberate on the case.

delicate.eng_def: needing careful treatment, especially because easily damaged
delicate.eg: Peaches have delicate skins which are easily bruised.
Repairing damaged nerves is a very delicate operation/process.

delicate.eng_def: a situation. matter, etc. that needs to be dealt with carefully in order to avoid trouble or offence
delicate.chi_def: 微妙的形勢（問題，時刻等）
delicate.eg: I need to speak to you about a delicate matter.

delicate.eng_def: able to measure very small changes
delicate.eg: Weather-forecasters have extremely delicate equipment which helps them predict what the weather is going to be like.
a rose with a delicate scent
She folded her delicate hands on the table.

delicious.eng_def: having a very pleasant taste or smell
delicious.chi_def: 美味的；（味道或氣味）誘人的

delicious.eng_def: used to describe a situation or activity that gives you great pleasure
delicious.chi_def: 好玩的，有趣的，有意思的
delicious.eg: I have some delicious gossip to tell you.

delight.eng_def: (something or someone that gives) great pleasure, satisfaction, or happiness
delight.eg: My sister's little boy is a real delight.
We're just discovering the delights of being retired.

delight.eng_def: to give someone great pleasure or satisfaction
delight.eg: Peter's academic success delighted his family.

delightful.chi_def: 愉快的；吸引人的；有趣的

delinquent.eng_def: a person, usually young, who behaves in a way that is illegal or not acceptable to most people
delinquent.chi_def: （通常指年輕的）違法者；不良青少年

delinquent.eng_def: illegal or not acceptable, or behaving in a way that is illegal or not acceptable
delinquent.eg: They are carrying out research on the causes of delinquent behaviour among young people.

delinquent.chi_def: 遲付欠款的，未按時還款的，拖欠的
delinquent.eg: She has been delinquent in paying her taxes.

deliver.eng_def: to take goods, letters, parcels, etc. to people's houses or places of work
deliver.eg: Mail is delivered to our office twice a day.

deliver.eng_def: to give, direct, or aim something
deliver.eg: The priest delivered a passionate sermon/speech against war.

deliver.eng_def: to achieve or produce something that has been promised
deliver.eg: The government has failed to deliver (what it promised).

deliver.eng_def: to (help) give birth to a baby
deliver.eg: She delivered her third child at home.

deliver.eng_def: to save someone from a painful or bad experience
deliver.eg: Is there nothing that can be done to deliver these starving people from their suffering?

delivery.eng_def: the act of taking goods, letters, parcels, etc. to people's houses or places of work
delivery.eg: We get two deliveries of mail (= it is delivered twice) a day.

delivery.eng_def: the way in which someone speaks in public
delivery.chi_def: 演講風格（或方式）；表演風格（或方式）
