delivery.eng_def: in some sports, such as cricket or baseball, the act of throwing the ball towards the person with the bat, in order for that person to try to hit the ball
delivery.eg: That was a good delivery from Thompson.

demand.eng_def: to ask for something forcefully, in a way that shows that you do not expect to be refused
demand.chi_def: 堅決請求，強烈要求；強要

demand.eng_def: to need something such as time, effort, or a particular quality
demand.chi_def: 需要，要求（時間、精力、特定數量等）
demand.eg: This is a very difficult piece of music to play - it demands a lot of concentration.

demand.chi_def: 強烈的要求，堅決的請求
demand.eg: You can't give in to children's demands all the time.

demand.eng_def: a need for something to be sold or supplied
demand.eg: There was little demand for tickets.

demand.eng_def: the difficult things that you have to do
demand.eg: The demands of nursing are too great for a lot of people.

democracy.eng_def: the belief in freedom and equality between people, or a system of government based on this belief, in which power is either held by elected representatives or directly by the people themselves
democracy.chi_def: 民主；民主思想；民主政體
democracy.eg: The government has promised to uphold the principles of democracy.

democracy.eng_def: a country in which power is held by elected representatives
democracy.eg: Few of the Western democracies still have a royal family.

democrat.eng_def: a person who believes in democracy
in the US, a member or supporter of the Democratic Party
democrat.chi_def: （美國）民主黨黨員；民主黨支持者

democratic.eng_def: based on the principles of democracy
democratic.eg: We must accept the results of a democratic election (= an election in which all people can vote).

demonstrate.eng_def: to show or make make something clear
demonstrate.eg: These numbers clearly demonstrate the size of the economic problem facing the country.

demonstrate.eng_def: to show something and explain how it works
demonstrate.eg: He got a job demonstrating kitchen equipment in a department store.

demonstrate.eng_def: to express or show that you have a particular feeling, quality, or ability
demonstrate.eg: He has demonstrated a genuine interest in the project.

demonstrate.eng_def: to make a public expression that you are not satisfied about something, especially by marching or having a meeting
demonstrate.eg: Thousands of people gathered to demonstrate against the new proposals.

demonstration.eng_def: the act of showing someone how to do something, or how something works
demonstration.eg: This disaster is a clear demonstration of the need for tighter controls.

demonstration.eng_def: an occasion when a group of people march or stand together to show that they disagree with or support something or someone
demonstration.eg: The students are holding a demonstration against the proposed changes.

demonstration.eng_def: a way of expressing a feeling or a quality
demonstration.eg: Huge crowds followed the funeral procession in a public demonstration of grief.

denial.eng_def: a statement that something is not true or does not exist
denial.eg: The CEO issued a denial of the report that she is about to resign.

denial.eng_def: a statement that someone has not done something
the fact of not allowing someone to do or have something
an unwillingness to accept that something unpleasant is true
denial.eg: He's still in denial about the break-up of his relationship.

denial.eng_def: the situation in which someone behaves in a way that goes against their beliefs and what they think is right
denial.eg: If I did what you ask, it would be a denial of everything I stand for (= believe in).

denounce.eng_def: to criticize something or someone strongly and publicly
denounce.eg: The government's economic policy has been denounced on all sides.

denounce.eng_def: to accuse someone publicly of being something that is bad or wrong
denounce.eg: His former colleagues have denounced him as a spy.

dense.eng_def: having parts that are close together so that it is difficult to go or see through

dense.eg: There are some really dense people in our class.

dense.eng_def: (of a substance) containing a lot of matter in a small space

density.eng_def: the number of people or things in a place when compared with the size of the place
density.eg: The area has a high/low population density.

density.eng_def: the relationship between the mass of a substance and its size

dental.eng_def: a speech sound in which your tongue touches your front teeth
dental.chi_def: （舌頭與牙齒摩擦發出的）齒音

dentist.eng_def: a person whose job is treating people's teeth
dentist.eg: You should have your teeth checked by a dentist at least twice a year.

dentist.eng_def: the place where a dentist carries out their job
dentist.eg: I've got to go to the dentist's on Friday.

deny.eng_def: to say that something is not true
deny.eg: He will not confirm or deny the allegations.
There's no denying that this has been a difficult year for the company.

deny.eng_def: to not allow someone to have or do something
deny.eg: Her request for time off work was denied.

deny.eng_def: to not admit that you have knowledge, responsibility, feelings, etc.
deny.eg: He denied all responsibility for the rumours which have been circulating.

deny.eng_def: to not allow yourself to have or do things
deny.eg: Many parents deny themselves so that their children can have the best.

deny.eng_def: to refuse to admit that you have any connection with something or someone
deny.chi_def: 不承認與（某人或物）有關係
deny.eg: She has denied her family and refuses to have any contact with them.

depart.eng_def: to go away or leave, especially on a journey

department.eng_def: a part of an organization such as a school, business, or government that deals with a particular area of study or work
department.chi_def: （組織或機構中的）部，系，處，科，室
department.eg: the chemistry department/the department of chemistry

departure.eng_def: the fact of a person or vehicle, etc. leaving somewhere
departure.chi_def: （人、交通工具等）離開；啟程，出發
departure.eg: There are several departures (= buses, trains, or aircraft leaving) for Paris every day.

departure.eng_def: the act of leaving a job
departure.eg: Everyone in the office was surprised by Graham's sudden departure.

departure.eng_def: a change from what is expected, or from what has happened before
departure.eg: There can be no departure from the rules.

depend.eng_def: to be decided by or to change according to the stated thing
depend.eg: Whether or not we go to Mexico for our holiday depends on the cost.

depend.chi_def: 看情況再決定，看情況再說
depend.eg: "Are you going to Emma's party?" "I don't know, it depends - we might be going away that weekend."

dependable.eng_def: If someone or something is dependable, you can have confidence in him, her, or it.
dependable.chi_def: 可以信賴的，可以信任的
dependable.eg: I need someone dependable to take care of the children while I'm at work.

dependent.eng_def: needing the support of something or someone in order to continue existing or operating
dependent.chi_def: 需要供養的，需要照料的；依賴的

dependent.eg: Whether I get into college or not is dependent on how good my grades are.

depict.eng_def: to represent or show something in a picture or story
depict.eg: Her paintings depict the lives of ordinary people in the last century.

deposit.eg: The flood waters fell, depositing mud over the whole area.

deposit.eng_def: to put something valuable, especially money, in a bank or safe (= strong box or cupboard with locks)
deposit.chi_def: （在銀行或保險箱中）存放，儲存（尤指金錢）
deposit.eg: There's a night safe outside the bank, so you can deposit money whenever you wish.

deposit.eng_def: to pay someone an amount of money when you make an agreement with that person to pay for or buy something, that either will be returned to you later, if the agreed arrangement is kept, or that forms part of the total payment
deposit.chi_def: 支付（押金、訂金或預繳費用）
deposit.eg: When we moved in, we had to deposit $1,000 with the landlord in case we broke any of his things.

deposit.eng_def: a substance or layer that is left, usually after a liquid is removed
deposit.eg: Decant the wine carefully, so that you leave the deposit in the bottom of the bottle.

deposit.eng_def: a layer that has formed under the ground, especially over a long period
a payment, especially into a bank account
deposit.eg: To open an account, you need to make a minimum deposit of $500.

deposit.eng_def: an amount of money that you pay as the first part of the total payment for something
deposit.eg: The shop assistant says if I leave £10 as a deposit, they'll keep the dress for me.

deposit.eng_def: an amount of money that you pay when you rent something, and is returned to you when you return the thing you have rented
deposit.eg: It costs $2,000 a week to rent the yacht, with a $200 refundable/returnable deposit.

depress.eng_def: to cause someone to feel unhappy and without hope
to reduce the value of something, especially money
depress.eg: A surplus of corn has helped depress the grain market/grain prices.

depress.eng_def: to reduce the amount of activity in something, especially a business operation
depress.eg: High interest rates are continuing to depress the economy.

depress.eng_def: to lower the level or amount of something
depress.eg: This drug helps depress high hormone levels.

depression.eng_def: the state of feeling very unhappy and without hope for the future
depression.eg: I was overwhelmed by feelings of depression.

depression.eng_def: a mental illness in which a person is very unhappy and anxious (= worried and nervous) for long periods and cannot have a normal life during these periods
depression.eg: Tiredness, loss of appetite, and sleeping problems are all classic symptoms of depression.

depression.eng_def: a period in which there is very little business activity and not many jobs
depression.eg: The stock market crash marked the start of a severe depression.

depression.eng_def: an area where the air pressure is low
depression.eg: The deep depression over the mid-Atlantic will gradually move eastwards during the day.

depression.eng_def: part of a surface that is slightly lower than the rest
depression.eg: There was a depression in the sand where he'd been lying.

deprive.eng_def: to take something, especially something necessary or pleasant, away from someone
deprive.eg: He claimed that he had been deprived of his freedom/rights.

depth.eng_def: the distance down either from the top of something to the bottom, or to a distance below the top surface of something
the lowest part of the sea
depth.eg: The ship sank slowly to the depths of the ocean.

depth.eng_def: the state of having serious qualities or the ability to think seriously about something
depth.eg: Terry lacks depth - he's a very superficial person.

depth.eng_def: in a serious and detailed way
depth.eg: I'd like to look at this question in some depth.

depth.eng_def: the distance from the front to the back of something
depth.eg: Measure the depth of the cupboard/shelf.

depth.eng_def: the fact of a feeling, state, or characteristic being strong, extreme, or detailed
depth.chi_def: （情感、狀態、特性等的）深度，力度，強度
depth.eg: He spoke with great depth of feeling.

depth.eng_def: experiencing an extreme and negative emotion
depth.chi_def: 處於極為…的消極情緒之中
depth.eg: He was in the depths of despair/depression about losing his job.

depth.eng_def: during the worst period of a bad situation
depth.eg: The company was started in the depth of the recession of the 1930s.

depth.eng_def: the quality of having a low sound
depth.eg: The depth of his voice makes him sound older than he is.

depth.eng_def: the fact of something, especially a colour, having the quality of being dark and strong
depth.eg: I love the depth of colour in her early paintings.

deputy.eng_def: a person who is given the power to do something instead of another person, or the person whose rank is immediately below that of the leader of an organization
deputy.eg: I'd like you to meet Ann Gregory, my deputy.

derive.eng_def: to get something from something else
derive.eg: The institute derives all its money from foreign investments.

descend.eg: The path descended steeply into the valley.

descend.eng_def: If darkness or night descends, it becomes dark and day changes to night.
If a negative or bad feeling descends, it is felt everywhere in a place or by everyone at the same time.
descend.eg: A feeling of despair descended (on us) as we realized that we were lost.

descend.eng_def: If a condition, usually a negative condition, descends, it quickly develops in every part of a place.
descend.eg: Silence descended on the room/over the countryside.

descendant.eng_def: a person who is related to you and who lives after you, such as your child or grandchild

descent.eng_def: the state or fact of being related to a particular person or group of people who lived in the past
descent.chi_def: 血緣關係，家族關係；祖先；出身
descent.eg: She's a woman of mixed/French descent.

descent.eng_def: an occasion when a group of people arrive somewhere, usually suddenly or unexpectedly
descent.eg: We weren't prepared for the descent of thousands of journalists on the town.
The plane began (to make) its final descent into the airport.

descent.eng_def: a change in someone's behaviour, or in a situation, from good to bad
descent.eg: His descent into crime was rapid.

describe.eng_def: to say or write what someone or something is like
If you describe a shape, you draw it or move in a direction that follows the line of it.
describe.eg: He used compasses to describe a circle.

description.eng_def: something that tells you what something or someone is like
description.eg: Write a description of your favourite beach.
Boats of every description were entering the harbour.

description.eng_def: to be something that you cannot describe accurately because of its great size, quality, or level

descriptive.eng_def: describing something, especially in a detailed, interesting way
A descriptive area of study is one that is based on saying what its subject is really like, rather than on developing theories about it.

desert.eng_def: an area, often covered with sand or rocks, where there is very little rain and not many plants
desert.eg: They were lost in the desert for nine days.

desert.eng_def: a place that is considered to have no cultural, intellectual, etc. quality or interest
desert.eg: This town is a cultural desert.

desert.eng_def: to leave the armed forces without permission and with no intention of returning
desert.chi_def: 開小差，當逃兵；擅離（部隊）
desert.eg: Soldiers who deserted and were caught were shot.

desert.eng_def: to leave someone without help or in a difficult situation and not come back
desert.eg: He deserted his wife and family for another woman.

desert.eng_def: If a quality deserts you, you suddenly and temporarily lose it.
desert.eg: All my confidence/courage deserted me when I walked into the exam.

deserve.eng_def: to have earned or to be given something because of the way you have behaved or the qualities you have
deserve.eg: After all that hard work, you deserve a holiday.

design.eng_def: to make or draw plans for something, for example clothes or buildings

design.eg: This dictionary is designed for advanced learners of English.

design.eng_def: a drawing or set of drawings showing how a building or product is to be made and how it will work and look
design.eg: Have you seen the designs for the new shopping centre?

design.eng_def: the art of making plans or drawings for something
design.eg: She's an expert on kitchen/software design.

design.eng_def: the way in which something is planned and made
design.eg: I don't like the design of this sofa.

design.eng_def: a pattern used to decorate something

design.eg: I'm sure he ignored you by accident and not by design.

design.eng_def: plans, often ones that are not honest, to get something or someone for yourself
design.eg: to have territorial designs (on neighbouring countries)

designate.eng_def: to choose someone officially to do a particular job
designate.eg: Traditionally, the president designates his or her successor.

designate.eng_def: to say officially that a place or thing has a particular character or purpose
designate.eg: This area of the park has been specially designated for children.

designate.eng_def: used after the title of a particular official job to refer to someone chosen to do that job, but who has not yet started doing it
designate.chi_def: （用於職務名稱後）新選定的，新指定的，新任命的

designer.eng_def: a person who imagines how something could be made and draws plans for it
made by a famous or fashionable designer
designer.chi_def: 出自著名設計師的，名師設計的

desirable.eng_def: worth having and wanted by most people
desirable.chi_def: 值得擁有的；渴望獲得的，令人嚮往的
desirable.eg: Reducing class sizes in schools is a desirable aim.

desire.eg: I desire only to be left in peace.

desire.eng_def: to have a strong sexual attraction to someone
a strong feeling that you want something
desire.eg: I certainly have no desire to have children.

desire.eng_def: the strong feeling that you want to have sex with someone

desk.eng_def: a type of table that you can work at, often one with drawers
desk.chi_def: （常指帶抽屜的）書桌，辦公桌，寫字枱

desk.eng_def: a place, often with a counter (= a long flat narrow surface) especially in a hotel or airport, where you can get information or service
desk.chi_def: （尤指飯店或機場的）服務臺，詢問處

desk.eng_def: an office that deals with a particular type of news for a newspaper or broadcasting company
desk.chi_def: （報館或廣播公司負責某一類新聞的）辦公室，部，室，組

despair.eng_def: the feeling that there is no hope and that you can do nothing to improve a difficult or worrying situation
to cause someone such difficulties that they do not know how to deal with you
despair.eg: He's the despair of his parents because he shows no interest in getting a job.

despair.eng_def: to feel despair about something or someone
despair.eg: Don't despair! We'll find a way out!

desperate.chi_def: 非常嚴重的；非常糟糕的

desperate.eg: The earthquake survivors are in desperate need of help.

desperate.eng_def: needing or wanting something very much
desperate.chi_def: 非常需要的；非常想要的

desperate.eng_def: feeling that you have no hope and are ready to do anything to change the bad situation you are in
desperate.chi_def: （因絕望而）拼命的，不顧一切的
desperate.eg: The doctors made one last desperate attempt/effort to save the boy's life.

desperate.eng_def: willing to be violent, and therefore dangerous
desperate.eg: This man is desperate and should not be approached since he may have a gun.

despise.eng_def: to feel a strong dislike for someone or something because you think that that person or thing is bad or has no value
despise.eg: The two groups despise each other.

despite.eng_def: without taking any notice of or being influenced by; not prevented by
despite.eg: I still enjoyed the week despite the weather.

despite.eng_def: If you do something despite yourself, you do it although you do not want to or although you know you should not.

dessert.eng_def: sweet food eaten at the end of a meal

destination.eng_def: the place where someone is going or where something is being sent or taken
destination.eg: We arrived at our destination tired and hungry.

destined.eg: The money was destined for the relief of poverty, but was diverted by corrupt officials.

destined.eng_def: travelling or being sent to somewhere
destined.chi_def: 前往（某地）的；寄往（某地）的
destined.eg: Customs officers have seized nearly a ton of heroin destined for New York.

destined.eng_def: controlled by fate, and not by humans
destined.chi_def: 命中註定的，命運決定的
destined.eg: She is destined for an extremely successful career.

destiny.eng_def: the things that will happen in the future
destiny.eg: The destiny of our nation depends on this vote!

destiny.eng_def: the force that some people think controls what happens in the future, and is outside human control

destroy.eng_def: to damage something so badly that it cannot be used
destroy.eg: Most of the old part of the city was destroyed by bombs during the war.

destroy.eng_def: to kill an animal because it is ill, in pain, or dangerous
destroy.chi_def: 宰殺，滅殺，殺死（被病痛折磨或危險的動物）

destruction.eng_def: the act of destroying something, or the fact of being destroyed
destruction.eg: Many people are very concerned about the destruction of the rainforests.

destructive.eng_def: causing, or able to cause, damage
destructive.eg: the destructive power of nuclear weapons

detach.eng_def: to separate or remove something from something else that it is connected to
detach.eg: You can detach the hood if you prefer the coat without it.

detail.eng_def: a single piece of information or fact about something
detail.eg: She insisted on telling me every single detail of what they did to her in hospital.
A police officer took down the details of what happened.

detail.eng_def: the small features of something that you only notice when you look carefully
detail.eg: I was just admiring the detail in the doll's house - even the tins of food have labels on them.

detail.eng_def: including or considering all the information about something or every part of something
detail.eg: We haven't discussed the matter in detail yet.

detail.eng_def: to tell or include all the facts about something
detail.eg: I won't go into detail over the phone, but I've been having a few health problems recently.

detail.eng_def: a part of something that does not seem important
detail.chi_def: 細枝末節，無足輕重的小事
detail.eg: Tony says, he's going to get the car, and finding the money to pay for it is just a minor detail.

detail.eng_def: a group of people who have been given a particular task
to describe something completely, giving all the facts
detail.eg: Can you produce a report detailing what we've spent on the project so far?

detail.eng_def: to order someone, often a small group of soldiers or workers, to perform a particular task
detail.eg: Four soldiers were detailed to check the road for troops.

detain.eng_def: to force someone officially to stay in a place
detain.eg: A suspect has been detained by the police for questioning.

detain.eng_def: to delay someone for a short length of time
detain.eg: I'm sorry I'm late - I was unavoidably detained.

detain.eng_def: to keep someone in prison for as long as the courts feel is necessary

detect.eng_def: to notice something that is partly hidden or not clear, or to discover something, especially using a special method
detect.chi_def: （尤指用特殊方法）發現，察覺，看出
detect.eg: Some sounds cannot be detected by the human ear.

detect.eng_def: to discover something, usually using special equipment
detect.chi_def: （通常指用特別設備）探測，檢測，測出
detect.eg: High levels of lead were detected in the atmosphere.

detective.eng_def: someone whose job is to discover information about crimes and find out who is responsible for them
used as part of the title of particular ranks in the police force
detective.chi_def: 警探（用於某些級別的員警頭銜）

deter.eng_def: to prevent someone from doing something or to make someone less enthusiastic about doing something by making it difficult for that person to do it or by threatening bad results if they do it
deter.eg: These measures are designed to deter an enemy attack.

deteriorate.eg: She was taken into hospital last week when her condition suddenly deteriorated.

devalue.eng_def: to reduce the rate at which money can be exchanged for foreign money
devalue.eg: Last year Mexico was forced to devalue the peso.

devalue.eng_def: to cause someone or something to be considered less valuable or important
devalue.eg: I don't want to devalue his achievement, but he managed to get a promotion without working very hard.

develop.eng_def: to (cause something to) grow or change into a more advanced, larger, or stronger form
develop.eg: It became clear that he wasn't developing like all the other little boys.

develop.eng_def: to invent something or bring something into existence
develop.eg: We have to develop a new policy/strategy to deal with the problem.

develop.eng_def: to start to happen or exist
develop.eg: Large cracks began to develop in the wall.

develop.eng_def: If you develop an illness or problem, or if it develops, you start to suffer from it.
develop.chi_def: 患上，患（病）；逐漸形成（疾病或問題）
develop.eg: The study showed that one in twelve women is likely to develop breast cancer.

develop.eng_def: to build houses, factories, etc. on a piece of land
develop.eg: They're planning to develop the whole site into a shopping complex.

develop.eng_def: to make photographs or negatives from a film
develop.eg: We developed some old negatives from my parents' wedding day.

development.eng_def: the process in which someone or something grows or changes and becomes more advanced
a recent event that is the latest in a series of related events
development.eg: an important development in the fuel crisis

development.eng_def: the process of developing something new
development.eg: Mr Berkowitz is in charge of product development.

development.eng_def: an area on which new buildings are built in order to make a profit

device.eng_def: an object or machine that has been invented for a particular purpose
a method that is used to produce a particular effect
device.chi_def: （以期達到某種特定效果的）方法，手段

devil.eng_def: an evil being, often represented in human form but with a tail and horns
a powerful evil force and the enemy of God in Christianity and Judaism
devil.chi_def: （基督教和猶太教中與上帝為敵的）魔鬼，撒旦

devil.eng_def: someone, especially a child, who behaves badly
devil.chi_def: 壞蛋，淘氣鬼，搗蛋鬼（尤指孩子）
devil.eg: Those little/young devils broke my window.

devil.eng_def: a person who enjoys doing things people might disapprove of
devil.chi_def: 鬼東西，死鬼（指故意做人們不喜歡的事情的人）
devil.eg: "I'm going to wear a short black skirt and thigh-length boots." "Ooh, you devil!"

devil.eng_def: used with an adjective to describe someone and express your opinion about something that has happened to them
devil.chi_def: （與形容詞連用表示對某人的看法）人，傢夥
devil.eg: I hear you've got a new car, you lucky devil!

devise.eng_def: to invent a plan, system, object, etc., usually using your intelligence or imagination
devise.chi_def: 巧妙構思；巧妙設計；發明
devise.eg: He's good at devising language games that you can play with students in class.

devotion.eng_def: loyalty and love or care for someone or something
devotion.eg: He inspired respect and devotion from his pupils.

devotion.eng_def: acts of religious worship, especially prayers

devour.eng_def: to eat something eagerly and in large amounts so that nothing is left
devour.eg: The young cubs hungrily devoured the deer.
The flames quickly devoured the building.

devour.eng_def: to read books or literature quickly and eagerly
devour.eg: She loves to read - she devours one book after another.

dew.eng_def: drops of water that form on the ground and other surfaces outside during the night

diabetes.eng_def: a disease in which the body cannot control the level of sugar in the blood

diagnose.eng_def: to recognize and name the exact character of a disease or a problem, by examining it

diagnosis.eng_def: a judgment about what a particular illness or problem is, made after examining it
diagnosis.eg: "What was the diagnosis?" "Arthritis in both joints."

diagram.eng_def: a simple plan that represents a machine, system, or idea, etc., often drawn to explain how it works
diagram.eg: The teacher drew a diagram showing how the blood flows through the heart.

diagram.chi_def: 用圖解的方式，以畫圖的方式
diagram.eg: She explained the whole problem diagrammatically.

dial.eng_def: to operate a phone or make a phone call to someone by choosing a particular series of numbers on the phone
dial.eg: Can I dial this number direct, or do I have to go through the operator?

dial.eng_def: the part of a machine or device that shows you a measurement of something such as speed or time
dial.eg: Can you read what it says on the dial?

dial.eng_def: a device on an instrument that you move in order to control it or make changes to it
dial.eg: You turn this dial to find a different radio station.

dial.eng_def: the disc with numbers on old-fashioned phones that you turn when you make a call

dialect.eng_def: a form of a language that people speak in a particular part of a country, containing some different words and grammar, etc.

dialogue.eng_def: conversation that is written for a book, play, or film
dialogue.eg: The play contained some very snappy/witty dialogue.

dialogue.eng_def: formal talks between opposing countries, political groups, etc.
dialogue.chi_def: （敵對國家、政治團體間的）對話
dialogue.eg: The rebel leaders stated that they are willing to enter into dialogue with the government.

diameter.eng_def: (the length of) a straight line that reaches from one point on the edge of a round shape or object, through its centre, to a point on the opposite edge
diameter.eg: The diameter measures twice the radius.

diamond.eng_def: a transparent, extremely hard precious stone that is used in jewellery, and in industry for cutting hard things
diamond.eg: The tiara was set with diamonds and rubies.
Shall I wear the diamonds or the pearls with this dress?

diamond.eng_def: a shape with four straight sides of equal length, forming two opposite angles that are wide and two that are narrow
diamond.eg: Joe's socks had diamond patterns on them.

diamond.eng_def: the square part of a field on which baseball is played, surrounded by the four bases, or the whole field on which the game is played
one of the four suits in playing cards, represented by a red diamond shape
a playing card from the suit of diamonds

diaper.eng_def: a square of thick soft paper or cloth that is fastened around a baby's bottom and between its legs to absorb its urine and solid waste

diary.eng_def: a book in which you record your thoughts or feelings or what has happened each day
diary.eg: While in hiding, Anne Frank kept a diary.

diary.eng_def: a book with a separate space or page for each day, in which you write down your future arrangements, meetings, etc.
diary.eg: Don't forget to write/enter the date of the meeting in your diary.

dictate.eng_def: to give orders, or tell someone exactly what they must do, with total authority
dictate.eg: The UN will dictate the terms of troop withdrawal from the region.

dictate.eng_def: to influence something or make it necessary
dictate.eg: The party's change of policy has been dictated by its need to win back younger voters.

dictate.eng_def: to speak something aloud for a person or machine to record what is said, so that it can be written down
dictate.eg: I dictated my order over the phone.

dictate.eng_def: an order that should be obeyed, often one that you give to yourself

dictation.eng_def: the activity of dictating something for someone else to write down
dictation.eg: I'll ask my assistant to take dictation (= write down what I say).

dictation.eng_def: a test in which a piece of writing is dictated to students learning a foreign language, to test their ability to hear and write the language correctly
dictation.eg: Our French dictation lasted half an hour.

dictator.eng_def: a leader who has complete power in a country and has not been elected by the people
a person who gives orders and behaves as if they have complete power
dictator.eg: My boss is kind of a dictator.

dictionary.eng_def: a book that contains a list of words in alphabetical order and that explains their meanings, or gives a word for them in another language; a similar product for use on a computer
a book that gives information about a particular subject, in which the entries (= words or phrases) are given in alphabetical order

die.eng_def: to stop living or existing, either suddenly or slowly
die.eg: Twelve people died in the accident.

die.eng_def: If a machine, battery, or phone dies, it stops working, usually because it has no power.
die.chi_def: （通常因為沒有電而）停止運轉，報廢
die.eg: The engine just died on us.

die.eng_def: a shaped piece or mould (= hollow container) made of metal or other hard material, used to shape or put a pattern on metal or plastic
a small cube (= object with six equal square sides) with a different number of spots on each side, used in games involving chance

diet.eng_def: the food and drink usually eaten or drunk by a person or group
diet.eg: Diet varies between different countries in the world.

diet.eng_def: an eating plan in which someone eats less food, or only particular types of food, because they want to become thinner or for medical reasons
diet.eg: I'm going on a diet next week and hope to lose ten pounds before Christmas.

diet.eng_def: a particular type of thing that you experience or do regularly, or a limited range of activities
diet.chi_def: 程式，套路；有限的幾種活動
diet.eg: He was brought up on a diet of political propaganda from birth.

diet.eng_def: Diet food or drink contains less sugar or fat than the usual type, and often contains an artificial sweetener.
diet.chi_def: （食物或飲品）健康的，低脂的，低糖的

diet.eng_def: to limit the food and/or drink that you have, especially in order to lose weight
diet.chi_def: （尤指為減肥而）節食，控制飲食
diet.eg: You should be able to reduce your weight by careful dieting.

differ.eng_def: to be not like something or someone else, either physically or in another way
differ.chi_def: 與…不同，跟…不一樣，有區別
differ.eg: The twins look alike, but they differ in temperament.
Economists differ on the cause of inflation.

difference.eng_def: the way in which two or more things which you are comparing are not the same
difference.eg: What's the difference between an ape and a monkey?
Exercise can make a big difference to your state of health.

difference.eng_def: to not change a situation in any way
difference.eg: You can ask him again if you want, but it won't make any difference - he'll still say no.

difference.eng_def: used to say that something is unusual, and more interesting or better than other things of the same type
difference.chi_def: 與眾不同，不同尋常，別具一格，更勝一籌
difference.eg: Try new Cremetti - the ice cream with a difference.
They had a terrible argument a few weeks ago, but now they've settled/resolved their differences.
They had a difference of opinion about/over their child's education.

difference.eng_def: the amount by which one thing is different from another

different.chi_def: 不同的，不一樣的，有差別的
different.eg: She seems to wear something different every day.

different.eng_def: used when you think someone or something is unusual or shows bad judgment
different.chi_def: 不同尋常的，另類的；品位差的
different.eg: What do I think of your purple shoes? Well, they're certainly different.

differentiate.eng_def: to show or find the difference between things that are compared
differentiate.eg: We do not differentiate between our employees on the basis of their race, religion, or national origin.

differentiate.eng_def: to make someone or something different
differentiate.eg: The slate roof differentiates this house from others in the area.

difficult.eng_def: not friendly, easy to deal with, or behaving well
difficult.chi_def: 不友好的；難以接近的；難對付的；沒教養的
difficult.eg: The manager is difficult to deal with/a difficult person to deal with.

difficulty.eng_def: the fact of not being easy to do or understand
difficulty.eg: We finished the job, but only with great difficulty.

difficulty.eng_def: to have problems or be in a difficult situation
difficulty.chi_def: 遇到問題；有難處，處於困境
difficulty.eg: A ship is in difficulties off the coast of Ireland.

dig.eng_def: to break up and move soil using a tool, a machine, or your hands
dig.eg: Digging (in) the garden is good exercise.

dig.eng_def: to form a hole by moving soil
dig.eg: The tunnel was dug with the aid of heavy machinery.

dig.eng_def: to search somewhere when you are looking for an object or information
dig.eg: He dug into his pocket and took out a few coins.

dig.eng_def: to push the side of someone's body quickly with your elbow (= the middle part of the arm where it bends) often as a way of sharing a private joke with that person or to get their attention
dig.chi_def: 用肘部碰…的肋部（常用來分享私密笑話或引起對方注意）

dig.eg: Hey, I really dig those shoes!

dig.eng_def: a remark that is intended to criticize, embarrass, or make a joke about someone
dig.eg: He's always taking digs/a dig at me.

dig.eng_def: the process of carefully removing soil and objects from an area of historical interest

dig.eg: Many students in London have to live in digs.

digest.eng_def: to change food in your stomach into substances that your body can use
digest.eg: I find that I don't digest meat easily.

digest.eng_def: to read or hear new information and take the necessary time to understand it
digest.eg: This chapter is so difficult to digest, I'll have to read it again later.

digest.eng_def: a short written report providing the most important parts of a larger piece of writing, or one containing recent news
digest.eg: A digest of the research findings is now available.

digestion.eng_def: the process by which your body digests food, or your ability to digest food
digestion.eg: Discover how eating raw food helps balance your body and aids digestion.

digital.eng_def: recording or storing information as series of the numbers 1 and 0, to show that a signal is present or absent
digital.chi_def: （用一串分別代表信號正負的數字1和0來記錄或存儲資訊）數位的

digital.eng_def: using or relating to digital signals and computer technology
digital.chi_def: （採用或與數位信號和電腦技術相關）數位的，數字的

digital.eng_def: showing information in the form of an electronic image
digital.chi_def: （用電子影像顯示資訊）數位式的

dignity.eng_def: calm, serious, and controlled behaviour that makes people respect you
dignity.eg: He is a man of dignity and calm determination.

dignity.eng_def: the importance and value that a person has, that makes other people respect them or makes them respect themselves
dignity.eg: How could you wear something so indecent? Have you no dignity?

dilemma.eng_def: a situation in which a difficult choice has to be made between two different things you could do
dilemma.eg: The president is clearly in a dilemma about/over how to tackle the crisis.

diligence.eng_def: action that is considered reasonable for people to be expected to take in order to keep themselves or others and their property safe
diligence.chi_def: （為保證自身、他人或財產安全而採取的）審慎行為
diligence.eg: People have to exercise due diligence and watch what's being bought on their credit cards.

diligence.eng_def: the detailed examination of a company and its financial records, done before becoming involved in a business arrangement with it
diligence.chi_def: （与某公司有业务往来之前对其本身以及其财务状况进行的）必要核计，必要了解

diligent.eng_def: careful and using a lot of effort
diligent.chi_def: 認真刻苦的，勤奮的，勤勞的

diligent.eng_def: done in a careful and detailed way
diligent.eg: The discovery was made after years of diligent research.

dim.eng_def: not giving or having much light
dim.chi_def: 光線暗的，暗淡的，昏暗的
dim.eg: The lamp gave out a dim light.

dim.eng_def: If your eyes are dim, you cannot see very well.
something that you remember slightly, but not very well
dim.eg: I had a dim recollection of having met her before.
He's a nice guy, but a little dim.
The company's prospects for the future are rather dim.

dim.eng_def: to (make a positive feeling or quality) become less strong
dim.eg: Our hopes/expectations dimmed as the hours passed.

dime.eng_def: an American or Canadian coin that has the value of ten cents

dimension.eng_def: a measurement of something in a particular direction, especially its height, length, or width
dimension.eg: Please specify the dimensions (= the height, length and width) of the room.

dimension.eng_def: a part or feature or way of considering something

diminish.eng_def: to reduce or be reduced in size or importance
diminish.eg: I don't want to diminish her achievements, but she did have a lot of help.

dine.eng_def: to eat the main meal of the day, usually in the evening

dinner.eng_def: the main meal of the day, usually the meal you eat in the evening but sometimes, in Britain, the meal eaten in the middle of the day
dinner.chi_def: 正餐（通常指晚餐，在英國有時指午餐）

dinner.eng_def: a formal social occasion in the evening at which a meal is served
dinner.eg: They held a dinner to celebrate his retirement.

dinosaur.eng_def: a type of reptile that became extinct about 65,000,000 years ago. There were many different types of dinosaur, some of which were extremely large.
an old-fashioned person or thing that people no longer consider to be useful
dinosaur.chi_def: 老古董（指過時的人或物）
dinosaur.eg: This computer's a dinosaur, isn't it?

dip.eng_def: to put something into a liquid for a short time
dip.eg: Dip the fish in the batter, then drop it into the hot oil.

dip.eng_def: to put sheep for a short time into a container of liquid containing chemicals that kill harmful insects on the sheep's bodies
dip.chi_def: 給（羊）洗藥浴（以殺死身上對其有害的蟲類）

dip.eng_def: to go down to a lower level
dip.eg: As you turn the corner, the road dips suddenly.

dip.eng_def: to make the beam from the lights at the front of a vehicle point down
dip.chi_def: 使（車輛前燈）向下照，把（前燈）調為近光
dip.eg: You'll dazzle oncoming drivers if you don't dip your headlights.

dip.eng_def: a cold, thick sauce that you eat by dipping pieces of uncooked vegetable or biscuits, etc. into it
a special liquid used for cleaning, etc.
a part of something that is at a lower level or a movement to a lower level
a short time spent considering a subject
dip.eg: We begin our dip into local history by examining the town's origins.

diploma.eng_def: a document given by a college or university to show that you have passed a particular exam or finished your studies

diplomacy.eng_def: the management of relationships between countries
diplomacy.eg: Diplomacy has so far failed to bring an end to the fighting.

diplomacy.eng_def: skill in dealing with people without offending or upsetting them
diplomacy.eg: It took all her tact and diplomacy to persuade him not to resign.

diplomat.eng_def: an official whose job is to represent one country in another, and who usually works in an embassy
a person who is skilled at dealing with difficult situations in a way that does not offend people
diplomat.chi_def: 善於社交的人，會與人打交道的人

diplomatic.eng_def: involving diplomats or the management of the relationships between countries
acting in a way that does not cause offence

direct.eng_def: going in a straight line towards somewhere or someone without stopping or changing direction
without anyone or anything else being involved or between
direct.eg: She decided to take direct control of the project.

direct.eng_def: strong light or heat that has nothing protecting and separating you from it
direct.eg: This plant should be kept out of direct sunlight.

direct.eng_def: a relation who is related to you through one of your parents, not through an aunt or uncle, etc.
direct.eg: Diana is a direct descendant of Robert Peel.

direct.eng_def: Someone who is direct says what they think in a very honest way without worrying about other people's opinions.
direct.eg: I like her open and direct manner.

direct.eng_def: in a straight line towards somewhere without stopping or changing direction
direct.eg: Does this bus go direct to the airport?

direct.eng_def: without anyone or anything else being involved or between
direct.eg: I intended to go direct to the manager with my complaint.

direct.eng_def: to control or be in charge of an activity, organization, etc.
to tell people the direction in which they must drive
direct.eg: There was a police officer directing the traffic.

direct.eng_def: to be in charge of a film or play and tell the actors how to play their parts
direct.eg: He wanted to give up acting and start directing (his own films).

direct.eng_def: to aim something in a particular direction
to tell someone how to get somewhere
direct.eg: Could you direct me to the airport?
The judge directed the defendant to remain silent.

direct.eng_def: without having to stop or change direction
direct.eg: Does this train go direct to Edinburgh?

direct.eng_def: without anything or anyone else being involved or in between
direct.eg: Can I dial this number direct or do I have to go through the switchboard?

direction.eng_def: the position towards which someone or something moves or faces
direction.eg: "No, go that way," I said, pointing in the opposite direction.

direction.eng_def: instructions that you give to someone about how to find a particular place
direction.eg: Can you give me directions to your house?

direction.eng_def: the area or position that someone is in
direction.eg: She keeps looking in my direction.

direction.eng_def: the ability to find places or to know which direction to go

direction.eg: The project was under the direction of a well-known academic.

direction.eng_def: information or orders telling you what to do
direction.eg: I couldn't understand the directions on the packet.

direction.eng_def: the way that someone or something changes or develops
direction.eg: There is disagreement over the direction the project is taking.

director.eng_def: a manager of an organization, company, college, etc.
someone in charge of a school for very young children
a person who is in charge of a film or play and tells the actors how to play their parts

directory.eng_def: a book that gives a list of names, addresses, or other facts

dirt.eng_def: dust, soil, or any substance that makes a surface not clean
dirt.eg: His coat was covered with dirt.
I've been digging in the dirt, planting seeds.
I got some dog dirt on my shoes.

dirt.eng_def: unpleasant or bad details about someone's private life that are repeated or published to influence people's opinion of them in a negative way
dirt.eg: Journalists are always digging for (= trying to discover) dirt.

dirty.eg: Her face was dirty and tear-stained.

dirty.chi_def: 不公平的；欺騙的；卑鄙的
dirty.eg: She played a dirty trick on me by telling me Diane was having a party when she wasn't.

dirty.eng_def: used to describe something that is connected with sex, in a way that many people think is offensive

dirty.eg: The old power station's nothing but a dirty great blot on the landscape.
Don't sit on the floor - you might dirty your dress.

disability.eng_def: an illness, injury, or condition that makes it difficult for someone to do the things that other people do

disable.eng_def: to cause someone to have an illness, injury, or condition that makes it difficult for them to do the things that other people do
disable.eg: She was disabled in the accident.

disable.eng_def: to stop something such as (part of) a machine, system, or weapon from working
disable.chi_def: 使發生故障，使失靈，使無法正常工作
disable.eg: This weapons system will destroy or disable any incoming missile.

disadvantage.eng_def: a condition or situation that causes problems, especially one that causes something or someone to be less successful than other things or people
disadvantage.eg: One disadvantage of living in the town is the lack of safe places for children to play.

disadvantage.eng_def: in a situation in which you are less likely to succeed than others
disadvantage.chi_def: 處於劣勢，處於不利地位
disadvantage.eg: He's at a disadvantage being so shy.

disadvantage.eng_def: to cause someone or something to be less successful than most other people or things
disadvantage.chi_def: 使處於劣勢，使處於不利地位
disadvantage.eg: Teachers claim such measures could unfairly disadvantage ethnic minorities.

disagree.eng_def: to not have the same opinion, idea, etc.
disagree.eg: I'm afraid I have to disagree with you (on that issue).

disagree.eng_def: If two or more statements, ideas, sets of numbers, etc. disagree, they are not the same.

disagreement.eng_def: an argument or a situation in which people do not have the same opinion
disagreement.eg: We had a disagreement about/over the fee for the work.

disappear.eng_def: If people or things disappear, they go somewhere where they cannot be seen or found.
disappear.eg: The search was called off for the sailors who disappeared in the storm.
These flowers are disappearing from our fields and woods.

disappoint.eng_def: to fail to satisfy someone or their hopes, wishes, etc., or to make someone feel unhappy
disappoint.eg: I'm sorry to disappoint you, but I'm afraid I can't come after all.

disappointment.eg: Get tickets early to avoid disappointment.

disappointment.eng_def: something or someone that is not what you were hoping it would be
disappointment.eg: The party turned out to be a huge disappointment.

disapprove.eng_def: to feel that something or someone is bad, wrong, etc.
disapprove.eg: The survey showed that 32 percent of respondents approve, 54 percent disapprove, and the rest are undecided.

disaster.eng_def: (an event that results in) great harm, damage, or death, or serious difficulty
disaster.eg: An inquiry was ordered into the recent rail disaster (= a serious train accident).

disaster.eng_def: to be very unsuccessful or extremely bad
disaster.eg: The evening was a complete disaster.

disastrous.chi_def: 極其糟糕的；極為失敗的；災難性的
disastrous.eg: Such a war would be disastrous for the country.

disbelief.eng_def: the feeling of not being able to believe that something is true or real
disbelief.eg: His response was one of complete disbelief.

disc.eg: The dog's name was engraved on a little metal disc attached to its collar.

disc.eng_def: a small piece of cartilage (= strong body tissue that stretches) between the bones in your back
a musical record or a compact disc

discard.eng_def: to throw something away or get rid of it because you no longer want or need it
discard.eg: Discarded food containers and bottles littered the streets.

discard.eng_def: to get rid of a card you are holding during a card game
in a card game, a card that you have got rid of

discharge.eng_def: to allow someone officially to leave somewhere, especially a hospital or a law court
discharge.chi_def: 允許…離開；（尤指）允許…出院；（根據法庭決議）釋放
discharge.eg: Patients were discharged from the hospital because the beds were needed by other people.

discharge.eng_def: to send out a substance, especially waste liquid or gas
discharge.chi_def: 排放，排出（尤指廢液或廢氣）
discharge.eg: Large amounts of dangerous waste are discharged daily by the factory.

discharge.eng_def: to perform a task, especially an official one
discharge.eg: The city must discharge its legal duty to house the homeless.

discharge.eng_def: to pay back a debt completely
to fire a gun, or to fire a shot from a gun
discharge.eg: The police stated that some 50 rounds had been discharged.

discharge.eng_def: official permission to leave the armed forces, a prison, or a hospital
discharge.chi_def: 獲官方允許離開（軍隊、監獄或醫院）
discharge.eg: The soldier received a dishonourable discharge for a disciplinary offence.

discharge.eng_def: the act of sending out waste liquid or gas
discharge.eg: Thousands of fish were killed as a result of a discharge of poisonous chemicals from a nearby factory.

discharge.eng_def: liquid matter that comes from a part of the body and is often infected
discharge.chi_def: （常指人體某一部分因感染而產生的）膿，液體分泌物

discharge.eng_def: the performance of duties or payment of money that is owed
the action of firing a gun

disciple.eng_def: a person who believes in the ideas and principles of someone famous and tries to live the way that person does or did
the twelve men who followed Jesus during his life

discipline.eng_def: training that makes people more willing to obey or more able to control themselves, often in the form of rules, and punishments if these are broken, or the behaviour produced by this training
the ability to control yourself or other people, even in difficult situations
discipline.eg: Maintaining classroom discipline (= control of the students) is the first task of every teacher.

discipline.eng_def: a particular area of study, especially a subject studied at a college or university
discipline.chi_def: （尤指大學或學院設立的）專業

discipline.eg: A senior army officer has been disciplined for revealing secret government plans to the media.

discipline.eng_def: to teach someone to behave in a controlled way
discipline.eg: I'm trying to discipline myself to eat less chocolate.

disclose.eng_def: to make something known publicly, or to show something that was hidden
disclose.eg: The company has disclosed profits of over £200 million.

disclosure.eng_def: the act of making something known or the fact that is made known
disclosure.eg: Any public disclosure of this information would be very damaging to the company.

disco.eng_def: an event where people dance to modern recorded music for entertainment, or a place where this often happens
disco.chi_def: 迪斯可舞會；迪斯可舞廳

disco.eng_def: a type of music, popular in the 1970s, that people dance to in a nightclub

discomfort.eng_def: a feeling of being uncomfortable physically or mentally, or something that causes this
discomfort.chi_def: 不適，不安；令人不適（或不安）的事物
discomfort.eg: You may feel a little discomfort for a few days after the operation.

disconnect.eng_def: to unfasten something, especially to break the connection between a supply of electricity, gas, water, etc. and a device or piece of equipment
disconnect.eg: Never try to fix a broken machine without disconnecting it from the electricity supply.

disconnect.eng_def: to stop supplying electricity/gas/water/phone services, especially because money has not been paid
disconnect.chi_def: （尤指因未繳費而）停止供應（電、氣、水、電話等其他服務）

disconnect.eng_def: If you are disconnected while speaking on the phone, the phone connection is suddenly broken and you can no longer continue your conversation.
disconnect.chi_def: 使（電話）斷線，將（電話）中斷

disconnect.eng_def: a situation in which two or more things are not connected in the way that they should be
disconnect.eg: The study found a disconnect between the state's social programs and some people who need government assistance.

discotheque.chi_def: 迪斯可舞會；迪斯可舞廳（同disco）

discount.eng_def: a reduction in the usual price
discount.eg: They usually give you a discount if you buy multiple copies.

discount.eng_def: to decide that something or someone is not worth considering or giving attention
discount.eg: You shouldn't discount the possibility of him coming back.

discount.eng_def: to reduce the price of something

discourage.eng_def: to make someone feel less confident, enthusiastic, and positive about something, or less willing to do something
discourage.chi_def: 使洩氣，給…潑冷水，使心灰意冷
discourage.eg: The thought of how much work she had to do discouraged her.

discourage.eng_def: to prevent or try to prevent something happening or someone doing something, by making things difficult or unpleasant, or by showing disapproval
discourage.eg: a campaign to discourage people from smoking

discouragement.eng_def: the state of having lost your confidence or enthusiasm for something
discouragement.chi_def: 洩氣，垂頭喪氣，心灰意冷

discouragement.eng_def: actions to prevent or try to prevent something from happening or someone from doing something
discouragement.eg: the discouragement of any direct action

discover.eng_def: to find information, a place, or an object, especially for the first time
to notice that a person has a special ability or quality and to help them to become successful
discover.eg: Los Angeles is full of young actors working as waiters, hoping to be discovered by a movie agent.

discovery.eng_def: the process of finding information, a place, or an object, especially for the first time, or the thing that is found
discovery.chi_def: （尤指首次）發現（的過程）；被發現的事物

discreet.eng_def: careful not to cause embarrassment or attract too much attention, especially by keeping something secret
discreet.eg: The family made discreet enquiries about his background.

discriminate.eng_def: to treat a person or particular group of people differently, especially in a worse way from the way in which you treat other people, because of their skin colour, sex, sexuality, etc.
discriminate.eg: She felt she had been discriminated against because of her age.

discriminate.eng_def: to be able to see the difference between two things or people
discriminate.eg: Police dogs can discriminate between the different smells.

discrimination.eng_def: treating a person or particular group of people differently, especially in a worse way from the way in which you treat other people, because of their skin colour, sex, sexuality, etc.
the ability to see the difference between two things or people

discuss.eng_def: to talk about a subject with someone and tell each other your ideas or opinions
discuss.eg: The police want to discuss these recent racist attacks with local people.

discuss.eng_def: to talk or write about a subject in detail, especially considering different ideas and opinions related to it
discuss.eg: The later chapters discuss the effects on the environment.

discussion.eng_def: the activity in which people talk about something and tell each other their ideas or opinions
discussion.eg: We will hold/have discussions with employee representatives about possible redundancies.

disease.eng_def: (an) illness of people, animals, plants, etc., caused by infection or a failure of health rather than by an accident
something that is considered very bad in people or society
disease.eg: The real disease affecting the country is inflation.

disgrace.eng_def: embarrassment and the loss of other people's respect, or behaviour that causes this
disgrace.chi_def: 恥辱，丟臉；不光彩的行為
disgrace.eg: They were sent home in disgrace.

disgrace.eng_def: to be a very bad situation
disgrace.eg: Three families living in one room - it's a disgrace!

disgrace.eng_def: to be so bad or unacceptable that you make people lose respect for the group or activity you are connected to
disgrace.eg: You're a disgrace (to the family) - what a way to behave!

disgrace.eng_def: to make people stop respecting you or your family, team, etc. by doing something very bad
disgrace.chi_def: 使丟臉，使蒙羞，使沒面子
disgrace.eg: You have disgraced us all with your behaviour.

disgraceful.chi_def: 可恥的，丟臉的，不光彩的

disguise.eng_def: to give a new appearance to a person or thing, especially in order to hide its true form
disguise.chi_def: 給…化裝，給…喬裝打扮；將…偽裝起來
disguise.eg: He disguised himself by wearing a false beard.

disguise.eng_def: to hide an opinion, a feeling, etc.
something that someone wears to hide their true appearance
disguise.chi_def: 化裝用具（服飾）；用於偽裝的東西
disguise.eg: He put on a large hat and glasses as a disguise and hoped no one would recognize him.

disguise.eng_def: If people, objects, or activities are in disguise, they appear to be something that they are not, especially intentionally.
disguise.eg: She usually goes out in disguise to avoid being bothered by the public.

disgust.eng_def: a strong feeling of disapproval and dislike at a situation, person's behaviour, etc.
to make you feel extreme dislike or disapproval
disgust.eg: Doesn't all this violence on TV disgust you?

dish.eng_def: a container, flatter than a bowl and sometimes with a lid, from which food can be served or which can be used for cooking
all the plates, glasses, knives, forks, etc. that have been used during a meal
food prepared in a particular way as part of a meal
to tell people unpleasant or shocking personal information about someone
dish.eg: She agreed to dish the dirt on her ex-husband for a large fee.

dishonest.chi_def: 不誠實的，不老實的，不正直的

disk.eng_def: a flat, circular device that is used for storing information
disk.eg: Put the disk into the drive.

dislike.eng_def: to not like someone or something
dislike.eg: Why do you dislike her so much?

dislike.eng_def: a feeling of not liking something or someone
dislike.eg: She has a dislike of cold weather.

dislike.eng_def: something that you do not like
dislike.chi_def: 不喜歡的東西，討厭的東西
dislike.eg: His main dislikes about work are the noise and dust in the factory.

dismantle.eng_def: to take a machine apart or to come apart into separate pieces
dismantle.eg: She dismantled the washing machine to see what the problem was, but couldn't put it back together again.

dismantle.eng_def: to get rid of a system or organization, usually over a period of time
dismantle.eg: Over the next three years, we will be gradually dismantling the company and selling off the profitable units.

dismay.eng_def: a feeling of unhappiness and disappointment
dismay.eg: Aid workers were said to have been filled with dismay by the appalling conditions that the refugees were living in.

dismiss.eng_def: to decide that something or someone is not important and not worth considering
dismiss.chi_def: 對…不予理會，摒棄，（從頭腦中）去除
dismiss.eg: I think he'd dismissed me as an idiot within five minutes of meeting me.

dismiss.eng_def: to remove someone from their job, especially because they have done something wrong
dismiss.chi_def: （尤指因做錯事）使免職，將…解職，解僱
dismiss.eg: He has been dismissed from his job for incompetence.

dismiss.eng_def: to formally ask or order someone to leave
dismiss.eg: The professor dismissed the class early because she had a meeting.

dismiss.eng_def: When a judge dismisses a court case, he or she formally stops the trial, often because there is not enough proof that someone is guilty.
dismiss.chi_def: （常指法官因證據不足而）駁回，不受理
dismiss.eg: The defending lawyer asked that the charge against his client be dismissed.

disorder.eng_def: a state of untidiness or lack of organization
disorder.eg: The whole office was in a state of disorder.

disorder.eng_def: an illness of the mind or body
an angry, possibly violent, expression of not being happy or satisfied about something, especially about a political matter, by crowds of people
disorder.eg: The trial was kept secret because of the risk of public disorder.

dispatch.eng_def: to send something, especially goods or a message, somewhere for a particular purpose
dispatch.eg: Two loads of cloth were dispatched to the factory on 12 December.
Our handsome hero manages to dispatch another five villains.

dispatch.eng_def: the act of sending someone or something somewhere
a newspaper report sent by someone in a foreign country, often communicating war news, or an official report, often on a military matter
dispatch.chi_def: （常指駐外記者發來的軍事方面的）新聞報道，電訊
dispatch.eg: In her latest dispatch, Clare Duggan, our war correspondent, reported an increase in fighting.

dispatch.eng_def: to be given a lot of praise for actions you have performed as a soldier
dispatch.chi_def: 在戰報中受到高度讚揚
dispatch.eg: Sergeant Havers was mentioned in dispatches for his courage.

dispensable.eng_def: more than you need and therefore not necessary; that can be got rid of
dispensable.eg: It seemed the soldiers were regarded as dispensable - their deaths just didn't matter.

dispense.eng_def: to give out things, especially products, services, or amounts of money
dispense.eg: There is a vending machine on the platform that dispenses snacks.

dispense.eng_def: to prepare and give out medicine

disperse.eng_def: to spread across or move away over a large area, or to make something do this
disperse.eg: When the rain came down the crowds started to disperse.

displace.eng_def: to force something or someone out of its usual or original position
displace.chi_def: 迫使…離開常居地（或原位）
displace.eg: The building of a new dam will displace thousands of people who live in this area.

display.eng_def: to arrange something or a collection of things so that it can be seen by the public
display.eg: Family photographs were displayed on the wall.
My grandfather disapproved of displaying emotion in public.

display.eng_def: to show words, pictures, etc. on a screen
display.eg: Retailers should display delivery times and costs on their websites.

display.eng_def: a collection of objects or pictures arranged for people to look at, or a performance or show for people to watch
display.chi_def: 陳列品，展覽品；陳列，展示，展覽；表演
display.eg: There's an Egyptian art collection on display (= being shown) at the museum at the moment.

display.eng_def: the fact of someone showing how they feel
display.eg: There's never much (of a) display of affection between them.

display.eng_def: the way in which words, pictures, etc. are shown electronically, for example on a computer screen
display.eg: The display problems might be due to a shortage of disk space.

displease.eng_def: to cause someone to be annoyed or unhappy
displease.eg: I wouldn't want to do anything to displease him.

disposable.eng_def: A disposable product is intended to be thrown away after use.

disposal.eng_def: the act of getting rid of something, especially by throwing it away
available to be used by someone
disposal.eg: I would take you if I could, but I don't have a car at my disposal this week.

dispose.eng_def: to make someone feel a particular way towards someone or something
dispose.eg: His rudeness when we first met didn't dispose me very kindlyto/towards him.

dispute.eng_def: an argument or disagreement, especially an official one between, for example, workers and employers or two countries with a common border
dispute.chi_def: （尤指勞資雙方或相鄰兩國之間的）爭執，爭端，糾紛
毫無爭議地，無可爭辯地，不容置疑地
dispute.eg: He is beyond all dispute the finest actor in Hollywood today.
I don't think her ability is in dispute - what I question is her attitude.
He says it's the best musical equipment you can buy, but I think that's open to dispute.

dispute.eng_def: to disagree with something that someone says
dispute.eg: Few would dispute his status as the finest artist of the period.

disregard.eng_def: the fact of showing no care or respect for something
disregard.eg: What amazes me is her complete disregard for anyone else's opinion.
He told us to disregard everything we'd learned so far and start again.

dissident.eng_def: a person who publicly disagrees with and criticizes their government

dissolve.eng_def: (of a solid) to be absorbed by a liquid, especially when mixed, or (of a liquid) to absorb a solid
dissolve.eg: Dissolve two spoons of powder in warm water.

dissolve.eng_def: to end an official organization or a legal arrangement

dissolve.eg: The tension in the office just dissolves when she walks out.

dissuade.eng_def: to persuade someone not to do something
dissuade.eg: I tried to dissuade her from leaving.

distance.eng_def: the amount of space between two places
distance.eg: What's the distance between Madrid and Barcelona/from Madrid to Barcelona?

distance.eng_def: from a place that is not near
distance.eg: From a distance he looks a bit like Johnny Depp.

distance.eng_def: at a point that is far away
distance.eg: On a clear day you can see the temple in the distance.

distance.eng_def: behaviour that shows little interest or friendliness
distance.eg: I noticed a certain distance between father and son.

distant.eng_def: part of your family but not closely related
far away in the past or future
distant.eg: At some point in the distant future I would like to have my own house.
They plan to have children in the not-too-distant future.

distant.eng_def: used to describe someone who does not show much emotion and is not friendly
distant.chi_def: 拒人千里的，不親近的，冷漠的

distinct.eg: There's a distinct smell of cigarettes in here.

distinct.eng_def: clearly separate and different (from something else)
distinct.chi_def: 明顯不同的，差別明顯的
distinct.eg: The two concepts are quite distinct (from each other).
She's a personal assistant, as distinct from a secretary.

distinction.eng_def: a difference between two similar things
distinction.eg: There's a clear distinction between the dialects spoken in the two regions.

distinction.eng_def: a mark given to students who produce work of an excellent standard
the quality of being special or different
distinction.eg: She has the distinction of being one of the few people to have an honorary degree conferred on her by the university this year.

distinctive.eng_def: Something that is distinctive is easy to recognize because it is different from other things.
distinctive.chi_def: 與眾不同的，獨特的，特別的

distinguish.eng_def: to notice or understand the difference between two things, or to make one person or thing seem different from another
distinguish.eg: He's colour-blind and can't distinguish (the difference) between red and green easily.

distinguish.eng_def: to do something so well that you are admired and praised for it
distinguish.chi_def: 使自己出類拔萃，表現突出
distinguish.eg: He distinguished himself as a writer at a very early age.

distinguished.eng_def: used to describe a respected and admired person, or their work
used to describe a person, especially an older person, who looks formal, stylish, or wise
distinguished.chi_def: （尤指長者）氣度不凡的，高雅的，睿智的
distinguished.eg: I think grey hair on a man can look very distinguished.

distort.eng_def: to change something from its usual, original, natural, or intended meaning, condition, or shape
distort.eg: My original statement has been completely distorted by the media.

distract.eng_def: to make someone stop giving their attention to something
distract.chi_def: 使分心，使轉移注意力，干擾

distraction.eng_def: the state of being very bored or annoyed
distraction.eg: His lessons bore me to distraction.

distraction.eng_def: something that prevents someone from giving their attention to something else
distraction.chi_def: 分心的事；分散注意力的東西
distraction.eg: I can turn the television off if you find it a distraction.

distraction.eng_def: an activity that you do for pleasure
distraction.eg: one of the distractions of city life

distress.eng_def: a feeling of extreme worry, sadness, or pain
distress.eg: She claimed that the way she had been treated at work had caused her extreme emotional and psychological distress.

distress.eng_def: a situation in which you are suffering or are in great danger and therefore in urgent need of help
distress.eg: Six people were rescued by helicopter from a fishing boat in distress off the coast.

distress.eng_def: to make someone feel very upset or worried
distress.eg: I hope I haven't distressed you with all these personal questions.

distribute.eng_def: to give something out to several people, or to spread or supply something
distribute.eg: The books will be distributed free to local schools.

distribution.eng_def: the process of giving things out to several people, or spreading or supplying something
distribution.eg: Has the Channel Tunnel improved the distribution of goods between the British Isles and mainland Europe?

distribution.eng_def: the way in which people or things are spread out in a place
distribution.eg: a map showing distribution of global population

district.eng_def: an area of a country or town that has fixed borders that are used for official purposes, or that has a particular feature that makes it different from surrounding areas
district.eg: the business district of New York

distrust.eng_def: the feeling of not trusting someone or something
distrust.eg: The two groups have existed in a state of mutual distrust for centuries.

distrust.eng_def: to not trust someone or something
distrust.eg: Many politicians are deeply distrusted by the electorate.

disturb.eng_def: to interrupt what someone is doing
disturb.eg: Please don't disturb your sister - she's trying to do her homework.

disturb.eng_def: to break the law by behaving unpleasantly and noisily in public
disturb.eg: Several fans were arrested and charged with disturbing the peace after the game.

disturb.eng_def: to cause someone to be worried or upset
disturb.eg: Some scenes are violent and may disturb younger viewers.

disturb.eng_def: to move or change something from its usual position, arrangement, condition, or shape
disturb.eg: The thief had disturbed the documents in her filing cabinet, but nothing had been taken.

disturbance.eng_def: something that interrupts someone or makes someone feel worried
disturbance.eg: Residents are tired of the disturbance caused by the nightclub.
There was a minor disturbance during the demonstration, but nobody was injured.

disturbance.eng_def: to break the law by fighting or behaving extremely noisily in public

ditch.eng_def: a long, narrow open hole that is dug into the ground, usually at the side of a road or field, used especially for supplying or removing water or for dividing land
ditch.chi_def: （尤指路邊或田邊用來供水、排水或劃分土地的）溝渠，壕溝

ditch.eng_def: to get rid of something or someone that is no longer wanted
ditch.eg: The getaway car had been ditched a couple of miles away from the scene of the robbery.

ditch.eng_def: to land an aircraft in water in an emergency

dive.eng_def: to jump into water, especially with your head and arms going in first, or to move down under the water
dive.chi_def: （尤指頭和手臂先入水的）跳水；下潛
dive.eg: Look at those children diving for oysters over there!

dive.eng_def: to swim underwater, usually with breathing equipment
dive.chi_def: （通常指攜帶呼吸設備的）潛水

dive.eng_def: to fall in value suddenly and by a large amount
dive.eg: The company's shares dived by 90p to 65p on the stock market yesterday.
The plane dived towards the ground and exploded in a ball of flame.

dive.eng_def: to move quickly, often in order to avoid something
dive.eg: They dived for cover when they heard the shooting start.

dive.eng_def: in football, to fall down deliberately without another player causing you to fall, in order to try to win a penalty or a free kick unfairly
dive.eg: Referees should be booking players when they dive.

dive.eng_def: a jump into water with your head going in first
dive.chi_def: （尤指頭和手臂先入水的）跳水
dive.eg: the best dive of the competition
The company's profits took a dive last month.

dive.eng_def: a movement down onto the ground
dive.eg: The goalkeeper made a valiant dive for the ball, but he couldn't quite get his hands on it.

dive.eng_def: in football, the action of falling down deliberately without another player causing you to do so, in order to try to win a penalty or free kick unfairly

dive.eg: He made a dive for the door.

dive.eng_def: a restaurant, hotel, bar, or place for entertainment or social activities that is unpleasant because of the condition of the building or the type of people that go there
dive.chi_def: 低級的餐館（或飯店、酒吧、娛樂場所）
dive.eg: The place is a real dive, but the drinks are cheap and the food's great.

diverse.eng_def: including many different types of people or things
diverse.chi_def: 多種多樣的，形形色色的
diverse.eg: Students from countries as diverse as Colombia and Lithuania use Cambridge textbooks.
We hold very diverse views on the topic.

diversify.eng_def: to start to include more different types or things
diversify.eg: Millions of years ago, changes in the earth's climate caused animal and plant life to diversify.

diversify.eng_def: If a business diversifies, it starts making new products or offering new services.
diversify.chi_def: （使）多元化經營，（使）從事多種經營
diversify.eg: Many wheat farmers have begun to diversify into other forms of agriculture.

diversion.eng_def: a different route that is used because a road is closed
diversion.eg: Traffic diversions will be kept to a minimum throughout the festival.

diversion.eng_def: the fact of something being sent somewhere different from where it was originally intended to go
diversion.eg: the diversion of money to other projects

diversion.eng_def: something that takes your attention away from something else
diversion.chi_def: 轉移注意力的事物；分心的事物
diversion.eg: Shoplifters often work in pairs, with one creating a diversion to distract the staff while the other steals the goods.

diversion.eng_def: an activity you do for entertainment

diversity.eng_def: the fact of many different types of things or people being included in something; a range of different things or people
diversity.eg: Does television adequately reflect the ethnic and cultural diversity of the country?

diversity.eng_def: the fact that there are many different ideas or opinions about something
diversity.eg: There is a wide diversity of opinion on the question of unilateral disarmament.

divert.eng_def: to cause something or someone to change direction
divert.eg: Traffic will be diverted through the side streets while the main road is resurfaced.

divert.eng_def: to use something for a different purpose
divert.chi_def: 將…用於其他目的；改變…的用途
divert.eg: Should more funds/money/resources be diverted from roads into railways?

divert.eng_def: to take someone's attention away from something
divert.eg: The war has diverted attention (away) from the country's economic problems.
It's a great game for diverting restless kids on long car rides .

divide.eng_def: to (cause to) separate into parts or groups
divide.eg: At the end of the lecture, I'd like all the students to divide into small discussion groups.
I think we should divide (up) the costs equally among/between us.

divide.eng_def: If something divides two areas, it marks the edge or limit of them.
divide.eg: There's a narrow alley that divides our house from the one next door.

divide.eng_def: to use different amounts of something for different purposes or activities
divide.eg: She divides her time between her apartment in New York and her house in the Berkshires.

divide.eng_def: If Members of Parliament divide, they vote by separating into two groups, one group who want the law that is being voted on to be accepted and one group who are against it.
divide.chi_def: （議會等）分贊成和反對兩組進行表決
divide.eg: After a lengthy debate, MPs/the House of Commons divided.

divide.eng_def: to cause a group of people to disagree about something
divide.eg: The party is divided on/over the issue of capital punishment.

divide.eng_def: a way of keeping yourself in a position of power by causing disagreements among other people so that they are unable to oppose you
to calculate the number of times that one number fits (exactly) into another
If a number divides into another number, it fits (exactly) into it when multiplied a particular number of times.
divide.eg: What do you get if you divide 6 into 18?
The divide between the rich and the poor in this country is continuing to grow.

divine.eng_def: connected with a god, or like a god
divine.eg: Some fans seem to regard the players as divine beings.
We had a perfectly divine time in Switzerland.
I divined from his grim expression that the news was not good.

divine.eng_def: to search for water or minerals underground by holding horizontally in your hands a Y-shaped rod or stick, the end of which suddenly points down slightly when water or minerals are below it
divine.chi_def: （用丫形杖）探測（地下水或礦藏）

division.eng_def: the act of separating something into parts or groups, or the way that it is separated
division.eg: the equal division of labour between workers

division.eng_def: a separate part of an army or large organization
a group of teams that play against each other in a particular sport
division.eg: The team plays in one of the lower divisions.

division.eng_def: the calculation of how many times one number goes into another
the situation in which people disagree about something
division.eg: Disagreements about defence cuts have opened up deep divisions within the military.

divorce.eng_def: an official or legal process to end a marriage
divorce.eg: The last I heard they were getting a divorce.
Why is there such a divorce between the arts and the sciences in this country's schools?

divorce.eng_def: to end your marriage by an official or legal process

divorce.eg: How can you divorce the issues of environmental protection and overpopulation?

divorce.eng_def: a man who is divorced and who has not married again
divorce.chi_def: 離了婚尚未再婚的男人

dizzy.eng_def: feeling as if everything is turning around, and that you are not able to balance and may fall down
dizzy.chi_def: 眩暈的，頭暈目眩的，眼花繚亂的
dizzy.eg: Going without sleep for a long time makes me feel dizzy and light-headed.
Who could have predicted the dizzy pace of change in the country?

dizzy.eng_def: A dizzy person, especially a woman, is silly.
dizzy.eg: In the movie, she played the part of a dizzy blonde.

dizzy.eng_def: in a dizzy way or a way that makes you feel dizzy
dizzy.chi_def: 令人目眩地，使人頭暈地
dizzy.eg: The skyscrapers towered dizzily above us.

do.eng_def: used with another verb to form questions and negative sentences, including negative orders, and sometimes in affirmative sentences for reasons of style
do.chi_def: （與另一動詞連用構成疑問句和否定句，包括表示禁止的命令，有時因文體原因亦可用於肯定句）
do.eg: Where do you work?
